title: St. Michaels VFD places new engine into service
author: Mike Detmer; mdetmer@chespub.com
content:
The St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department (SMVFD) placed its new Engine 45, a 2023 E‑One Cyclone, into service on July 27, 2023. The engine tanker, equipped with a 1,035‑gallon water tank, Cummins L9 engine, Hale QMAX pump, Harrison hydraulic generator, Whelen and Firetech lighting, and an Arkon electric monitor, has already responded to calls, including pumping water for an attic fire in town the previous week. It carries 1,000 feet of 5‑inch supply hose, 500 feet of 3‑inch hose, five attack lines, a Blitzfire monitor, a battery‑powered fan, work lights and a full complement of firefighting tools, and replaces Engine 49 as the “first‑due” apparatus after Engine 48, a 1990 model that served for 33 years, was moved to reserve.

Funding for the $718,850 apparatus came from multiple sources. “It’s a combination of fundraising efforts and money that we get from the county, town and state,” President Chris Thomas said. The department also issued a statement: “The department thanks the generous residents and businesses who helped make this purchase happen through their donations and support over the past few years.” Thomas highlighted the community’s role, noting that fundraising events such as barbecue chicken dinners, a fund drive, and “pit beef and pit turkey offerings” are popular, adding, “I think that it is off the charts it’s phenomenal.”

SMVFD, with roughly 70 members—about half of whom are fire and EMS personnel—faces the same staffing challenges as many fire agencies. Thomas explained that the town’s retiree‑heavy demographics help staff the administrative side, but “We’re hurting just like everyone else.” Despite the manpower crunch and a three‑to‑five‑year lead time for new equipment, the department continues to plan for future acquisitions, including upgrades to its brush truck and tanker truck. Engine 45 now sits in the right‑hand bay of the firehouse, ready to carry volunteers to the next call.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a volunteer fire department acquiring a new fire engine, which is directly related to emergency services and public safety.

title: Escape or die - BI: 'Kidnapped, chained' woman escaped from cell built inside home
author: Molly O Brien; Herald & News
content:
An Oregon man, Negasi Zuberi, 29, has been indicted on interstate kidnapping and sexual‑assault charges after a woman escaped from a sound‑proof, cinder‑block cell built in the garage of the house he rented in the 1300 block of North Eldorado Avenue, Klamath Falls. Police say the victim was “kidnapped, chained (and) sexually assaulted” and “kidnapped, chained, sexually assaulted and locked in a cinderblock cell,” according to a news release from the FBI’s Portland field office. The complaint alleges Zuberi lured the woman, identified only as Adult Victim 1, on the morning of July 15 to engage in prostitution along Seattle’s Aurora Avenue, then claimed to be an undercover officer, handcuffed and leg‑ironed her, and drove her 450 miles to his Oregon home where he assaulted her during the trip.

After arriving, the victim was placed in the garage‑built cell with a metal door that could not be opened from the inside. “Once Zuberi left, the victim says she repeatedly banged on the door and was able to break the door open and escape the room,” the release said. The victim recalled Zuberi telling her he was leaving “to do paperwork.” While trying to get out, she “repeatedly punched the door with her own hands,” Klamath Falls Police Capt. Rob Reynolds told a news conference, adding that “She had several lacerations along her knuckles.” She eventually broke enough of the welded joints to climb through, broke into Zuberi’s vehicle, seized a handgun, and fled to the street, where she climbed over a wooden fence, flagged down a passing motorist, and was taken to Sky Lakes Medical Center.

FBI Assistant Special Agent in Charge Stephanie Shark said investigators have identified “three additional victims from other states where (Zuberi) has lived,” and that “Those states could include: California, Washington, Oregon, Colorado, Utah, Florida, New York, New Jersey, Alabama, and Nevada,” according to an FBI statement. Evidence found at the residence included handwritten notes titled “Operation Take Over” and a sketch for an underground structure. “Her quick thinking and will to survive may have saved other women from a similar nightmare,” Shark said.

Klamath Falls Mayor Carol Westfall, who and her husband Kevin owned the rental property, said there were no prior indications of Zuberi’s criminal activity. “We had service people going there, and he would invite us in,” Westfall said. “It was incredibly brazen.” She added, “He came into this town, but it’s over for him.” Zuberi, also known as Sakima, Justin Hyche, and Justin Kouassi, has been charged “with interstate kidnapping and transporting an individual across state lines with intent to engage in criminal sexual activity,” the U.S. Attorney’s Office for Oregon said in a statement. After the escape, Zuberi and his family fled to Reno, Nevada, where Nevada State Patrol located them the next afternoon; Zuberi surrendered after a brief standoff. The child in the car was reported unharmed.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details a kidnapping, sexual assault, and a makeshift prison, focusing on criminal activity and law‑enforcement response, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Baltimore police clear homeless encampment
author: Connor Bolinder; connor.bolinder@chespub.com
content:
On July 21, 2023, Baltimore City police, first responders and outreach workers cleared the homeless encampment on the corner of Dundalk and Holabird Avenues. A “No Trespassing” notice posted earlier that month warned that “the area would be cleared on July 21.” The encampment, which had been occupied since earlier in the year with tents set up on a strip of grass in front of the Holabird Business Park, was cleared by noon that day.

Baltimore City police issued a statement to the Old Dundalk Neighborhood Association saying, “Members of the Baltimore County Homeless Services Division have been working closely with Baltimore City officials to address the encampment near Dundalk and Holabird Avenues,” and adding, “We understand how concerning it is to see this situation in your community. As the encampment is located on city property, the Baltimore City Mayor’s Office of Homeless Services is leading response efforts in coordination with other City agencies, including the Baltimore City Police Department, Baltimore City Department of Public Works, and Baltimore City Department of Transportation with support from nonprofit organizations under contract with Baltimore County to provide outreach and access to services.” The Mayor’s Office of Homeless Services and nonprofit groups visited the site before the clearance to connect residents with shelter and drug‑treatment resources.

Community groups—including the Old Dundalk Neighborhood Association, Boston Courts, Norwood‑Holabird and Graceland Park—had been lobbying for months. In February they wrote a letter to city and county officials requesting a solution, noting that long‑term tent living posed public‑health concerns and that police were regularly called to the site for crime and drug‑use incidents. Baltimore Police Precinct 12 Capt. Glenn Wiedeck and City Police Maj. Kiera Saunders coordinated crime‑call responses, and ODNA President Jess Lilli observed, “They’re actually speaking to each other right now and that didn’t happen in the past,” in April.

The Baltimore County Police Department, while not having jurisdiction over the city‑owned property, pledged to assist any displaced persons. The department said, “Though this is a Baltimore City operation the Baltimore County Police Department is aware of the impact it may have on the surrounding county communities and is taking steps to offer any homeless person(s) services and resources if they attempt to migrate into Baltimore County,” and added, “Officers will also be in place to remind any of these homeless person(s) that the camp sites they are used to in Baltimore City will not be allowed in Baltimore County.” The operation concluded with Department of Public Works crews hauling away tents, belongings and trash, leaving the cleared site vacant.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on police and first responders clearing a homeless encampment, highlighting law enforcement actions and public safety concerns, making Public Safety the most fitting category.

title: Never plug these into power strip
content:
For safety reasons, several common household appliances should never be plugged into a power strip. Hair‑dressing tools such as hairdryers, curling wands and flat irons require large amounts of amperage to generate heat, so they must be connected directly to a wall outlet—ideally one equipped with a ground‑fault circuit interrupter breaker to protect against water exposure. Refrigerators and freezers also draw continuous current as they cycle on and off, which can quickly overload a power strip, so they need a dedicated wall outlet. Likewise, toasters and toaster ovens have exposed heating elements that require high current, making them unsuitable for extension cords or power strips.

Microwave ovens, which perform rapid cooking, thawing and reheating, demand more energy than a power strip can provide, and portable space heaters commonly use about 1,500 watts on their highest settings, creating a hazard if run from a strip for extended periods. All of these appliances should be plugged directly into wall outlets to avoid overloading power strips and to reduce the risk of electrical fires.

llm_classification.explanation: The article provides safety instructions to prevent electrical hazards, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: WHAT A NIGHT! - Storms cause damage, flooding in Mid-Shore region
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
A line of strong storms moved through Maryland’s Mid‑Shore region on Monday evening, dumping heavy rain and gusty winds. By 8 a.m. Tuesday the National Weather Service recorded Cambridge’s 24‑hour rainfall total at just over 4 inches, St. Michaels at about 2.7 inches, Easton at just over 2 inches and Denton at roughly 1.7 inches. Dorchester County Emergency Management Planner Jimmy Windsor said the 4 inches of rain fell in about two hours, quadrupling forecasts, and the downpours produced flooding that left motorists in the Henry Street area wading through more than two feet of water.

The storms also sparked a lightning‑induced fire on Maiden Forest Road near Vienna, which was quickly contained, and caused widespread damage reported by weather‑service storm logs, including damage to an Oxford restaurant and an “abundance” of downed trees and wires in Bozman and portions of Queen Anne’s County. In Westminster, dozens of vehicles were trapped after power lines fell like dominoes onto a highway; utility crews turned off the electricity, allowing the 33 adults and 14 children in the cars to escape safely, Maryland State Police Superintendent Col. Roland Butler said at a news conference Tuesday. A spokesperson for Maryland’s largest power utility, BGE, called the destruction “catastrophic.” Nick Alexopulos, speaking at a news conference Monday night, added, “This is damage that if you worked in electric distribution at BGE for your entire career, you may see it once.”

First responders and state officials praised the coordinated rescue effort. Gov. Wes Moore said, “There were people who were stuck and stranded in cars who were able to sleep in their own beds last night.” The storms disrupted air travel across the mid‑Atlantic, with FlightAware reporting more than 2,600 U.S. flights canceled and nearly 7,900 delayed by Monday night, and the FAA warning of continued low clouds, winds and thunderstorms affecting airports nationwide on Tuesday.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on storm‑related hazards, flooding, emergency responders, power outages, and safety measures, which align most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Police investigating Easton homicide
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
The Easton Police Department is investigating a homicide that occurred Monday evening on Blake Street in Easton, Maryland. Officers were dispatched to 104 Blake St. at about 7 p.m. after receiving a report of a person who had been shot and was lying in the grass.

The victim was identified as 55‑year‑old Ty A. Brooks of Easton. Police rendered aid until Talbot County paramedics arrived, but Brooks died from his injuries at the scene and was later taken to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner for an autopsy.

Police later learned that Brooks had been involved in an argument with people on the street. After shots were fired, witnesses reported seeing a white SUV flee the scene with Black male occupants. The homicide remains an ongoing investigation, and investigators are asking anyone with information to come forward.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a homicide investigation by the Easton Police Department, which is primarily a public safety issue.

title: Cambridge theater has another incident of smoke in theater
content:
Fire crews responded on Wednesday, Aug. 10, 2023, to the Cambridge Premier Cinema after receiving a report of smoke inside the theater. This was the second such incident in two weeks at the venue, which is located on the 2700 block of Dorchester Square Mall in Cambridge, Maryland.  

The earlier incident on July 29 and the most recent on Aug. 9 were each investigated and determined to have been caused by a malfunction in an air‑handler on the roof of the cinema. Multiple fire companies and other emergency personnel were dispatched to both events.  

The story was reported by the Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). © 2023 Star Democrat.

title: Dispute over girlfriend led to shooting, police say - Suspect arrested in D.C. area after massive manhunt
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Police say Stewart Orlando Ray, 37, of Clinton, opened fire on Jahari De’Mon Cooper, 39, of Talbot County, near Unionville on Sunday evening after a dispute over a common girlfriend. Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office responded to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton around 9 p.m. when Cooper, who was driving, “passed Ray’s vehicle, Ray shot at him multiple times, striking both him and his car.” Cooper was able to drive himself to the emergency room for treatment. Ray fled the scene, failed to stop for a stop sign at Unionville Road and Bruffs Island Road, collided with several parked cars, disabled his own vehicle and then ran into nearby woods, prompting a 24‑hour manhunt that began early Monday.

Investigators learned Tuesday morning that Ray may have slipped through the search area during severe storms and headed toward the Washington, D.C., metro area. The Talbot County Sheriff’s Office contacted the U.S. Marshals Capitol Area Regional Fugitive Task Force, which located Ray in northern Virginia that afternoon. At 12:46 p.m. on Tuesday, Alexandria police responded to a shooting at the Potomac Yard Shopping Center; officers discovered that the U.S. Marshals task force had found Ray and that “Ray was shot when the task force attempted to apprehend him,” after which he was taken to a hospital with life‑threatening injuries. Detectives from the Alexandria Police Department are now investigating the shooting and are coordinating with the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office. Ray, who is on probation for a 2009 attempted second‑degree murder conviction, now faces charges of attempted murder, first‑degree assault, reckless endangerment and use of a firearm in a violent crime or felony.

Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble praised the multi‑agency effort, saying, “I am incredibly grateful to the countless state, local and federal law enforcement officers on the Eastern Shore, CARTIF, and the Alexandria Police Department who willingly put themselves in harm’s way to make our community safer during this manhunt.” He added, “During these strange times, as the Maryland Legislature continues to make policing more difficult, it is inspiring to know that there are still selfless men and women who are willing to risk their lives daily for all of us, knowing that their every action will be scrutinized by people who have risked nothing and have never known real danger.I can't thank these public servants enough for their sacrifice and heroism.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a shooting, police investigation, and a multi‑agency manhunt, which are core subjects of public safety reporting.

title: Fire group raising $5 million for training center
content:
The Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department have launched a two‑to‑three‑year capital campaign to raise $5 million for the Emergency Services Training Campus at 9095 Mistletoe Drive. The state‑of‑the‑art facility will sit on a 2.7‑acre property gifted by the town and will include a 3,500‑square‑foot concrete public‑safety building, a 3,600‑square‑foot classroom and storage building, and a 1,500‑square‑foot concrete pad for car‑fire, extrication, stabilization, and traffic‑safety training. It is intended to serve Easton’s volunteer fire department, the six local volunteer fire departments in Talbot County, and fire departments across the Mid‑Shore, as well as law‑enforcement and EMS personnel. Talbot County has 260 active firefighters; the Easton Volunteer Fire Department responded to 896 calls involving 10,000 man‑hours and completed 1,910 hours of training in 2022.

"This state-of-the-art training campus will not only support EVFD members for their training but will also help us in recruiting and training new members for the department. The training campus will also enable us to support our partners in law enforcement and emergency services in their training and recruitment needs and to better coordinate our roles in emergencies.We encourage the community to support our fundraising efforts as we embark on this $5 million goal," said fire Capt. Daryl Caldwell.  

"It has never been more important than now to train our first responders and emergency personnel who serve Talbot County every day. There currently is no dedicated first responder training campus in Talbot County. The Friends of the EVFD and its volunteers accepted the challenge to raise $5 million for facility construction and operational expenses for the new campus.This campaign is essential toward ensuring cutting-edge training is available for all emergency services personnel," said campaign co‑chairman Brett Whitehead.  

"The sheriff's office is very excited to see this project come to fruition. The facility will not only offer training to our dedicated volunteer firefighters but will be able to support training for our deputies and police officers. Our citizens deserve the best-trained law enforcement officers. This training facility will support localized training to better equip our deputies while saving hard‑earned taxpayer funds through reduced travel time and associated expenses. The facility will also be available for K‑9 training for tracking people as well as drug detection," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said.  

"We're very excited about the brand-new state-of-the-art training facility to be used by fire departments, EMTs, and law enforcement around the Mid‑Shore. This facility will allow us to train and recruit talented first responders from around the region. The Town is fully committed to helping our first responders safely and effectively serve our community, and this training facility is a crucial resource that will improve many facets of their operations. We are very thankful for the dedication and selfless service of the men and women who volunteer to protect and serve our Town, and thankful that they go above and beyond to ensure our community's safety," Easton Mayor Megan Cook said.  

For more information or to donate, contact campaign co‑chair Brett Whitehead at (302) 236‑6249 or whitenj20@gmail.com.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a fire department's capital campaign to build an Emergency Services Training Campus for firefighters, EMTs, and law enforcement, which is primarily about public safety training and facilities.

title: St. Michaels reorganizes police, OKs raises
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
The St. Michaels Commissioners voted unanimously on Wednesday to revise police job descriptions and approve salary raises tied to a new organizational structure. The restructuring was prompted by the retirement of former Chief Anthony Smith on June 30, after which newly appointed Chief Jeffrey Oswald was sworn in the same day, leaving the captain’s position vacant. Rather than recruit a new captain—whose salary would have ranged from $85,000 to $100,000—Chief Oswald recommended promoting two officers to sergeant and eliminating the captain role.

Under the old model the department consisted of a chief, a captain, two corporals and four patrol officers. The approved structure now includes the chief and two sergeants, each supervising two officers. A memo in the town‑meeting agenda noted that the sergeants will be able to cover each other’s duties but will have distinct primary focuses: one will assist the chief with patrol responsibilities and the other with administrative tasks. The change will have a minimal budgetary impact, with the total base‑salary increase for the restructuring calculated at $7,200. The promoted sergeants will undergo mandatory first‑line administrator training, be recognized by the Police Training Commission to command in the chief’s absence, and will serve a two‑year probationary period.

The St. Michaels Police Department is located at 100 S. Fremont St. © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group.

title: Plane crashes during landing at Bay Bridge Airport
author: Staff Writer
content:
On the morning of April 30, 2025, a four‑seat Cirrus aircraft crashed while landing at Bay Bridge Airport in Stevensville, Queen Anne’s County. Upon touchdown the plane veered off the side of the runway into a marshy area, coming to rest partially in the water.

The sole occupant was not injured, according to Beth Malasky, public information manager for the county. While the aircraft sustained significant damage, the runway itself was undamaged.

Local fire departments and EMS cleared the scene shortly after noon, and federal and state aviation authorities were dispatched to conduct a standard investigation. Malasky said the airport will remain closed until the investigation is complete.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a local aircraft crash and the emergency response, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The Star Democrat’s most‑viewed online stories for the week of June 28, 2025 were ranked by page‑view counts as of Wednesday evening. The top story was the death of recent Easton High School graduate Darren Foxwell, noted as a loss for the Easton community. A second‑place story detailed a body left in a Greensboro yard for “upwards of four hours” after a medical examiner was delayed by Bay Bridge traffic; the incident occurred on June 22 at about 1:57 p.m. on Maple Avenue, Greensboro.  

The third‑through‑tenth stories covered a series of public‑safety incidents and local developments: a serious rollover crash outside Trappe on June 17 at around 4:30 a.m. on Chloras Point Road and Claylands Road, where a passenger was ejected and suffered life‑threatening injuries; the death of an Easton man in a car crash in Anne Arundel County; a rollover on Route 16 near Egypt Road Park in Cambridge with no injuries; the arrest of two Cambridge men and an Easton woman tied to a recent bank robbery; the upcoming opening of a second Molly’s Place store in Easton later this summer; the reopening of the Blue Crab Coffee Shop in St. Michaels under new owners; a guilty plea for attempted first‑degree murder in a Trappe gas‑station shooting; and the resignation of Easton’s winningest basketball coach, Keenan, after the season ended.  

The list concludes with a prompt to read the full stories at stardem.com. © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 2 charged with hindering drug investigation, reporting fake shooting in Easton
author: Konner Metz
content:
Police arrested Elon Black, 38, of Easton, and Lacira Wilson, 39, of Worton, for hindering a drug investigation that began on April 4. Officers stopped Black’s vehicle near U.S. Route 50 and Cecil Drive, and a K‑9 search discovered “suspected heroin/fentanyl mix,” crack cocaine and ecstasy, police wrote. During the stop Black was on his phone and called Wilson, who then placed a 911 call reporting a fake shooting at the Easton Walmart; officers who responded found no evidence of shots fired.

Both defendants were taken into custody on September 18 and 19 and charged with intent to distribute drugs, obstructing and hindering, and making false statements to police officers. Each posted a $10,000 unsecured personal bond, meaning the full amount is owed only if they miss a court date or violate other conditions.

Wilson’s trial is set for November 5 in Talbot County District Court, where she faces four counts: obstructing and hindering, making a false statement to officers, and two counts of possession with intent to distribute a controlled dangerous substance. Black’s trial is scheduled for November 3 in the same court on the identical four charges.

In a separate case in Talbot County Circuit Court, Black also faces two felony counts of possession with intent to distribute narcotics, six misdemeanors and 11 traffic violations stemming from the April 4 traffic stop; a jury trial for those charges is slated for December 8. He posted a $10,000 unsecured bond for the felony charges back in July.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on police arrests, criminal charges, and a false emergency report, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Gallatin County Sheriff's Office welcomes public to tour new building at Four Corners
author: Laurenz Busch Chronicle Staff Writer
content:
Sheriff Dan Springer hosted a public tour of the new Gallatin County Sheriff’s Office building in Four Corners on Wednesday, marking the next phase of modernizing the county’s law‑enforcement facilities. The 25,000‑square‑foot, 6.48‑acre site off Laura Louise Lane near Jackrabbit Lane was purchased for $5.4 million in 2020 and has been occupied since the summer. The location, within a nine‑mile radius of most calls, “Seventy percent of our calls occurring within that radius is pretty significant,” Springer said. “Getting our calls from here has been excellent and puts us right to where we need to be.” The move also eliminates the need for deputies to navigate traffic on 19th Avenue and Huffine Lane from the former office at the Gallatin County Detention Center.

The facility includes three shooting ranges—one 100‑yard and a 25‑yard “most active bay”—space for patrol units, detectives, and the Missouri River Drug Task Force, and a main conference room where fireplaces crackled, dual TVs displayed, and cookies and coffee were served. Springer explained the financial rationale, noting, “There wasn’t enough money to build a facility, which had been the plan to build our Sheriff’s Office up by the jail,” Springer said. “Since we couldn’t do that, there wasn’t that kind of money available, so we ended up remodeling this to make it more fiscally‑responsible.” While demonstrating the 25‑yard range he added, “We do most of our training here, this is by far the most active bay,” Springer said. “You can do movements and cover and all that type of stuff but the only thing I would do differently is try and figure out a way to get a car down here (to train with).” He further noted, “We train a lot in shooting, but when you look at the big picture, it’s (mostly) traffic stops and domestic responses,” Springer said. “(Ranges were) the bonus to the facility. The primary objective when we purchased this was the fact that it’s 6.48 acres, in the middle of Four Corners, which is where we’re growing and where our primary routes are.”

The tour’s first stop featured a dedication to deputies who died in the line of duty, noting that over the past 160 years the office has lost five deputies, most recently Jake Allmendinger in 2019 after a patrol‑vehicle accident on Bridger Canyon Road—a stretch that was dedicated to him in May. A Sheriff’s Office chaplain recounted that two deputies were killed in 1917 while pursuing a suspect. County auditor Jill Therrien and CFO Justine Swanson attended the tour, and a new search‑and‑rescue building is under construction across the street as the county works toward a broader law‑enforcement and emergency‑response campus.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the county sheriff's office, its new building, law‑enforcement operations and public tours, which are core aspects of public safety. It also involves county officials, linking it to local government, but public safety is the primary theme.

title: Automotive Group gives $300,000 to first responder training campus
author: Contributed
content:
The Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department received a $300,000 donation from Preston Automotive Group to fund an Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton, Maryland. “Preston Automotive Group is proud to support an amazing project that will benefit the first responders in our local counties firsthand,” said David Wilson Jr., president of Preston Automotive Group. He added, “We are grateful to have so many brave men and women putting their lives on the line daily to make sure we are all safe. These men and women are the backbone of our community, the least we could do is contribute to a facility that will help train them and give them the resources they need to be as prepared as possible for situations that come their way while protecting us.”

Located at 9095 Mistletoe Drive, the campus will serve Talbot County fire departments, emergency‑service personnel, law enforcement and paramedics. The project includes a 3,500‑square‑foot public‑safety building, a 3,600‑square‑foot classroom and storage building, and a 1,500‑square‑foot concrete pad for car‑fire, extrusion/stabilization and traffic‑safety training. Training will cover firefighting skills, rescue and motor‑vehicle fire/extraction for fire departments; hostage rescue, physical testing, traffic training, Homeland Security and K‑9 for law enforcement; and classroom space for EMS. “We train together because we answer the call together,” said Brett Whitehead, co‑chairman of the Public Safety Capital Campaign and president of the Friends of EVFD. He explained, “The donation from the Preston Automotive Group is an essential first step toward ensuring training available for all emergency services in Talbot County, including our volunteer firefighters, our law enforcement and our emergency services personnel and paramedics. The demand for these services continues to grow on the Mid‑Shore and this training campus will help meet this critical need.”

For additional information or to contribute to the Friends of EVFD Public Safety Capital Campaign, contact Brett Whitehead at (302) 236‑6249 or whitenj20@gmail.com. The caption accompanying the announcement shows Dave Wilson Jr. and Dave Wilson Sr. of Preston Automotive Group; Brett Whitehead, president of Friends of EVFD; Rick Stacy, president of EVFD; Ed Forte, vice president of Friends of EVFD; Daryl Caldwell, captain of EVFD; and Joe Gamble, Talbot County Sheriff. © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group.

title: Dead body found in Walmart parking lot in Denton
author: Konner Metz
content:
A dead body was discovered inside a vehicle in the Walmart parking lot in Denton on Wednesday afternoon after police received a call just before 3 p.m., according to Denton Police Chief George Bacorn. The body was found by officers responding to the report.

Chief Bacorn said the investigation is active and, as of now, there is “no indication of foul play.” A cause of death has not yet been determined, and authorities are awaiting findings from the medical examiner’s office.

As of Friday, the Denton Police Department has not released the deceased person’s name. The incident was reported by the Star Democrat on January 24, 2025.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police investigation of a dead body found in a public parking lot, which falls under public safety/crime reporting.

people: George Bacorn, Police Chief

title: 2-structure fire causes $850,000 in damage
author: Tom McCall
content:
On August 21, 2024, Cambridge firefighters responded to a two‑structure, two‑alarm fire on Stone Boundary Road. No deaths or injuries were reported. The blaze involved a former butcher shop and storage building and a neighboring wooden‑frame farmhouse.

Seventy‑five firefighters worked for three hours to bring the fire under control, according to a release from the office of the State Fire Marshal, and the Tanker Task Force was called in for additional water. The combined loss of both buildings was estimated at $600,000, with the contents valued at $250,000.

According to the fire marshal’s report, "The fire originated inside the butcher shop shortly after the owner had been doing work inside. Embers from this fire landed on the cedar shingles of the vacant nearby 100+ year old home eventually spreading to the remainder of the house. Both structures are considered a total loss." The investigation also noted that there were no smoke alarms present.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a two-structure fire, the emergency response by firefighters, and safety details, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: After The Storm
content:
A baby was photographed looking out the window of a truck as it navigated the flooded streets of Horseshoe Beach, Florida, after Hurricane Idalia passed through the area on Wednesday, Aug. 30, 2023. The image, captured by AP photographer Rebecca Blackwell, shows the child surveying storm damage while the vehicle made its way through the community.

The photo appeared in the Sept. 4, 2023 edition of the Star Democrat (Easton, MD) on page 2 of the News section. © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Human trafficking expert hired by For All Seasons
content:
For All Seasons is participating in the Governor’s Maryland Regional Navigator Program, a statewide effort that serves human‑trafficking victims under the age of 24 on the Mid‑Shore. The organization’s new human‑trafficking navigator, Susan Ahlstrom, is being linked with experts across Maryland to strengthen support for these victims.

Ahlstrom brings more than 25 years of nonprofit development, community building, education and youth‑advocacy experience, as well as a background in mental‑health counseling. She most recently served as the T.A.M.A.R. (Trauma, Addiction, Mental Health, and Recovery) coordinator for female detainees at the Dorchester and Caroline County detention centers, is a certified EFT/tapping practitioner, holds a Master of Science in Counseling from the University of Hartford and a Bachelor of Arts in English from William Smith College. She said, “I hope to help mitigate the upward trend in Human Trafficking by expanding For All Seasons Rape Crisis Center's outreach; and strengthening the medical, legal, social service, and mental health collaboration that has already been established to support survivors. I believe my counseling and education background, along with strong communication and networking skills will help facilitate the most effective trauma‑informed response to serve victims and their families in the Mid‑Shore region and beyond,” Ahlstrom said.

The article defines human trafficking as the use of force, fraud or threats to obtain labor or commercial sex acts against a person’s will, noting that all persons under 18 who exchange sex for anything of value are victims regardless of coercion. The Eastern Shore’s proximity to major highways (I‑95, Routes 40, 50, 301, 13), three international airports, inexpensive bus and train services, and a high rate of seasonal work makes it attractive to traffickers. For information on identifying victims, the industries most affected, and how to help, readers are directed to WeSupportSurvivors.org, and can request presentations by emailing Susan Ahlstrom at sahlstrom@forallseasonsinc.org.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on human trafficking, a criminal activity and victim support, which falls under public safety concerns. It also mentions a state‑run program and local coordination, making Local Government a secondary relevance.

people: Susan Ahlstrom, human trafficking navigator, For All Seasons

title: 'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro Police Chief George Paugh promoted Officer Lenox Trams to lieutenant during an informal ceremony at the Town Meeting Hall on Main Street on Monday morning, Oct. 30. While the ceremony highlighted Trams’ advancement, it also marked Chief Paugh’s announcement that he will soon leave Greensboro to join the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office as commander of criminal investigations and a lieutenant.  

At the ceremony Trams expressed his gratitude, saying, “Well, I'm very humbled,” and added, “I was recruited here to make a difference and reinstate the love for law enforcement, so I've been trying to do that for seven months, and I'm going to continue to do that. It's a great little town.” He continued, “I'm going to stay and watch this thing grow, and continue to give excellent service to the citizens and the town,” Trams said. Town manager Tammy Kelledes praised him, saying, “We're very proud to have you, and you're doing a fantastic job,” Kelledes said.  

Chief Paugh thanked attendees, stating, “I want to thank you guys for taking your time out of your busy Monday to join Lenox on his special day. It's been a long time coming.” He noted Trams’ rapid impact, saying, “Even though it's been a short period of time in Greensboro, you definitely made an impact in the community,” he told Trams. Paugh added, “I'm always stopped and told about how well you're doing and how you interact with the community, and that's huge. And that's who you are. You're Mr. Community Policeman,” Paugh said, and concluded, “You've done some amazing things, and you're worthy of the rank.”  

Trams and Paugh both arrived in Greensboro seven months earlier after long careers with the Easton Police Department—Trams, 48, after 22 years including a stint as a school resource officer, and Paugh, 50, after 26 years. Reflecting on the department’s progress, Paugh said, “We made a big impact.” He detailed upgrades, stating, “We completely redid all the cars - the technology in them. Everything is up to date,” and, “We got a new CAD (computer-aided dispatch) system, new body cameras, new in-car cameras, all new computer systems” – all updates the department “very, very much” needed.  

The ceremony was attended by town officials, police leaders from neighboring jurisdictions, and department staff, underscoring the community’s support for Trams’ promotion and Paugh’s forthcoming transition.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police officer's promotion and the police chief's career move, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Officer fights to deter drivers like one who injured him
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content:
Less than four months after an October 18, 2023, crash on Interstate 270 left Montgomery County police Sgt. Patrick Kepp without both legs, the officer is traveling from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda to testify on two reckless‑driving bills in Annapolis. Kepp said the incident occurred when a speeding driver, known to “have a history of speeding and taunting police into chasing him,” intentionally hit him as he tried to stop the vehicle. “When I was brought into the conversation about new laws being created, right away, I knew it was something I wanted to do,” Kepp said, adding that “I will be there in Annapolis to make sure these bills happen.” He spends each day from 9:45 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. in rehabilitation and has undergone a dozen surgeries since the crash.

The legislative push was announced in a press briefing with Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich and several county lawmakers. Del. Greg Wims (D‑Montgomery) said, “I’m going to call it the Sgt. Pat Kepp Bill on Reckless Driving,” calling Kepp a “hero.” Elrich explained one proposed penalty: “It’s way too easy for a driver to just pay a fine and get back on the road and do what they were doing before.” Kepp said the measures would “give a little more teeth to some of our laws” and would address the “overall frustration” with enforcing current reckless‑driving statutes, which he says lack sufficient fines and deterrence.

The two pending bills would broaden the criminal definition of reckless and negligent driving, increase penalties, and require offenders to appear in court rather than simply paying a fine. Elrich said he hopes the law will stop people from “ignoring lights and sirens from law enforcement, breaking the rules of the road … and performing car tricks like drifting, peeling out, and doing donuts in the middle of a road.” He warned, “All it takes is a moment’s loss of control over that vehicle,” and added, “Instead of being entertaining, it would take little to transform it into a deadly incident.” The aim, Kepp emphasized, is not to imprison everyone but to end reckless driving, especially by repeat offenders, and to “strengthen our laws and make our roadways safer.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police officer's injury from reckless driving and his push for new traffic safety legislation, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

Marc Elrich, Montgomery County Executive
Greg Wims, Delegate, Maryland House of Delegates

title: CPR training for 911 calls could expand statewide
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Tony Rose, the chief of 911 for Charles County, received unanimous permission from the Charles County commissioners on Feb. 28 to travel to Annapolis and testify on House Bill 1092, legislation that would require the Maryland 911 Board to set training standards for public‑safety answering point personnel on telecommunications CPR and expand the 911 Trust Fund to cover related training costs.  

Rose emphasized the urgency of rapid response, saying, “When an out-of-hospital cardiac emergency occurs, you have about 600 seconds —10 minutes — to make a difference to save a life before irreversible brain death occurs,” Rose said. In 2019 he learned of a new program to change how education is delivered to 911 call‑center operators and immediately brought in a specialist to evaluate current telecommunications personnel. “It was all over the board,” Rose said referring to answers about the last time 911 operators had given over‑the‑phone CPR. “Some had it done it yesterday, some had never done it.” The program now requires a virtual training scenario every three months, putting operators through challenging situations to improve CPR instruction proficiency.  

“The results have been phenomenal,” Rose said. “We have doubled, and in some cases tripled, the number of survivors of out‑of‑hospital cardiac arrest in Charles County. They're walking out of a hospital after they've stopped breathing.” A written testimony Rose provided to the board added, “We also reported that we had improved the application of bystander CPR from 27% to 43%, improved bystander application of an AED from 23.5% to 28.6% and saw the number of survivors that were discharged from the hospital increase from five to eleven.”  

Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II (D) recalled a personal experience, noting, “It reminds me of an incident when I used to coach soccer,” Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II (D) said. “We had a cardiac arrest incident.” He highlighted how the calm operator guided those present, underscoring the bill’s importance. Rose concluded, “Currently, Charles County is the only jurisdiction that participates in this program,” Rose said. “This bill would make it mandatory for 911 centers to provide, not necessarily this particular program, but one similar to it.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses legislation and training for 911 operators to provide CPR instructions, focusing on emergency response and public safety infrastructure.

people: Tony Rose, Chief of 911, Charles County
Ralph E. Patterson II, Commissioner, Charles County

title: Mid-Shore sheriffs join in call for DJS secretary's resignation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Sheriffs from Dorchester, Talbot and Caroline Counties, representing the Maryland Sheriffs’ Association, voted on Monday to send Gov. Wes Moore (D) a letter demanding the immediate resignation of Vincent Schiraldi, secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services. The letter states, “Since Schiraldi's appointment in 2022, his extreme policies and lack of leadership as the Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, have directly made communities less safe in Maryland,” and adds, “Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes,” followed by, “only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes.” The governors’ office responded that “over the past year,” the administration has made a “concerted effort” to hold youth accountable, citing a “26% decline in juvenile homicide arrests and 46% decline in non-fatal shootings of juveniles” and affirming, “The governor is fully committed to working with local elected officials, law enforcement, the judiciary, and community leaders to improve public safety by holding youth accountable and rehabilitating them,” though it did not address the resignation request.

Schiraldi, appointed by Moore in March 2023, told WBAL‑TV, “Gov. Moore has been extremely supportive,” and added, “He's gotten us additional funds this year — $17 million to make community safer by expanding programs — and I want those community members who are calling for my resignation to feel safe.” The Department of Juvenile Services has not yet commented on the sheriffs’ letter.

Dorchester County Sheriff James Phillips explained his loss of confidence, saying he “lost all respect” for Schiraldi after a community meeting where the secretary “had the audacity to tell us, … ‘The data that I'm receiving doesn't support your claim of increased juvenile crime,’” and Phillips replied, “Well, obviously the numbers are going to go down because you're not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.” Phillips noted, “we're dealing with the same people, the same names, the same age kids,” and warned, “The law-abiding citizens are suffering because of their ignorance and stupidity in protecting these criminals,” adding, “And that's all they are. They might only be 15 or 16, but they're thugs.”  

Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said there is “no accountability,” criticizing that “good” juvenile‑services workers are “but they're being hampered by the secretary.” He praised Talbot Teen Court, stating, “They're getting more community service and stuff out of Teen Court than they would ever get out of DJS,” and concluded, “It's just a failed system. And it's being led by what the Sheriffs' Association believes is a bad pick by the governor.”  

Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker pointed to the 2022 Child Interrogation Protection Act as limiting police ability to charge juveniles, calling it a “shame when parental rights are superseded by the legislature.” Baker, a member of the state’s juvenile‑justice reform commission, emphasized, “Juvenile reform needs to be a high priority to help take the steps needed for them to have accountability for when they step into adulthood.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on law‑enforcement officials (sheriffs) demanding the resignation of a state juvenile services secretary due to concerns about juvenile crime and community safety, making public safety the most fitting category.

title: For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
Representatives from the nonprofit For All Seasons told the Talbot County Council that human trafficking remains an active problem in the area. Lauren Weber, the organization’s vice‑president of strategy and development, said, “It is happening and it's happening here. That continues to be the case,” Weber said. “ … There's a complexity to human trafficking that it doesn't really know county boundaries.” She noted that a year ago the group reported that “a good fifth of what was coming in was having at least one indicator of human trafficking,” adding, “ … That persists.”  

Weber and Katie Theeke, vice‑president of marketing and communications, emphasized the nonprofit’s regional reach across the five Mid‑Shore counties—Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne’s and Talbot—stating, “We know that human trafficking knows no boundaries and that it affects people of different backgrounds, races, genders,” Theeke said. “We have seen several cases come through our doors, and it comes from Talbot County. It comes from neighboring counties. We really aim to be the connector to get those people the help that they need.” Weber said the organization is seeing a shift in how victims are identified: “The folks that are self‑referring, we're seeing a decline,” she said. “But we're seeing a real rapid incline in folks coming to us and saying, 'Hey, I know more and now I've seen something.'” Since September, more than 120 people have completed For All Seasons’ free, online anti‑human‑trafficking course, and the group serves as the official regional navigator for the Mid‑Shore, participating in task forces and supporting youth and young adults who are victims.  

Council members thanked the presenters and, on Tuesday, issued a proclamation designating January as National Human Trafficking Awareness Month. Council Vice President Pete Lesher said, “We know that even one victim is too many,” council Vice President Pete Lesher said. “We appreciate all that you do both on prevention, but also to develop and take care of those who have been victims.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses human trafficking, a crime and safety concern addressed by a nonprofit and county council, making Public Safety the most relevant category.

title: Suspect still at large following police pursuit
content:
A police pursuit that began on Friday, Aug. 25, near Marydel, Maryland, left suspect Todd Randall Hockensmith, 36, of Felton still at large on Tuesday morning, Aug. 29. Officers from the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office first chased Hockensmith through the northern part of the county before he escaped into a wooded area, prompting the involvement of the Maryland State Police, Delaware State Police and several other units.

At the Marydel property, Hockensmith was seen running to a car and fled the scene; the vehicle was later identified as stolen. “The vehicle was reported stolen to the Denton Police Department by Hertrich Chevrolet (in Denton), and we actually located another vehicle on the property that was stolen from them that they didn’t even know about,” Baker said. Police pursued the car through northern Caroline County until Hockensmith drove it off the roadway in the 16,000 block of Lentz Road in Henderson, Maryland, then fled on foot into a heavily wooded area where a perimeter, K‑9 units and aviation support were deployed. After about three hours of searching, Hockensmith could not be located.

The investigation also led to the arrest of a female associate, Danyeal L. Shahan, who is being held on bond at the Caroline County Detention Center and faces motor‑vehicle‑theft and related charges. “The Caroline County Sheriff's Office has active warrants for Hockensmith ‘for the two motor vehicle deaths (of) two brand new cars from Hertrich Chevrolet here in Denton,’” Baker said. The Delaware State Police had earlier posted a request for public help, noting that Hockensmith “has three active felony warrants for his arrest for a host of offenses, including theft, burglary and a police pursuit.” The case remains active, and anyone with information is asked to contact the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office at 410‑479‑2515.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an ongoing police pursuit, suspect search, and law‑enforcement actions, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Icy roads, school closures continue into Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Snow has covered the roads of the Eastern Shore since Monday, and county officials say they expect the routes to be cleared by Thursday. Town of Easton crews are working to salt all back roads in town, according to town engineer Rick Van Emburgh. Van Emburgh said Wednesday afternoon that “emergency roads, such as those leading to the hospital, had been the priority.” At that point, back roads had been plowed twice and the focus shifted to salting to prevent freezing.

In the nearby town of Denton, superintendent of public works Mark Chandler reported that as of Wednesday afternoon all roads in town were passable, though he urged residents to drive with caution.

School districts on the Eastern Shore will stay closed Thursday. Talbot County Public Schools will remain closed “due to the continued treacherous road conditions in some parts of the county,” according to the district’s website, and the district has four inclement‑weather days built into the 2024‑25 calendar so the missed days will not affect the end‑of‑school date. Dorchester County Public Schools announced a virtual day of instruction for Thursday, providing students with electronic devices; the district has three inclement‑weather days in its calendar, also preventing any impact on the school year’s end date. Caroline County Public Schools will be closed Thursday as well, with four snow days built into its calendar, meaning the closures will not change the scheduled end of the school year.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on hazardous icy road conditions and the resulting safety advisories, which aligns with Public Safety. It also mentions actions by town officials (Local Government) and school closures (Education), but safety is the central focus.

people: Rick Van Emburgh, Town Engineer, Town of Easton
Mark Chandler, Superintendent of Public Works, Town of Denton

title: Residents displaced in 2-house fire
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
On Saturday afternoon, February 4, 2024, a fire broke out at 17 South Locust Lane in Easton, Maryland, affecting two adjacent homes. Firefighters were dispatched at 3:07 p.m., and by then flames were spreading quickly between the structures. Both residences were evacuated without serious injury, and the blaze was fully contained a little after two hours, with responding crews beginning to pull back before 5:30 p.m. Seven volunteer fire departments—including the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, Cordova Volunteer Fire Company, St. Michael’s Fire Department, Preston Volunteer Fire Company, Oxford Fire Company, Queen Anne‑Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company, and Trappe Volunteer Fire Company—along with local EMS and law‑enforcement personnel, worked the incident.

Among the displaced was 87‑year‑old Leona Demdy, a lifelong Easton resident who lost a home she had lived in for 27 years. “I cried, cried, cried,” Demdy said as she watched firefighters extinguish the last remaining embers. “I had everybody's picture on the wall. My walls were just full of pictures.” The fire destroyed many of her personal belongings, including a collection of photographs of friends, family and neighbors that had been proudly displayed on her walls. Demdy, who lived alone, will stay with a relative near Salisbury while arrangements are made for her neighbors.

The state fire marshal has opened an investigation into the cause of the fire; the exact damages have not yet been determined, but both houses sustained significant damage and all residents were displaced. Demdy indicated she would be staying with family, and local officials have coordinated temporary housing for the other affected family. The investigation’s findings will be released at a later date.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a residential fire, emergency response, and displacement of residents, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Leona Demdy, 87, resident

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The Star Democrat released its list of the ten most‑viewed online stories for the week of June 7, 2025, ranking the items in order of page views as of Wednesday evening. The list highlights a range of public‑safety incidents and community events that captured readers’ attention across Easton and surrounding counties.

Top of the list is a police appeal for help identifying a man suspected of robbing a bank in Easton on Monday afternoon. A May 20 discovery of human remains on the Ronald Spearing Farm during Cherrywood Solar construction follows, as does a serious crash on Route 50 that injured four people, according to Maryland State Police. A homicide investigation began after deputies responded at about 1:15 a.m. on June 1 to reports of gunfire in the 1500 block of Centreville Road in Queen Anne’s County. The week also saw Talbot and Queen Anne’s counties named “sanctuary jurisdictions” by the Trump administration, a designation later removed from the Department of Homeland Security’s website.

Other prominent stories include graduations at Easton High School and St. Michael’s High School, a 12‑year‑old middle‑schooler becoming the youngest author of a fantasy novel, the removal of the tile wall at Idlewild Park after years of delay, a National Transportation Safety Board transcript revealing the final words from the Dali crew before the Key Bridge collapse, and a community rally to assist retired teacher and former baseball coach Dan Hortert after his home was damaged by an EF‑1 tornado.

llm_classification.explanation: The majority of the listed stories involve police investigations, crimes, accidents, and emergency responses, which align most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy
author: Konner Metz
content:
Students in grades 10 through 12 graduated from the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office inaugural citizens police academy Tuesday night after a 10‑week course that met every Tuesday, covering crisis response, bleeding emergencies and traffic stops. The academy, held in Easton, MD, culminated with the graduation of Yvonne Herrera Hernandez (North Caroline High School), Ian Knopp (Saints Peter & Paul High School), Eric Loredo (Easton High School), Sofia Miller (St. Michael’s Middle High School), Canin Parks (Saints Peter & Paul High School), Jules Stepp (Saints Peter & Paul High School), Carson Tyree (Saints Peter & Paul High School) and Evelio Urdaneta Delgado (Easton High School). The department is now accepting applications for a second citizens police academy open to county residents 18 and older, with classes beginning April 8 and applications due March 31.

Saints Peter & Paul sophomore Carson Tyree said the academy changed his perspective of police work. “What stood out is how these guys work. It's not all fun and games,” Tyree said. “ … When they go into a situation, there's a lot of thinking behind it because they can't violate procedure. If they violate procedure, they can't be a police officer.”  Junior Jules Stepp, who most enjoyed learning about Talbot County’s crisis response unit, added, “It was like we were there with them,” Stepp said. “We got to live vicariously through them.”  She later reflected, “I was surprised how much detail went into every little thing, and how one little thing can cause a problem so they had to backtrack and think about what the consequences could be,” she said. “And how they have to go through so many processes to get grants, peace orders, protective orders and all that type of stuff.”

Following the final class, Maj. Steve Elliott thanked the students and called them a “great group” for the first ever citizens police academy. Lt. J.R. Dobson said, “I think from day one — when (Sheriff Joe Gamble) was giving you guys a lesson on when the first sheriff of Talbot County was — until now, I've seen you all loosen up,” Dobson said. Sheriff Joe Gamble thanked grants administrator Lori Stepp for securing the grant that made the academy possible and announced the upcoming program for adults.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a citizens police academy run by the Sheriff's Office, focusing on law‑enforcement training and community safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Man gets five years for Thanksgiving Day stabbing of stepson
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
A Cecil County Circuit Court jury convicted 64‑year‑old Ernest Anthony Vuocolo of second‑degree assault, reckless endangerment and carrying a dangerous weapon with intent to injure for a stabbing that occurred at about 10 p.m. on Nov. 23 2023, after a family Thanksgiving dinner at his residence on the unit block of Stirrup Drive near Elkton. Judge Cameron A. Brown imposed a five‑year prison term—suspending all but four years of a maximum 10‑year sentence for the assault, adding a consecutive one‑year sentence for the weapons charge and a concurrent four‑year sentence for reckless endangerment—followed by three years of supervised probation.

The jury, after a two‑day trial in March, acquitted Vuocolo of the most serious charge, first‑degree assault, a felony that carries up to 25 years. Assistant State’s Attorney Gavin Patashnick prosecuted the case, while Elkton‑based defense attorneys Tina Harris Schlecker and C. Thomas Brown argued that Vuocolo acted in self‑defense, citing his history of multiple heart attacks and the fact that he is 20 years older than his 41‑year‑old stepson, who testified that he had confronted Vuocolo about “sexual comments” Vuocolo allegedly made about his wife. During a hospital interview, the victim repeated that he had asked Vuocolo for an apology after the “sexual comments” on Nov. 21 2023, and that Vuocolo then attacked him with a knife while holding him in a headlock.

Cecil County Sheriff’s Office deputies responded to the Stirrup Drive home at 10:14 p.m. after receiving a complaint about a “physical domestic involving a knife.” Police said they found the victim “bleeding heavily” from his left side and recovered a six‑inch “thick blade” knife that investigators later described at trial as “field clever.” The victim was taken to Christiana Hospital in Delaware for treatment of a stab wound to his chest, while Vuocolo, who complained of chest pain at the scene, was taken to ChristianaCare’s Union Hospital in Elkton, treated, and then returned to police custody.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal incident, court sentencing, and police involvement, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Weekend storm threatens Shore with rain, wind
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
The Eastern Shore is expected to experience an escalating coastal storm from late Saturday through Monday, with the National Weather Service forecasting one to three inches of rain and sustained winds of about 40 mph. Zack Cooper, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service Office in Mount Holly, noted that while the chance of thunderstorms or tornadoes is low, the storm could still produce minor coastal flooding.

Cooper explained the timing of the precipitation, saying, “So really starting late in the day Saturday we’ll start to see an increase in cloud cover and shower activity, which will ramp up rapidly from there going into Sunday, which is when most of the heavy rainfall will occur, Sunday into Sunday night and going into Monday as well,” Cooper said. He added, “It all starts with just preparation and planning,” Cooper said. “A lot of times if there’s minor flooding or roadway flooding or things like that the best course of action is to just stay off the roadways.”

The Maryland Transportation Authority warned residents and travelers to be ready for wind warnings, restrictions, and possible temporary traffic holds on MDTA bridges Sunday through Monday, noting that if wind exceeds 55 mph the agency could decide to hold traffic or close bridges. The National Weather Service will continue to monitor the coastal storm throughout the weekend.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an upcoming coastal storm, emphasizing weather warnings, potential flooding, and traffic restrictions, which are primarily concerns of public safety.

people: Zack Cooper, meteorologist, National Weather Service Office in Mount Holly
organizations: National Weather Service Office in Mount Holly

title: State looks to clear out homeless camp near highway
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
The Maryland State Highway Administration (SHA) announced a competitive bid for a clean‑up contract to dismantle a homeless encampment at Crain Highway and Mattawoman Beantown Road north of Waldorf in Charles County. The contract’s summary reads, “Contractor shall provide all labor and expertise for surveying, documenting, clean‑up, collecting, removal, and disposal services involving homeless encampment abatement actions on MDOT SHA property located in Charles County under an ‘as needed’ agreement basis.” It calls for the removal of tents, mattresses, blankets, trash, debris, overfilled dumpsters, cardboard, tires, and “disposal of biohazardous waste, including human bodily fluids and waste and drug paraphernalia.” The contract also states, “The site must be restored to a condition without obvious evidence of previous human habitation.”

A Charles County government spokesperson noted that because the encampment sits along two state roads, “the encampment is largely a state situation.” The issue is not new; Corae Young, chief operating officer of Lifestyles of Maryland, told Southern Maryland News that a similar camp existed about a year ago and that Lifestyles had helped SHA deliver clearance notices. “I believe what occurred is people moved close by,” Young said.

During a site visit on the morning of Aug. 21, a reporter observed abundant debris—bikes, shopping carts, bags, mattresses, cardboard, propane tanks and bottles—alongside multiple lived‑in tents. One resident emerged as contractors walked the area, underscoring the difficulty of achieving the contract’s requirement for a clean site.

After the tour, Southern Maryland News contacted SHA. Daniel Allman of the agency’s communications office said, “SHA works in partnership with local agencies, including support and outreach services and law enforcement, to assist those residing on state rights‑of‑way. Connecting them with agencies that can provide relocation assistance, housing or other support services has proven to be a successful approach.” He added that state workers inform residents they are on state property and give a “30‑ to 60‑day timeframe for them to relocate.” Despite the pending bid, Allman said, “At this time, there is no work scheduled for this location.”

Bids for the contract are due Aug. 28, but the agreement sets no fixed start date, and relocation efforts remain uncertain as of this week.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a state agency's plan to clean up a homeless encampment, involving safety concerns, law enforcement coordination, and public‑property management, which aligns most closely with Public Safety.

Daniel Allman, communications office, Maryland State Highway Administration
location: intersection of Crain Highway and Mattawoman Beantown Road north of Waldorf

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content:
The Fallen Heroes Memorial, observed each February 13 for the past 22 years, was held on Feb. 21, 2024 at the Centreville United Methodist Church in Centreville, Maryland. Hosted by the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 108, the ceremony began with the Pledge of Allegiance and a moment of silence led by Sheriff Gary Hoffman, followed by a welcome from Senior Pastor Rev. Karen Handy.

Chase Armington, past president of Lodge 108 and a Queen Anne’s County deputy, opened the program, stating, “Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes. It is our duty to never forget them, for they have paved the path forward with their lives. The path leading us here tonight was born from tragedy. Incredible losses. Unbearable pain for our families, friends, and the community. These honored in front of you served our community with pride, dignity, and honor. Knowing their lives could, at any moment be taken, so that we may live. So that we may continue on the path they have now paved.”  

Sue Nickerson, who lost her son Officer Michael Nickerson in 2001, explained the event’s origins: “The FOP from QAC started (this event) and they will always have it on February 13, the night that Michael (Nickerson) and Jason (Schwenz, Queen Anne’s County deputy) were killed. But, it’s to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne’s County.” She added, “It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters and our EMTs have done. It is very much appreciated.”  

Queen Anne’s County State’s Attorney Lance Richardson reflected on the community’s response, saying, “The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us. We don’t have any control over that. But what we do have control over is how we respond to it, how we react, how we pick up the pieces and go on. Stoicism also places an emphasis on appreciating the unity and precious gift of life.” During the remembrance, first‑responders marched for the Presentation of Colors, ten fallen heroes were honored—including Daniel Lister, “Buck” Clough, “Dougie” Thomas, David Brinkley, Michael Nickerson, Jason Schwenz, Charles Rider, and troopers Thomas Noyle, Philip Russ and Wallace Mowbray—and a radio transmission declared, “Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland. May their dedication and sacrifice never be forgotten and may they rest in eternal peace.” Bagpipes played “Amazing Grace,” and the church fell silent.

Rev. Karen Handy closed the ceremony with a prayer, proclaiming, “Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others. Lord, mend those hearts that are broken in the loss of these loved ones. Lord, we pray that this memorial tonight has brought a bit of peace. Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons. We thank you and pray for those that they have left behind.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a memorial ceremony honoring fallen police, fire, and EMS personnel, which is directly related to public safety and first‑responder activities.

title: Cambridge man gets 25 years after taking plea deal in murder trial
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
A Cambridge teenager, Daeveon Johnson, 19, was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Sept. 6 for the Nov. 18, 2021 fatal shooting of Ja'Len Woolford. Johnson faced a first‑degree murder charge and entered an Alford plea in November 2022. Under the plea deal he will serve his term at the Patuxent Youthful Offenders Program, become eligible for parole after serving half the sentence, and will also receive five years of probation. The sentence is retroactive to Jan. 4, 2022, the day Johnson was arrested by Cambridge police, and orders him to have no contact with Key’Marion Ennals, who was acquitted of 12 charges—including first‑degree murder—at a trial in August.

Johnson’s sentencing was delayed as part of the agreement that required him to testify at Ennals’ trial last month. In his initial police interview he admitted to carrying a .40‑caliber firearm, and an autopsy confirmed Woolford died from a single .40‑caliber gunshot wound.

Dorchester County State’s Attorney Amanda Leonard issued a statement after the sentencing. She said, “The State recommended a sentence of life imprisonment, suspending all but forty years of active incarceration,” and added, “The Court heard heartfelt victim impact statements from three members of the victim's family, each expressing their choice to forgive Mr. Johnson, and each requesting the Court consider a lesser period of active incarceration for Mr. Johnson given his cooperation and remorse.” Leonard concluded, “The State continues to offer condolences to all family and loved ones impacted by the loss of Ja'Len Woolford, and thanks the Court for its mindful consideration of all circumstances at sentencing.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and police involvement, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Crane accident at power substation leaves much of Caroline County without power Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
A third‑party contractor operating a crane at Delmarva Power’s substation on Camp Road in Denton hit equipment, causing a fire that knocked out power for more than 1,100 customers Thursday morning. “This morning, a third‑party contractor came in contact with our infrastructure which initially impacted more than 1,100 customers,” the utility said, adding, “Due to the extent of the repairs, we were able to restore 850 customers in just over two hours, with the remaining 300 customers restored two hours later, just before 1 p.m.” By shortly after 9:30 a.m. the Maryland Department of Emergency Management’s outage map showed that 15‑25 % of Caroline County was without electricity.

County officials were alerted immediately. “Delmarva Power's intergovernmental affairs liaison reached out to me,” Caroline County Commissioners President Travis Breeding said. “She was very responsive, kept me up to date on the progress so that we knew what to plan for.” The outages disrupted businesses, government agencies and schools. Caroline County Public Schools moved Greensboro Elementary’s students to the first floor, where limited heat from a backup generator kept the building operational. Colonel Richardson Middle School and Colonel Richardson High School remained open on generator power, offering students the option to go home and allowing parents to pick up children. Colonel Richardson High cancelled final exams. Breeding later remarked, “I know it. It caused some havoc in a few of our schools,” and added, “I think Colonel Richardson Middle, Colonel Richardson High, and Greensboro Elementary had to react and make some changes. But I think all in all we got through it okay.”

The county and the town of Denton opened warming shelters at the Choptank Visitor & Heritage Center and the General James F. Fretterd Community Center, though staff reported no residents sought refuge. Power was fully restored in Caroline County around 1 p.m., and by 1:45 p.m. Choptank Electric confirmed that all its customers in the area had electricity. “Delmarva power takes things very seriously, and I believe they did everything they could to restore power as quickly as possible,” Breeding said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a crane accident causing a fire at a power substation, leading to widespread outages and emergency response, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnap and murder of woman
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
A Cambridge man, Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 40, was indicted on March 29 on charges of murder, assault, kidnapping, false imprisonment and reckless endangerment for the disappearance and death of 31‑year‑old Tiyavauna Britt. Bradley is being held without bail at the Dorchester County Detention Center.  

Britt vanished on February 19 in Anne Arundel County after being last seen at work in Delaware on February 7. Her vehicle was discovered unoccupied and unlocked in the Dollar Tree parking lot in Easton, with her phone, wallet and other belongings still inside.  

According to February charging documents, Britt’s mother told police she had tried to contact her daughter several times between January 31 and February 13 but could not reach her, and other family members also failed to make contact. The mother believed Britt was with her ex‑boyfriend, identified as Bradley, and feared for her safety because of a prior domestic‑violence history between the two.  

The investigation is being led by the Maryland State Police Homicide Unit with assistance from the Easton and Cambridge police departments. Maryland State Police asks that anyone with knowledge of Britt’s whereabouts contact Maryland State Police Sergeant Scott Sears at 443‑783‑7230.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal investigation, charges, and police actions related to kidnapping and murder, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.
