title: Mid-Shore preps for National Night Out Aug. 5
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Mid‑Shore municipalities will join the nationwide celebration of National Night Out on Aug. 5, an annual community‑building campaign that “helps promote police‑community partnerships and neighborhood camaraderie,” according to the event’s website. The evening is designed to strengthen ties between neighbors and law‑enforcement officers and revive a true sense of community.

St. Michaels Police Department Chief Jeffery Oswald said the event “will help ‘build better relationships with members of the community.’” He invited residents to “enjoy a hamburger with the fire department, see new law‑enforcement equipment, and reconnect with old friends. All of our local partners will be in attendance as we recognize those in the community who have donated their time and care towards a safer St. Michaels.”

The scheduled National Night Out activities on the Mid‑Shore are:
- St. Michaels Police Department: 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. at Bay Hundred Pool.  
- Caroline County Sheriff’s Office: 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. on Morris Avenue, across from the Federalsburg Police Station.  
- Easton Police Department: 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. at Moton Park.  
- Dorchester County Sheriff’s Office: 6 p.m. at Town Hall.

The Cambridge Police Department will hold its National Night Out celebration in October.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on National Night Out events that promote police-community partnerships and neighborhood safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, with a secondary relevance to Local Government due to municipal involvement.

people: Jeffery Oswald, Police Department Chief, St. Michaels Police Department

title: Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Fire crews were dispatched to Queen Anne's County High School in Centreville after a fire alarm activated at 7:13 p.m. on Sept. 9.  Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler later confirmed that the blaze began in a special‑education room on the rear first floor and that the sprinkler system activated, limiting damage to the originating space.  According to the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal, the fire originated in a rear first‑floor office and “the preliminary cause was deemed accidental, the result of ‘an unspecified electrical event of a power surge protector.’”  

A total of 36 firefighters, led by Goodwill Volunteer Fire Company, responded and brought the fire under control in about 30 minutes.  Water collected in a back hallway, one special‑education classroom, an office and a conference room as the sprinklers ran for roughly 20 minutes.  The fire marshal estimated approximately $30,000 in structure and content damages, and no injuries were reported.  On its Facebook page, QACPS wrote: “We are thankful that there were no injuries, and our fire suppression system worked appropriately.”  

The school was closed to students and non‑essential personnel on Wednesday, Sept. 9, to allow cleanup and assessment, and normal operations resumed on Sept. 11.  Third‑party contractors were brought in to evaluate the damage, and QACPS expressed gratitude to first responders, the Queen Anne’s County Fire Marshal’s Office, the Maryland State Deputy Fire Marshal, and its custodial and maintenance staff for returning the building to use.  Questions should be directed to Principal Lou Sheppard, Kibler said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an electrical fire at a high school, focusing on fire response, safety measures, and damage assessment, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Cambridge theater has another incident of smoke in theater
content:
Fire crews responded on Wednesday, Aug. 10, 2023, to a report of smoke inside the Cambridge Premier Cinema, marking the second such incident in two weeks. The theater, located in the 2700 block of Dorchester Square Mall in Cambridge, experienced a similar event on July 29. Both occurrences were traced to a malfunctioning air‑handler on the roof of the cinema.

Multiple fire companies and emergency personnel responded to each incident, working to clear the smoke and ensure patron safety. The repeated equipment failure prompted authorities to investigate the air‑handler system to prevent further disruptions.

title: Federalsburg police chief resigns; sheriff's office takes over leadership
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
At the July 7 town meeting, Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner announced that Police Chief Joseph Gasser had resigned effective June 25, saying, “The mayor and council would like to announce the resignation of Chief Gasser from the Federalsburg Police Department effective June 25,” and adding, “We want to thank Chief Gasser for his service to the town and wish him well on his future endeavors.” The mayor also said the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office would assume leadership of the department while town officials decide on future police leadership, and she announced a public‑forum meeting for July 21 at 6 p.m. at Federalsburg Town Hall to discuss options for public safety and policing.

Sheriff Donald Baker told the Star Democrat, “I was contacted by the mayor and council and asked to take over day‑to‑day operations and management oversight of the department,” and he said, “I agree to do that on an interim basis for 30 to 60 days until the mayor and council decide what they are going to do moving forward and what that looks​ for the Federalsburg Police Department.” Baker indicated that all possibilities are being considered, including a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the sheriff’s office.

“I believe that everything is on the table to include signing an MOU somewhat like Ridgley's, directly with the sheriff's office of the county,” Baker said. “Again, everything is on the table. and we are really early in this stage, but we absolutely could absorb any officers that were left.” Gasser, appointed chief in January, came to the role with a military background and had served the town for nearly 30 years. The town of Ridgley, which has a contract with the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office covering it since last year and renewed a similar MOU for the next fiscal year, provides a precedent for Federalsburg’s possible restructuring.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the resignation of a town police chief and the sheriff's office assuming interim leadership, which directly pertains to public safety matters.

people: Kim Abner, Mayor of Federalsburg
Joseph Gasser, Police Chief, Federalsburg Police Department
Donald Baker, Sheriff, Caroline County Sheriff's Office
incident_type: police chief resignation and interim leadership transition

title: Fire causes $1 million in damage to pizzeria
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
An investigation is ongoing after a blaze caused an estimated one million dollars in damage to Mario’s Pizza, a longtime pizzeria near Elkton, forcing the business to close indefinitely, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal. A neighboring employee called 911 at 9:57 p.m. on Tuesday after discovering the fire at the unit block of Beauchamp Road in the Cherry Hill area, a few miles north of Elkton. Mario’s Pizza is part of a strip shopping center that fronts Route 213.

Several area volunteer fire companies responded to the scene, with Singerly Volunteer Fire Company of Elkton serving as the on‑scene command unit. Approximately 75 firefighters battled the blaze for about 20 minutes before bringing it under control.

The fire caused an estimated $600,000 in structural damage to the pizzeria portion of the building, which was equipped with smoke detectors, and it destroyed approximately $400,000 in property inside the shop, according to a Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal spokesperson, who further reported that no one was injured. The spokesperson identified Mario Testa as the owner.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire incident, emergency response, and investigation by the State Fire Marshal, which aligns primarily with public safety concerns.

title: Trams takes helm as Greensboro police chief
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Mayor David Spencer administered the oath of office to new Greensboro Police Chief Lenox Trams shortly after 6 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 4, at the Greensboro Community Center and Fire Hall. Trams, who was named chief on Dec. 11, took the oath alongside Greensboro Police Sgt. Jake Smith, and the ceremony and meet‑and‑greet preceded the town’s first meeting of 2024.

Trams, 48, brings a 25‑year law‑enforcement career and joined the GPD in March 2023. He told attendees, "(Chief Paugh) did a lot of work to get us up to standards," and said he would continue that trend. Trams also said he wants to fill out the department with three more officers, adding, "We want the best officers who can do the job that the town deserves."

Former colleagues from the Easton Police Department and other law‑enforcement leaders were on hand, and several of Trams’s family members attended. Sgt. Al Orrison recalled, "took me under his wing. My kids actually call him Uncle Lenox. I love this man." He continued, "When you get to that 15-, 20-year mark, you become very cynical, and it's hard to have compassion all the time," and added, "But Lenox Trams always has compassion for everyone. He treats everybody fairly, and he's just an incredible human being." EPD Sgt. David Trevino said Trams has "endless energy" and "never stops giving to people" through mentoring and volunteer work, concluding, "The town of Greensboro is very fortunate."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the swearing‑in of a new police chief, a matter directly related to law enforcement and community safety, making Public Safety the most fitting category, with Local Government as a close secondary fit.

title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Police Department’s K‑9 program was forced to start over after Maryland legalized recreational cannabis in July 2023, which retired three marijuana‑detecting dogs.  The department’s “complete rebuild,” as Lt. Tim Larrimore put it, began with the arrival of a nearly two‑year‑old black Labrador named Knox, who finished training in January 2025 and was deployed 17 times in the first quarter, helping make six drug arrests with her handler, Pfc. Mark Schinault.  Schinault explained, “She has that drive for her reward, her toy after she does a good scan,” and added, “That means the world to her, so she's very driven to work.”

Other agencies faced the same challenge.  Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said, “I really didn’t want to go down the road because I didn’t want to be challenged in the courtroom.”  Across the state, law‑enforcement leaders are rebuilding their units, often with untrained puppies to cut costs.  “Most of the agencies were able to replenish the dogs,” said Kent County Sgt. Scott Lockerman, president of the Maryland Police K‑9 Foundation, which funded one of Easton’s new dogs.  At Dorchester County Sheriff’s Office, Sheriff James Phillips recalled, “We saw it coming. It was on the horizon,” and noted that funding has been “mind‑boggling” in generosity.  Larrimore explained the new reality: “This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that’s out,” adding, “So now you need the ability to smell something that the human nose isn’t necessarily good at detecting. It’s the dog that gets you there.”  He also said, “It hasn’t hit us yet. These dogs are just retired last year. They’re young, they’re healthy.”

The rebuilt K‑9 teams are proving valuable beyond narcotics work.  Dorchester Sgt. Steve Twilley said the dogs “bridge the gap between the Sheriff’s Office and the community” and noted, “Next thing you know, that kid’s come to you for help instead of lashing out or doing something at school.”  Phillips echoed the return on investment, stating that money spent on K‑9s comes back “10 times over because of the relationships that we build with the kids and the people.”  He concluded, “I think an agency that’s trying to do today’s police work and doesn’t have the K‑9 ability out there, I don’t think they’re a full police agency. I think it completes the police agency by having the K‑9s.”  

The effort to rebuild Maryland’s K‑9 units continues, with Easton already adding a second dog, Waylon, and two more untrained pups slated to join, while other counties secure funding through grants, donations, and foundations to maintain the vital roles dogs play in detection, tracking, explosives work, and community policing.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on police K‑9 units, their operational challenges, funding, and community impact, which are core aspects of public safety rather than broader government or economic topics.

title: Three arrested in connection with death of Centreville teen
author: Staff Writer
content:
The Queen Anne’s County Sheriff’s Office arrested 19‑year‑old Kamryn Andrews, 20‑year‑old James Lawson and 27‑year‑old Travis Lissau for the June 1, 2025 shooting death of 19‑year‑old Christopher Parsley in the 1500 block of Centreville Road, Queenstown. Deputies responded at approximately 1:15 a.m. and found Parsley, who had been attending a bonfire with friends, fatally shot; life‑saving measures were attempted but he was pronounced dead at the scene.

Detectives from the Sheriff’s Office Criminal Investigation Unit launched an immediate investigation, working with the FBI Baltimore‑Annapolis Field Office, the Chesapeake Bay Safe Streets Task Force, Homeland Security Investigations’ Baltimore Eastern Shore Field Office, Maryland State Police Centreville Barrack, Centreville Police Department, Delaware State Police and related agencies. After an extensive probe, a Queen Anne’s County grand jury returned indictments and arrest warrants were issued on Oct. 6. Andrews faces multiple counts of attempted second‑degree murder, manslaughter, first‑ and second‑degree assault, reckless endangerment, several firearm offenses and possession of a firearm as a minor. Lawson is charged with attempted second‑degree murder, manslaughter, assault, reckless endangerment, firearm‑related offenses, conspiracy to alter physical evidence, possession of a firearm as a minor and possession of a firearm without a serial number. Lissau faces similar charges, including attempted second‑degree murder, manslaughter, assault, reckless endangerment, firearm offenses, conspiracy to alter evidence and possession of a firearm without a serial number. All three suspects are being held without bond.

Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, “This has been an incredibly difficult time for Chris' family and for our entire community. The effects of this tragedy have been deeply felt, and our thoughts remain with those who continue to grieve. This investigation reflects the strength of collaboration between our community and our law enforcement partners.” He added, “As the investigation continues, every tip, video, and witness account remains vital to bringing closure for Chris's family and our community. We have zero tolerance for crime in Queen Anne's County and will always stand up for victims who no longer have a voice.” The investigation remains ongoing, and officials urge anyone with information to call the Anonymous Tip Line at 410‑758‑6666 or email Sheriff‑Info@qac.org.

title: Easton man charged with eight counts of child porn possession
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
An Easton man, Travis Schwaninger, 42, was arrested on eight counts of possession of child pornography after a joint investigation led by the Criminal Investigations Division of the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office. The investigation began in April when the Easton Police Department’s Criminal Investigations Unit received several tips about Schwaninger from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Because Schwaninger lived outside Easton’s jurisdiction, the department contacted the Sheriff’s Office to take over the case.

On June 11, detectives executed a search warrant at Schwaninger’s home and recovered additional evidence from his electronic devices, according to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office. Schwaninger was arrested on site, transported to the Talbot County Detention Center and later released on a $20,000 unsecured bond.

The Talbot County Sheriff’s Office Patrol Division, Drug Task Force and Crisis Response Unit, together with the Easton Police Department and the Maryland State Police Computer Crimes Unit, assisted in the investigation. Anyone with information about the case can contact Cpl. Samuel Faggert at 410‑822‑1020 or sfaggert@talbotcountymd.gov.

title: Federalsburg workshops agreement with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
On Monday, September 23, 2025, the Federalsburg Town Council convened a special meeting to discuss a draft Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office that would transfer policing duties from the town’s police department to the sheriff’s deputies. The proposed one‑year contract would assign four officers to Federalsburg: former police department Sgt. Brian McNeill, two police‑academy cadets, and one current sheriff’s deputy. Town officials said the agreement is intended to help address Federalsburg’s $5 million debt by reducing policing costs, noting that the town currently spends $1.146 million annually on its police department while the sheriff’s coverage would cost about $863,000—an estimated saving of $280,000, though earlier estimates projected savings of $300,000‑$500,000 per year.

Council members indicated that the MOU includes provisions for regular public oversight, with quarterly meetings planned throughout the year. “We felt as we wanted to give this MOU situation a try for a year, and throughout that year we want to have quarterly meetings with the public,” Council Member Brandy James said at an Aug. 3 meeting. Additional details of the draft agreement call for the town to provide police vehicles, covering gas and maintenance, and to allocate a $15,000 line item for officer uniforms. The sheriff’s office would handle press releases for criminal events, while the town would manage releases related to municipal events. Discussions with Sheriff Donnie Baker also explored the possibility of sharing the police department building, using half for town offices and half for sheriff’s deputies.

A motion to advance the modified agreement was made contingent on Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan making clarifying revisions. If approved, the MOU would remain in effect for one year, after which the council could assess its performance and financial impact before deciding on any further action.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a town's agreement with the sheriff's office to provide policing services, which is primarily a public safety issue, though it also involves local government budgeting and decision‑making.

title: Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants
content:
The Maryland Department of Transportation (MDOT) announced that 17 counties and municipalities across the state were selected to receive more than $28 million in Fiscal Year 2023 Safe Streets and Roads for All grants, funded by the U.S. Department of Transportation. The grants support Maryland’s Vision Zero goal of eliminating all traffic fatalities and serious injuries by 2030. “In order to create the transportation system that Marylanders deserve, we must work with our citizens, our local officials and our Congressional delegation with unity and focus to deliver safe, equitable access across the state for everyone, whether they drive, ride, or walk,” Gov. Wes Moore said. “These grants help us achieve that goal and help fulfill our mission to lift every community.” Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld added, “The Maryland Department of Transportation is proud to have worked closely with our federal delegation to support our local partners' efforts to receive more than $28 million in funding to boost safety for those who bike, walk and drive on our roads,” and “The Maryland Department of Transportation looks forward to working with local leaders throughout the state to put this money to use to reduce roadway fatalities and ensure our streets are safer for all Marylanders.”

Among the awards, the City of Mount Rainier received the largest implementation grant at over $9.7 million for traffic‑calming measures, bicycle‑network improvements, sidewalk enhancements and pedestrian safety near Mount Rainier Elementary School. The Town of Brentwood was granted $160,000 to develop a Vision Zero Action Plan. “As a historically disadvantaged community, we're grateful for this federal investment and support of our county and state partners so that we can deliver safety for our residents, businesses and visitors,” Brentwood Mayor Rocio Treminio‑Lopez said. “While a small town, we have urban issues that need collaborative approaches to solve.” Baltimore County received $3.5 million for its Vision Zero Action Plan, with County Executive Johnny Olszewski stating, “Investing in our roadways not only improves vital infrastructure, but prioritizes the safety and wellbeing of our residents and communities,” and “We are grateful to our federal and state partners for their help with the critical planning projects supported with this grant – and for helping to ensure Baltimore County's roads are safe for years to come.”

Queen Anne’s County was awarded $280,000 to develop a comprehensive multimodal safety plan. “This federal grant will help our local, state and federal partners combine knowledge and resources to create a comprehensive highway safety plan that will improve safety for our citizens and everyone traveling though Queen Anne's county,” County Commissioner Jim Moran said. The City of Cambridge received $320,000 for research on reorganizing streets to make them safer and more pedestrian‑friendly. Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout explained, “We have a number of streets and intersections that are really quite dangerous, especially to pedestrians,” and added, “We're grateful for the funding. It's the kind of thing small communities need.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on MDOT grants aimed at reducing traffic fatalities and improving road safety (Vision Zero), which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, though it also involves local government entities receiving the funds.

title: Train and tractor-trailer collide in Hurlock accident
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
A tractor‑trailer carrying a load of corn collided with a train on Friday, February 17, 2024, in Hurlock, Maryland, prompting the closure of Nealson Street at Broad Street for several hours while cleanup crews worked. Local police confirmed the accident remains under investigation, and no injuries were reported. The truck managed to get only halfway across the tracks before being struck, leaving the corn spill beside the rails and the truck cab twisted as if it were driving on the tracks.

Leon Guin, a jockey driver at Amick Farms on Nealson Street near the crash site, said he saw the incident moments after it occurred. He recounted, “Our security guards heard the accident,” he said, “and two of our outside drivers saw and heard it also. They were bringing the chickens in at that time.” From his viewpoint, Guin could see the truck cab and the front portion of the trailer wrapped around the side of the train, with the covered load spilling onto the rail line.

President and General Counsel for Maryland and Delaware Railroad Company Cathrin Banks said she believed the train operators had done everything required when approaching the crossing. Police shut access at the Nealson Street entrance of Amick, rerouting traffic through the Route 392 and Delaware Avenue entrance, and cleanup was still ongoing four hours later. Hurlock Chief of Police Bruce Jones noted at press time that he could not yet release further details, including the truck driver’s name and the hauling company.

title: Church outside Trappe struck by lightning; storms cause other minor damages
author: Konner Metz
content:
Storms moved through Maryland on Tuesday, July 9, 2025, and at about 7:45 p.m. firefighters responded to the Faith Chapel United Methodist Church in the village of Bruceville, east of Trappe, after it was struck by lightning. The blaze caused roughly $25,000 in damage, but the Office of the State Fire Marshal reported no injuries. The Rev. Gary Moore said the damage is “very, very significant” for the small church, which dates to the 1880s. “I was there last night,” Moore said in an interview Wednesday. “Assessing the building will be a difficult decision as we move into the future.”

The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, assisted by neighboring fire departments, controlled the fire in about 20 minutes, according to the fire marshal’s report. Moore thanked the crews, noting “It’s what makes living in Talbot County a joy.” Sunday morning services at the Bruceville church will be moved to Trappe United Methodist Church on Maple Avenue.

Elsewhere in Talbot County, the storm felled around nine trees, downed wires, caused some flooding and a few minor car accidents. Talbot County Emergency Services Director Brian LeCates said, “We had a total of 24 incidents that were storm-related,” and added, “Most of them are trees down with wires and then just flooding on streets down in Oxford and here in Easton.” He urged residents to avoid driving through flooded waters and to “Prepare your homes for loose objects that will be blowing around,” and to “Secure loose objects.”  

Commerce Drive in Easton was temporarily closed by flooding Tuesday night but reopened shortly after. The St. Michaels town office will be closed Thursday for repairs to an electric pole lost in the storm, though no further outages are expected. Dorchester County emergency management planner Jimmy Windsor reported no major flooding or significant damages, noting only tree damage in the county’s northern parts. In Caroline County, a few downed trees were cleared from roadways by mid‑Wednesday. Easton Utilities reported two customers without power Tuesday night; President and CEO John Horner said, “Every upgrade we make strengthens our system, reduces outages, and ensures we’re prepared to meet growing demands.”  

The National Weather Service’s Mount Holly/Philadelphia office issued a flood‑watch alert for Caroline and Talbot counties from 5 p.m. Wednesday to 2 a.m. Thursday, indicating that thunderstorms are expected to continue.

title: Minor injured in Federalsburg vehicle fire
author: Staff Writer
content:
A minor suffered non‑life‑threatening burns to his arms after a vehicle fire erupted in Federalsburg shortly after 6:40 p.m. on Monday, according to a release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal. The blaze consumed a 2002 Ford Explorer and required a response from 24 firefighters, who spent about 20 minutes extinguishing the fire. The injured minor was transported to the Johns Hopkins Burn Center for treatment.

The fire marshal’s office indicated that the incident is still under investigation. "The fire does not appear suspicious in nature," the release said, "but the exact cause remains under investigation."

The report was published on June 11, 2024 in the Star Democrat (Easton, MD) by a staff writer in the Local News section. © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Changes ripple through Caroline County law enforcement
author: Staff Writer
content:
Recent developments have shaken law‑enforcement operations across Caroline County. In Ridgely, town employees and officials have filed a motion to dismiss a federal lawsuit brought by the town’s former police chief and officers. The plaintiffs argue the town violated their due‑process rights when the entire department was laid off last year, while the town maintains it was acting according to its charter and applicable laws.

Meanwhile, in Greensboro, the police department has tripled in size this year. Police Chief Lenox Trams, who in January was the department’s sole officer, welcomed a third officer this month who joins the department from the now‑defunct Federalsburg Police Department.

title: Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - A Preston man pleaded guilty Monday to attempted murder in connection to the February 2022 stabbing of a young woman.After waiving his right to a jury trial two weeks ago, Mark William Thompkins, 25, pleaded guilty to attempted second-degree murder during a hearing in Caroline County Circuit Court.The plea reached Monday comes over a year and a half after the stabbing of a then 25-year-old woman near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston shortly before 3 p.m. on Feb. 17, 2022.According to Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, trash collection workers near the scene first saw the woman sitting in the driver's seat of her vehicle with a man, later identified as Thompkins, seated behind her. Thompkins began striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck.The woman ran from her vehicle and collapsed in the front yard of a nearby house. Thompkins cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat, Franklin said.A witness attempted to help the victim but Thompkins threatened them, pointing the knife at them and yelling for them to get back.Multiple law enforcement agencies, including the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, Maryland State Police and Maryland Natural Resources Police, responded to the stabbing.Franklin said Thompkins punctured his own neck with a knife while running to the woods, evading officers.After 15 minutes and the use of multiple non-lethal methods, including a taser, to diffuse the situation, a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him, police said.Both Thompkins and the woman were flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment of their injuries.Following his arrest, a judge found Thompkins incompetent to stand trial in April 2022.He was committed to the Maryland Department of Health until August of this year, then transferred back to a local detention center upon being found competent, according to court filings.In court Monday, Franklin said he will recommend a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years of active incarceration suspended, followed by five years of supervised probation and special mental health conditions.State sentencing guidelines recommend five to 10 years, said Jesse Hicks, Thompkins' attorney. The plea is not binding, meaning a judge has the ability to impose a higher or lower sentence than what is recommended.Sentencing will be deferred until Feb. 1, 2024. 
 
 Caption: PHOTO BY MIKE DETMER
 
Police on scene in Preston for a reported stabbing Thursday, Feb. 17, 2022.

title: Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 670
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A Chestertown pediatrician has surrendered his license to practice in Maryland ahead of a civil case filed Tuesday morning in Kent County Circuit Court.Julio Ramirez, formerly head of his private practice at 6602 Church Hill Road in Chestertown, is being sued by a Kent County woman. The woman, who is not named in court filings, is seeking relief from the court for physical, psychological and emotional injuries she said she incurred while seeking treatment for her child in his office in 2023.
According to court documents, the woman was touched inappropriately and in a sexual manner while in the treatment room with Ramirez and her daughter. Following the encounter, which she said she tried to rebuff, the woman notified office staff and subsequently filed a report with the Chestertown Police Department.
In September 2023, the woman made a formal complaint to the Maryland State Board of Physicians.
Through the course of the board's investigation, four former employees "all testified to a pervasive environment of sexually abusive, unethical, and inappropriate behavior," according to the investigation report.
The investigation found Ramirez, on multiple occasions, sexually assaulted at least three female employees of his over the course of several years. The investigation further found that he sexually assaulted at least one other mother while in the course of treating her child.
Following the board's initial inquiry into the allegations in April, the board ordered a summary suspension of Ramirez's license, concluding "the public health, safety or welfare imperatively required emergency action in this case."
As a result of the board's investigation, Ramirez permanently surrendered his license to practice medicine, according to a letter Ramirez sent to the board.
As listed by the Maryland Board of Physicians, Ramirez, 65, graduated from Universidad de El Salvador Facultad de Medicina in 1988. He was first licensed in Maryland in 1998.
Ramirez opened his first office in Chestertown in 1999. According to information on his practice's website, he opened a second office in Centreville in 2004 to "better serve the Queen Anne's and neighboring communities." In February of 2015, he moved this office to the Shore Medical Pavilion in Queenstown. Hospital affiliations include the Anne Arundel Medical Center and Chester River Hospital Center.
The woman, named Jane Doe in the court filings, is represented by Schlachman, Belsky, Weiner & Davey of Baltimore. The complaint was filed by Michael J. Belsky and Catherine A. Dickinson.
In a statement released to the press, the law firm attorneys state Ramirez grabbed their client's breasts, vagina and buttocks in the course of examining her daughter. The attorneys state it is likely there are other victims.
"As alleged in the Complaint, Dr. Ramirez was a serial abuser of women. Our office is actively investigating these instances of abuse, especially against mothers who were assaulted while the doctor was treating their children. It goes without saying that this behavior is not acceptable, and we intend to hold the doctor accountable for his actions. We encourage anyone with information on these allegations to reach out to us," Belsky and Dickinson said in an interview with the Kent County News.
Ramirez's office is not taking phone calls. A message on his website states, "It is with a heavy heart that I announce my office has closed permanently. Due to unforeseen circumstances, and after careful deliberation, I have decided to retire and close my practice. I assure you that this decision was not made lightly, and I am deeply saddened that I will no longer be able to serve you and our community as a pediatrician."
He continues, "I would like to thank you for your time and the trust you have given me during our many years of operation in Chestertown. Taking care of your family was an honor and a privilege for me and my staff. My years here have been filled with countless rewarding experiences and the most remarkable patients. These shared moments will be remembered fondly, and will always be with me."
Contacted Tuesday morning, Kent County State's Attorney Brian DiGregroy was not able to immediately respond to inquires regarding any criminal charges. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Cambridge man charged with armed carjacking, robbery

 CAMBRIDGE - A Cambridge man was arrested Oct. 27 on 36 charges, including armed carjacking, armed robbery, assault, use of a firearm, reckless endangerment and theft.Kevin McClain, 53, was arrested in the 700 block of Race Street on Oct. 27. Police said McClain had an active Dorchester County District Court arrest warrant.Charges stem from an Oct. 3 incident where the Cambridge Police Department said officers responded to the 400 block of Caribbean Avenue around 1:40 a.m. regarding an armed robbery.Police said officers contacted the victim, who reported that after leaving their residence with a friend, another male subject came from the side of the residence, approaching the victim and knocking them to the ground.Police said the victim reported that the teen pulled out a handgun pointing and threatening to shoot them as he went through the victim's pockets, taking their wallet and vehicle keys. title: A 'crisis' on the shore — animal intake on the rise
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A 'crisis' on the shore — animal intake on the rise

 June 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Animal shelters across the Eastern Shore are facing higher levels of dog and cat intake than seen in years past.Patty Crankshaw-Quimby, executive director of Talbot Humane, said that just in the first six months of this calendar year, the shelter has seen a significant increase in the number of animals entering its care.
There has been a 35% increase in dog intake and a 25% increase in cat intake this year over 2023, she said. Crankshaw-Quimby noted that the shelter has yet to reach its busiest time of the year for kitten, which is in the later summer months and early fall.
"This is a trend we are seeing across the country," Crankshaw-Quimby said. "I am the president of Professional Animal Workers of Maryland, the state association of shelters and animal control agencies, and we are seeing crisis level intake in our larger municipalities."
A similar trend is being seen in Caroline County.
Karen Culotta, director of the Caroline County Humane Society, said the number of dogs at the animal shelter has increased significantly over the past four years.
The shelter is currently at 95% capacity. Though Culotta said they spend all their efforts caring for all the animals they can, the influx has overwhelmed the shelter.
Culotta acknowledged that it is difficult to determine the exact reason for the influx. She said it seems to go beyond issues of pets going without being spayed or neutered. She speculates that it could be economically driven.
"For some people, with the cost of vet care going up, with the cost of everything going up, or, since the pandemic, sometimes (people) can't afford to feed their animals or can't afford to get vaccinations, which is required of every cat and dog in the state of Maryland," Culotta said. "It's very challenging for everybody here."
Crankshaw-Quimby said that the Talbot County Shelter has embedded essential programs to help address the large number of animals the shelter is facing.
"We work very hard to keep animals out of the shelter with our robust assortment of programs; however, being an open admission shelter that turns no county resident in need of surrendering their pet away, as well as performing the role of animal control, one large animal control seizure or a wave of animal surrenders could put us over the top," Crankshaw-Quimby said. "This is why the foster, spay/neuter and intervention programs are so very important."
Culotta said she has contacted directors of other local shelters, and they have noted the "odd" rise in intake.
"It's definitely a crisis here on the Eastern Shore," Culotta said.
Culotta and Crankshaw-Quimby encouraged residents to partake in spray/neuter programs and to sign-up to take in foster animals, particularly dogs, at a local shelter. Participating in these programs can assist shelters as they go through high animal intake, they said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week

content:
The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week

 August 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 408
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here are the 10 stories that attracted the most page views on The Star Democrat's website this week. The stories are ranked in order of number of page views as of Wednesday evening.1. Tractor-trailer driver charged with assault in alleged hit-and-run. Police arrested a tractor-trailer driver on an assault charge last week after he allegedly hit a car three times at a red light in Easton.
2. Report: Dorchester County K-9 died in hot car. An investigation into the death of a Dorchester County K-9 revealed the dog died after being left in a hot car.
3. State test scores: Mid-Shore school districts see mixed results. The Maryland Department of Education released English and math test scores Aug. 26, revealing a major jump for one Mid-Shore school district and mixed results for others.
4. Trash dumpsters removed from multiple apartments in Greensboro. At the Greensboro Town Council meeting, Town Manager Cindy Yost revealed that multiple audits have been conducted on different parts of the town's finances.
5. Back to school: Talbot celebrates teachers, staff ahead of school year. Speaking before teachers and staff, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi encouraged employees to carry first-day-of-school energy with them throughout the entire year.
6. Easton council debates how to move forward with food trucks. After uproar from food truck owners and residents, the Easton Town Council is considering changes to its restrictions on food trucks.
7. Easton man charged for fatal June car accident near Trappe. Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office arrested Ellis Mitcham Newcomb, 18, of Easton for a fatal accident that took place in June. The charges were the result of a fatal accident on June 17 on Island Creek Road near the intersection of Chloras Point Road. The accident resulted in the death of 18-year-old Darren Foxwell. Newcomb was not injured in the crash.

9. Dorchester schools restricting cell phone usage. The Dorchester County Board of Education passed its new student policy on the use of electronic equipment, internet safety and portable electronic communication devices at the final board meeting before the school year begins.
10. Dorchester schools seek to curb student violence. This summer, North Dorchester High School became the first school to pilot Risk Threat Crisis' Violence Prevention Initiative.

title: Pride Flags stolen over the weekend
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Pride Flags stolen over the weekend

 June 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 137
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — The Chestertown Police Department is investigating the theft of Pride flags and other rainbow-themed items taken from the Emmanuel Church on Cross Street earlier this week.Police said they have multiple suspects in the theft of Pride flags (representing the LGBTQ+ community) that occurred over the weekend and "appropriate charges will be pending."
According to Cpl. Chris Schwink, there were a total of nine thefts reported in multiple locations, including Cross Street, High Street, Greenwood Avenue and Philosophers Terrace.
He confirmed all of the suspects were from "out of town" and male.
On their social media Facebook page, the police posted, "We want everyone to know this type of hate will not be tolerated in Chestertown. If you are a victim of anything similar, please reach us at 410-778-1800."
"Nobody's been charged yet, and it's still ongoing," Schwink said.

title: Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness

 January 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — From Queen Anne's County to Dorchester County many churches, libraries and senior centers assisted as various organizations hosted a point-in-time, a count of all experiencing unsheltered and sheltered homelessness.In Caroline County alone, approximately 142 people were reported to be in attendance on Wednesday. Jimmy Morris, continuum of care housing specialist for Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, said the count in Dorchester County recorded its highest ever number of people experiencing homelessness. Finalized numbers for the Mid-Shore will not be available for several weeks.
Morris said large efforts were made to reach this specific population, from media outreach to visiting encampments. He said this larger effort was made due to the growing population of homelessness on the Shore.
Over the last few years, the population of people experiencing homelessness has skyrocketed on the Eastern Shore, and organizations focused on assisting this population are working to have a proper count in order to better secure funds to provide resources.
Ashley Kessinger, continuum care manager at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, said this winter the organization's shelters were filled with people trying to stay warm.
"It's been a crisis," Kessinger said. "Our shelters are completely full, and they stay full all the time. They're all working off of waitlists. They're all trying to find other ways so that people that come to them, don't have to turn them away. But they're just full and we don't have enough."
According to Kessinger, the results of the data gathered by each jurisdiction will be submitted to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and can be used to secure grant funding.
Yvette Robinson, grant manager at Neighborhood Service Center, was distributing information at the Fredrick Douglas room of the Talbot County Free Library in Easton, one of the locations for the county Wednesday. Robinson said homelessness on the Eastern Shore looks different in comparison to homelessness in major cities. One of those contributing factors, she said, is resources.
"The numbers are growing, the resources are not," Robinson said. "We rely on community partners to try to collaborate so that we can see what's working, what may not be working …we're just trying to get the information out that there are variable resources."
According to Robinson, since Nov. 24, 2024, Neighborhood Service Center has given out 9,000 pounds of food and served over 600 families, a majority of which were homeless.
Kessinger said a contributing factor to the growing homeless population has been a lack of affordable housing on the shore. Many of the people served at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health either have no income or they receive funds from Social Security which can be about $900 a month.
A lack of affordable housing has made the issue worse but it is the mark of homelessness that will make it difficult to get landlords to consider working on affordable housing alternatives.
In her experience, there are some landlords that refuse to help customers that her organization works with because the customers have experienced homelessness. Kessinger said there is an assumption that the customers will be bad tenants or bad people in general.
For Kessinger, everyone deserves help and people shouldn't treat those experiencing homelessness differently because of their circumstance because it can happen to anyone at any time.
"People think homelessness looks a certain way and we have seen people from all walks of life and it does not look a certain way," Kessinger said. "There's a lot of stigma on the shore about homelessness and some people just don't want to see it. If they come across an encampment or something like that, they just want it to go away. …everyone deserves a chance to have a home." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school
author: Konner Metz
content:
Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Newsletters 
 
 187
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Local police and emergency medical professionals took part in a serious training of the utmost importance in Easton on Thursday.Active shooter situations in elementary and secondary schools caused 328 deaths from 2000 to 2022, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.
That's why before every school year, local first responders have made it a habit to complete active shooter trainings. This year's training brought Talbot and Caroline sheriff's deputies, Easton police, local EMTs and paramedics, and others to The Country School.
Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull led a drill Thursday afternoon, showing me just how critical it is that first responders from different counties to work together cohesively under stress.
And the results were enlightening: officers and EMTs didn't always make the correct decision every split-second, but they did confer with each other on what steps to take during the next drill, learning how to get better along the way.
To learn more about the training, read my story below. Also in today's newsletter: Talbot Mentors helps local students achieve their goals, a conservation easement will become a public park in Dorchester County and more.
Thanks for reading.
— Konner Metz

title: '25 kids should not take this whole city down' - Cambridge council grapples with youth crime in city
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
'25 kids should not take this whole city down' - Cambridge council grapples with youth crime in city

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 610
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Youth issues were the overwhelming theme for the third Cambridge City Council meeting in a row.At the Sept. 12 meeting, residents and commissioners alike made comments about juvenile crime.Lance Cephas, who is the father of Commission President Lajan Cephas and Commissioner Sputty Cephas, said crime is affecting everyone, including the children and families who aren't part of the problem.He further noted the children who aren't contributing to juvenile crime are being punished for the actions of about 25 children, "25 kids should not take this whole city down," he said.Lance Cephas stressed the importance of educating the kids that are caught doing things they shouldn't be."Because if you send them back home to that same environment, ain't nothing going to happen," he said. "A lot of police officers, they'll pick them up, they'll let them go, and soon as they're around the corner, they've done something else to somebody else. So you've got to get them and educate them." He said he understood both his children's, Lajan and Sputty, and Mayor Stephen Rideout's points of view regarding the juvenile curfew but said the council shouldn't be "at each other's throats" and "controlled by 25 kids." "We've all got to come together," he said.In late August, Rideout vetoed a juvenile curfew ordinance which commissioners had passed Aug. 14.Before that, in July, Rideout had proposed an alternative curfew ordinance which had additions and changes from the original curfew ordinance. These included adding definitions and altering language on enforcement procedures and penalties.Since Rideout vetoed the original curfew ordinance, Sputty Cephas has made amendments to Rideout's alternative ordinance in an effort to compromise and "find middle ground." According to council meeting documents, Cephas plans to recommend these amendments Sept. 25 when Rideout's proposed ordinance will be read for a second time.During the meeting, Sputty Cephas talked about finding that middle ground."Commissioner Atkiss made a point to say that $100 is a lot of money for a struggling parent," he said."My day job is in banking, so I understand that struggle as well." Sputty Cephas said he would like to keep fines as part of the penalty for not following the curfew, but said he cut them in half in his amendment. Instead of a $100 fine, it would be $50.At the end of the meeting, Rideout suggested to Sputty Cephas that the two of them get together to talk about the proposed amendments to the alternative ordinance. Sputty Cephas agreed to meet.Two presentations were given during Monday's meeting, as well. One presentation was given by Pam Gregory, president and CEO of United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, and one by Lisa Molock, chief executive director at Let's Thrive Baltimore and an organizer for Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America.Molock talked about the work she has been doing in Baltimore, and Gregory talked about the economic issues that many Marylanders face. She shared data from a report that focused on asset limited, income constrained and employed (or ALICE) Marylanders and shared data on Dorchester County residents specifically. Gregory said that in Dorchester County, 45% of residents are below the ALICE threshold.During public comment, Theresa Stafford said poverty is a "lead driver" for many other issues in Cambridge."We need to get serious about fixing the problem of poverty," Stafford said."Bringing in industries or businesses that will pay good wages, and of course, supporting getting kids educated because that's the other key driver that keeps driving up the crime." 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Pam Gregory, CEO of United Way of the Lower Eastern Shore, gives a presentation at a Cambridge City Council meeting on Sept. 11. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Firefighters handle major town house blaze in St. Michaels
author: Konner Metz
content:
Firefighters handle major town house blaze in St. Michaels

 June 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Firefighters across the Mid-Shore worked together to put out a large town house fire in St. Michaels on Saturday. No injuries were reported.Around 1:20 p.m. Saturday, the St. Michaels Fire Department responded to a fire at a six-unit town house complex on Martingham Circle. Assistant Chief Phil Jones said a second alarm was requested. Agencies from Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester and Queen Anne's counties assisted, with at least 70 people on the scene.
The fire was caused by an electrical failure with an HVAC system in the attic, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal.
Jones said two of the six units will be "displaced for some time." A third unit incurred small fire damage, a fourth unit sustained water damage and the other two units were unharmed, he said.
The fire marshal's office estimates $1 million in damages to the structure and contents.
First responders were able to extinguish most of the fire in the first hour of efforts. Jones said firefighters were on scene for over four hours Saturday to fully handle the blaze. They had to be mindful of the hot conditions.
"With the heat, it makes it twice as hard for us," Jones said. "Usually a firefighter can only work five to 15 minutes in the heat" without taking a break, he added.
All firefighters were required to receive a medical check on their vitals, Jones said. Crews went through over 20 cases of bottled waters.
Jones emphasized that the firefighters on scene were all volunteers. He expressed appreciation for the responding units from surrounding counties, as the additional manpower was necessary for such a hot day. Jones said there was good cooperation with the homeowners and between fire agencies.
"We all work together to complete everything," Jones said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Students and staff at Easton High School are evacuating after a bomb threat made Monday afternoon, according to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.At 2:57 p.m., the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said in a release posted to Facebook that deputies are on scene at the school. Students and staff were evacuated into the stadium and are safe, police say.
Police say students who are car riders are being picked up at the Easton Elks Lodge, students who are bus riders are riding buses and students who are walkers can walk home.
As of 3:01 p.m., "all buses (were) being loaded and released from EHS," according to police. All after-school activities are canceled.
Talbot County Public Schools sent EHS families a message at around 2:15 p.m. on Monday.
"Easton High has received a Bomb threat. At this time the school is on lockdown," the message stated. "We are waiting further direction from law enforcement."
"This is an ongoing investigation and Deputies will be on scene for several hours," Talbot County Sheriff's Office stated. "Please avoid the area and obey police detours. We will be sure to release additional information as soon as it becomes available."
Earlier on Monday, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office said it was investigating a threat made on social media.
Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday morning that the threat, which originated on Instagram, was not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code. It was not immediately shared by law enforcement if the Easton High lockdown resulted from this threat or from a separate threat.
On Monday morning, Gamble said all school resource officers in the district were aware of the threat, and extra deputies were patrolling.
On Friday, TCPS students were put in a modified lockdown following a threatening social media post made that morning. According to the Sheriff's Office, the threat originated outside of the United States and similar threats were made to schools in Easton, Pennsylvania.
This report will be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Family fights Dunkirk cemetery's plan to move plot
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Family fights Dunkirk cemetery's plan to move plot

 December 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 508
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to her daughter, it was in 1989 that Gloria Moseley purchased two plots at Dunkirk's Southern Memorial Gardens. It was supposed to be a modest resting place in a quiet rural setting.Laura Dodgson, Moseley's daughter who now lives in North Carolina, said her sister died in 1994 and her brother died four years later. Urns containing their ashes were buried side-by-side on the site.
Gloria Moseley died in 2002 and eight years later her husband, Robert, passed. Both were laid to rest at the family gravesite.
Southern Memorial Gardens has had different owners since 1989, when the Moseleys purchased the plots.
Now the cemetery owners say mistakes have been made. Their solution has brought distress to the family.
In a letter to Southern Maryland News, Dodgson said she received a phone call from cemetery officials back in September.
"They stated that my family had been buried in the wrong plot and that they would have to be dug up and moved," Dodgson wrote.
During a phone conversation with Dodgson after the letter was received, Southern Maryland News learned cemetery officials, via mail, told her to sign papers for moving the family members to another location.
"I don't want them moved," Dodgson said.
When Southern Maryland News contacted the cemetery about the situation, the employee answering the phone provided contact information for the business's attorney, Kevin Vitelli.
"It happens at every cemetery," Vitelli said of the Moseley family's situation. "Mistakes were made in 1989. We're just trying to make it right."
Vitelli, whose law practice is based in Pennsylvania, said the relocation of the family's plot would be done at no additional cost.
The local cemetery has a well-documented history of problems.
Nearly 20 years ago, fraudulent activity on the part of former owner, Larry Deffenbaugh, came to light after a Maryland State Police investigation. Deffenbaugh was later convicted of defrauding over 500 people out of funeral and memorial items.
He had entered an Alford plea, which is not an admission of guilt, but an acknowledgment that prosecutors have evidence to support a charge, received a 15-year suspended sentence and ordered to pay restitution to the victims.
Deffenbaugh's story then gets more convoluted, as he was summoned back to court for a violation of probation hearing but failed to appear. Apparently not wishing to go to prison, Deffenbaugh reportedly fell off a fishing boat. He was, however, recaptured in 2010 and sent to prison.
Dodgson said her late sister's daughter, Pam, filed court papers to have her mother's urn removed from the cemetery and given over to her. Dodgson and another family member confirmed that the urn was flooded with water.
Dodgson said she fears the disturbance of the plot could result in the collapse of the vaults where her parents' coffins are laid.
The family has been in contact with attorneys for a possible breech of contract and gross negligence lawsuit.
"There were some mistakes made by prior owners," Vitelli said of the Southern Memorial Gardens situation. "We have to correct those mistakes."
The attorney added that while aggrieved plot owners have been urged to file suit, "nobody has filed any action against the cemetery." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton man gets five years for narcotics charges
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton man gets five years for narcotics charges

 November 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - An Easton man was sentenced Wednesday, Nov. 22, to five years in prison for possession with the intent to distribute narcotics.During a plea hearing, Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen Kehoe found Jaurice K. Henry, 27, guilty of two drug charges, handing down two 15-year sentences and suspending all but five years of each in a binding agreement. The two fiveyear terms will be served concurrently, according to court documents.Henry's release will be followed by three years of supervised probation.The charges against Henry stemmed from the Easton Police Department's investigation into a fatal overdose late last year.Police were dispatched to the Econo Lodge on Dec. 5, 2022, for an overdose victim.Officers began and continued resuscitation efforts until they were relieved by Talbot County paramedics.The victim was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, where he was later pronounced dead.Detectives with EPD's Criminal Investigations Division conducted the death investigation. After several months, Henry and Iyana Wilson, 27, were identified as the individuals who sold a cocaine and fentanyl mix to the victim, police said.Two cases involving alleged drug possession and distribution remain pending against Wilson.In September, Wilson entered an Alford plea to possession with intent to distribute narcotics in one case. She is set to be sentenced Dec. 15 in Talbot County Circuit Court.A second case charges Wilson with manufacturing narcotics, conspiring with Henry to manufacture drugs, possession of drug paraphernalia and obstructing justice.She is also alleged to have altered physical evidence relevant to a criminal proceeding and to have possessed contraband in a place of confinement by having narcotics inside her body while at the Easton Police Department, according to charging documents.The second case against Wilson is set for a status conference on Dec. 1.

 CHESTER — A Chester man has been arrested in connection with the murder of his father. The Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff's Criminal Investigation Unit arrested Drew Bernard Meyer, 32, of Chester, charging him with first degree murder in the death of his father, Wayne Michael Meyer, 65, also of Chester.According to police reports, on May 17, deputies were dispatched to Auckland Way in Chester, for a report of a cardiac arrest. title: Time to remove delivery boxes
author: Staff Writer
content:
On December 28, 2024, the *Star Democrat* (Easton, MD) published a reader’s letter that highlights the ongoing presence of the newspaper’s yellow delivery boxes that have been left in front yards and on local roads since the paper discontinued hand‑delivery. The letter begins, “As your editor reminds us frequently, the decision to stop hand delivery of the Star Democrat to our homes is perhaps economically necessary and practical to continue bringing local news to our community.”

The writer complains that these boxes “do not get prettier with time and will continue to mar our beautiful highways until they are removed,” and calls for a way to unearth and dispose of them “without buying tools, hiring someone or hurting ourselves.” The letter stresses that the rusted containers are “too rusty and dangerous for service groups or school kids to get service hours.”

The writer asks, “If we get them out of the ground, can someone collect them and dispose of them in a responsible way? Too rusty and dangerous for service groups or school kids to get service hours? Let’s come up with a happy resolution for keeping our scenery free of antiquated ugliness, OK?” The letter is signed “SUZANNE HOOD, Royal Oak” and is published under the *Star Democrat’s* staff writer’s section.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the hazard posed by rusted delivery boxes in public spaces and calls for safe removal, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Crime in Cambridge 'trending down,' police department says
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said the city’s crime data “trending down” based on the department’s first‑quarter 2024 report, which shows a drop in reported incidents, ShotSpotter alerts, and shots fired calls compared with the same period last year.  
“A lot of credit goes to our officers that are out doing what we're asking of them to do as an administration,” Todd said about these decreases. “And that's patrol with a purpose, be in our high‑crime areas.”

The report records 200 crime incidents submitted to the National Incident‑Based Reporting System in Q1 2024, down from 247 in Q1 2023, and notes that most of those incidents were assaults.  ShotSpotter alerts fell 33.3% to 46, and shots fired calls fell 40.9% to 13.  The first quarter also had one shooting, confirmed by Todd as occurring on March 1 in the 800 block of Phillips Street.  Police found several spent shell casings from multiple calibers, and Isaiah David Foster, 23, of Cambridge was arrested on firearm possession, resisting arrest, and obstructing and hindering charges.  
“We know there's more out there, and we know there's still crime,” Todd said. “But we're making progress.”

Calls for service rose 9.1% to 171 adult arrests, 8 juvenile arrests, and 34 juvenile referrals, though Todd said the numbers for last year were not available.  He described juvenile crime as “stagnant” and added, “I think there's a lot of work to do with juvenile reform,” continuing, “We have to put more emphasis on figuring out why these kids are out committing these crimes and getting in touch with families by working through social services and Juvenile Services.”  Todd expects a clearer picture after summer, stating, “When the kids get out of school, that'll be a big factor of just how good we're doing crime‑wise.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on crime trends, police department statistics, and safety initiatives, which directly relate to public safety concerns.

title: 2 arrested on gun charges in Days Inn incident
author: Konner Metz
content:
Police arrested Ernest Young Jr., 40, of Federalsburg and Katherine Adkins, 29, of Queen Anne on August 12 after an incident at the Days Inn hotel in Easton. Young is charged with first‑degree assault, home invasion, reckless endangerment and four firearm charges; Adkins faces two handgun charges, accessory after the fact to a felony, altering physical evidence and making a false statement to an officer.

Around 1:40 p.m. on August 12, police were dispatched to a first‑floor room. According to court documents, 58‑year‑old James Terrell Jr. told police he and Adkins were in the room when Young knocked at the door. A few minutes later, Terrell told police that Young allegedly pointed a gun at his chest. Terrell then grabbed Adkins and left the room before “Young grabbed Adkins and took her back” into the room, per court records. A woman in a second‑floor room later told police that Adkins “knocked on her door and handed her a handgun.” Adkins allegedly told the woman, “‘Take this ’cause I don’t want to get in trouble,’” court records indicate. An officer saw Adkins on the second floor and approached her. Adkins told officers “there was no gun” and soon after “doubled down” on that assertion. Officers found a gun in the second‑floor room, which was allegedly the same one hidden by Adkins and held by Young during the first‑floor incident.

Adkins was released on a $25,000 unsecured personal bond on August 14. A preliminary hearing is set for September 2. Young posted a $1,000 cash bond on August 3, and his preliminary hearing is set for September 3.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police response, arrests, and firearm charges, which are matters of public safety rather than sports, education, or other categories.

Katherine Adkins, 29, of Queen Anne

title: Leaving a timeless mark: Remembering lives lost with roadside memorials
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Along Route 210 in Bryans Road, a metal cross marks the spot where Tiffani Carrington was killed on Dec. 21, 1996.  The cross reads “Tiffani” in large letters, has a red flower at the top, and bears the Bryans Road Volunteer Fire Department and Rescue Squad insignia.  According to Deborah Carrington‑Smith, “She was 19 years old,” and “Her car, a 1987 Nissan 300ZX, was broadsided by a Charles County sheriff’s officer.”  Carrington‑Smith added that the 19‑year‑old “was a child full of spunk, a teenager wise beyond her years and an EMT with aspirations of becoming a flight paramedic. She was a cheerleader, a softball player, a coach and a mentor to other youth. She was the apple of her father’s eye and a bit bossy with her younger brothers. She had so much love to give and was never stingy with her affection.”  Her mother said, “This is who Tiffani was to our family,” and described her further: “She spoke her mind unabashedly, valuing authenticity, honesty and courage.”  “Material things were not important to her and she judged people by how they treated others.”

The state’s rules for roadside memorials are vague.  SHA spokesman Daniel Allman told Southern Maryland News, “State Highway Administration does not track memorials that are placed along state highways in memory of crash victims.”  “However, state law prohibits the unauthorized placement of anything along state highways that are not approved, highway safety‑related signs or devices.”  “The placement of roadside memorials could pose safety and maintenance concerns for motorists, pedestrians and highway workers.”  Despite this, many memorials remain on Maryland roads, and the state offers legal alternatives such as the Adopt‑a‑Highway program and Partnership Plantings.

Another memorial, at the intersection of Tim’s Place in Nanjemoy, honors 20‑year‑old Autumn Jenkins, who died in a collision on April 28, 2015.  Katelyn Shannon described the memorial: “The memorial to her cousin ‘sits in front of a telephone pole. We have a stone that was engraved with a drawing of a dog and the fire shield. We also have her helmet shield up and we actively put flowers and solar lights. We actively attend DUI checkpoints conducted by the La Plata Police Department in memory of her.”  Jenkins was a volunteer responder and worked at the Charles County Humane Society and a Waldorf pool, and the 0.14 blood‑alcohol level of the truck driver was cited in her sentencing.

The memorials for 27‑year‑old Lauren Pitt and 55‑year‑old motorcycle rider Conrado “Chico” Fabricante Jr. stand in front of the guardrail on southbound Route 2/4 near Rousby Hall Road.  Jonna Jones remembered Pitt, “Her enthusiasm for people made me feel like I could do anything.”  “Such a bright, positive person. We lost a bright light when she passed.”  “This year it will be 10 years, that’s hard to believe,” Jones said.  Jones also noted her participation in a half‑marathon to honor Pitt, “It helped me keep going,” she added.

Other roadside memorials highlight different tragedies.  A cross bearing “Joseph” on Three Notch Road marks the fatal crash of 24‑year‑old David Joseph Johnson on Oct. 1, 2018; the St. Mary’s County Sheriff’s Office release said his sedan “went out of control ‘for unknown reasons.’”  Then‑Captain Steve Hall told The Enterprise, “There’s only one person that knows, and that person can’t tell us.”  “There’s never any logical explanation.”  Zachary “Zack” Spain’s memorial on a utility pole in Prince Frederick is kept in flowers year‑long, “I keep flowers all year round attached to the utility pole,” Kandia Spain told Southern Maryland News.  Finally, a small white cross at the Route 5 and Chingville Road intersection commemorates Brysen McKinley Carter, 8, who died in a March 16, 2024 single‑vehicle crash; a GoFundMe raised more than $19,000 and a Pax River Raiders tribute wrote, “I miss you every day, Lil Bro.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on road deaths, memorials, and the safety/legal issues surrounding roadside markers, which best fits the Public Safety category.

title: Bill could improve police awareness of unseen disabilities
author: SOfIA APPOLONIO Capital News Service
content:
Lawmakers in Maryland are debating “Eric’s ID Law,” a bill that would allow residents to add a notation to their driver’s license or state ID card indicating an invisible disability such as autism or hearing impairment.  If passed, the measure would require law enforcement to receive training on interacting with people who have hidden disabilities and would task the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration with developing awareness programs.  The proposal aims to protect individuals with invisible disabilities during encounters with first responders, a concern that has been heightened for parents of Black children who may be at higher risk during police interactions.

“The reality of these encounters presents differently when your Black son transitions to adulthood and becomes a legally independent Black man,” said bill co‑sponsor Del. Kym Taylor, a Democrat representing Prince George’s County, who explained that her son has a hidden disability.  “There are no visible signs nor immediate indicators to help first responders understand potential reactions.”  Named after 20‑year‑old Eric Blessed Carpenter Grantham, a Black man living with autism, the bill arose after Grantham and his mother Linda feared he might face police encounters that could not accommodate his disability.  Grantham, who designed logos that could be displayed on ID cards, said, “Eric’s ID Law was created to help save lives for people who cannot use their own voice.”

Prince George’s County Sheriff John Carr expressed support, stating, “From a law enforcement perspective, we want you to know that we are here to serve you and we want this bill to pass.”  He added, “Any time that we’re able to put a citizen at ease during a traffic stop, that is something that helps us interact and keep our community safe.”  Similar initiatives already exist in Maryland, such as the MVA “blue card” and the Ethan Saylor Alliance, which was formed in 2015 to provide additional training for law enforcement after the death of 26‑year‑old Saylor, who had Down syndrome, in a police altercation at a Frederick movie theater.  If enacted, Maryland would join 11 other states that allow people with disabilities to identify themselves on identification cards.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a proposed law affecting police interactions with individuals who have invisible disabilities, which is primarily a public safety issue, while also addressing racial concerns.

title: Fire Marshal investigating Greensboro vehicle fire
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The Office of the State Fire Marshal is investigating an intentional vehicle fire that occurred on Kibler Road in Greensboro on Friday night, July 1, 2024. The fire was in the passenger compartment of a 2011 Kia owned by Linda Bennett and was discovered by family members just before midnight. Firefighters from the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company spent about 20 minutes to control the blaze, and no injuries were reported. The incident caused approximately $4,000 in damage to the vehicle and its contents.

This fire is the second deliberate incident at 12,640 Kibler Road in just four days. The first was an abandoned mobile home that was set on fire on Tuesday, June 25. The fire marshal’s office noted that the mobile home had been abandoned for more than 15 years and that no injuries occurred in that incident either.

Residents or anyone with information about either of the fires can contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal at 410‑822‑7609.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an investigation by the State Fire Marshal into intentional vehicle and property fires, focusing on safety, fire response, and public alerts, which aligns directly with the Public Safety topic.
