title: Investigators looking into fatal crash in Easton
author: Staff Writer
content:
The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General is investigating a fatal crash that followed an attempted traffic stop and pursuit in Easton on Monday evening. Just after 7 p.m., deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, driving marked police cruisers, encountered a vehicle on westbound Route 50 near Dutchmans Lane and tried to initiate a traffic stop. The driver did not comply and the car was pursued for several minutes.

The pursuit ended when the vehicle crashed into a tree in the 8300 block of Black Dog Alley. Four people were in the car. Officers from the Easton Police Department, who were assisting, rendered aid and emergency medical services were called to the scene. The driver, a juvenile male, and a front‑seat passenger, an adult woman, were taken to a local hospital for serious injuries; the adult woman was later pronounced dead there. The two rear passengers, another juvenile male and an adult woman, were transported to an area hospital for treatment of serious injuries. Officers were equipped with body‑worn cameras.

The investigation is being conducted by the Independent Investigations Division with help from the Maryland State Police Crash Team. Anyone with information about the incident is asked to contact 410‑576‑7070 or email IID@oag.state.md.us.

title: Caroline commissioners discuss plan for public safety after Ridgely police suspension
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
On March 13, the Ridgely Commissioners suspended the entire police department with pay, effective immediately, pending an investigation by the Office of the Maryland State Prosecutor.  No reason for the investigation was indicated in the town’s press release.

The next day, the six officers that normally work for the department were put on hold.  On March 19, county commissioners announced a temporary agreement with the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office to provide public safety for Ridgely residents.  The plan calls for the sheriff’s office to work a single five‑hour shift each day, seven days a week, while the Maryland State Police will take over the other half of law‑enforcement duties.

The sheriff’s office will also handle 911 dispatch calls for half the town’s incidents, with the Maryland State Police handling the remaining calls.  Sheriff Donald Baker will be responsible for securing warrants, firearms and the front door of the Ridgely Police Department during the suspension.

Caroline County’s Police Accountability Board is currently reviewing a case involving the Ridgely Police Department.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on how local officials are arranging law‑enforcement coverage after the police department suspension, centering on maintaining public safety for the community.

title: Talbot County man charged for possessing, distributing child porn
author: Konner Metz
content:
A 20‑year‑old from Talbot County, Jordan Cabrera, was arrested on March 2, 2025, after a Talbot County Sheriff's Office news release. He was charged with three separate counts of child pornography: two for soliciting a minor to be a subject in such material and one for knowingly distributing it.  

The charges were filed by Cabrera’s ex‑girlfriend, who was underage when they dated from 2021 to 2023. Court records say she alleges Cabrera obtained nude photos from the then‑minor and sent them on Telegram, and that the images also appeared on Instagram and Twitter. She wrote that they broke up in 2023, a month before she turned 18, and that “she was a minor in every nude photo and video,” per the charging documents.  

Cabrera was initially held without bond but posted a $1,500 bond on March 3. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for March 31.

title: Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
The state attorney general’s office released a 70‑page audit on Thursday, May 16, 2025, concluding that Anton Black’s 2018 death in Greensboro should have been ruled homicide.  The report examined 87 cases investigated by former Medical Examiner Dr. David Fowler between 2003 and 2019, reclassifying the cause of death from accidental, unknown or natural to homicide in 36 of them, including Black’s.  Black, 19, was handcuffed and shackled by Greensboro Police Officer Thomas Webster IV, off‑duty Ridgely Police Chief Gary Manos, Centreville Police Officer Dennis Lannon, and a civilian; he was pinned against a wooden handicap ramp for six minutes.  After he stopped breathing, he was taken to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton and pronounced dead that evening.  Fowler had originally ruled his death a sudden cardiac event, but a later Johns Hopkins cardiologist concluded asphyxiation was the cause.

“The audit also validated concerns that bias may have affected death investigations in Maryland,” Attorney General Anthony Brown said in a letter to Marylanders included with the report.  “Addressing those concerns benefits everyone in our system of justice — including the vast majority of law enforcement professionals who perform their duties with integrity and deserve clear, consistent standards.”  Gov. Wes Moore wrote, “This audit marks the beginning of a long conversation — one that must be handled with honesty, delicacy, resolve, and deep consideration,” and highlighted reforms underway in the medical examiner’s office that have been in progress for several years.

The audit was led by Towson University psychology professor Jeff Kukucka and began in 2021 after Dr. Fowler’s testimony in the Derek Chauvin trial, in which Fowler cited “excited delirium” as a possible cause of death, a term that over 450 medical experts had condemned.  The 2023 settlement of a lawsuit by the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black and his family required policy changes for deaths in custody, incorporating guidelines from the National Association of Medical Examiners.  “This 70‑page independent report vindicates what family members and communities — mostly Black and Brown Marylanders — have been saying for decades: the truth.  That the entire system has been complicit in making police‑involved deaths seem inevitable,” said ACLU of Maryland senior staff attorney Sonia Kumar in a statement Friday.

An executive order issued by Governor Moore on the same day called for the attorney general’s office and the state’s attorney’s office to examine whether any cases should be reopened based on the audit’s findings and established a task force to review the handling of in‑custody deaths.  The audit thus marks a potential turning point for Maryland’s death‑investigation procedures and the broader conversation about bias and transparency in police‑involved fatalities.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a police‑involved death, an audit of medical examiner rulings, and policy reforms related to law‑enforcement custody, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Counties and towns prepare for snow on the Mid-Shore this weekend
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Counties and towns prepare for snow on the Mid-Shore this weekend

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 531
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With snow in the forecast this Sunday and Monday, Mid-Shore towns and counties are making plans and readying their snow plows."Every storm is different and unique," Easton Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said. "But we feel that we're prepared and ready for the storm."
On Friday, the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services had a meeting with local towns to coordinate in preparation for the winter weather.
According to the National Weather Service forecast as of Friday afternoon, snow is likely to fall in Easton from Sunday night into Monday. The weather organization is expecting a "major winter storm" will bring snow and ice across the country, "from the Central Plains to the Mid-Atlantic" this weekend.
Sunday night, there is a 90% chance of precipitation in Easton with snow expected mainly after 1 a.m., according to the National Weather Service. On Monday, there is a 90% chance of precipitation in Easton with snow expected before 1 p.m. and then rain and snow likely. Monday night, there is a 50% chance of precipitation.
Talbot County Public Schools Communications Director Debbie Gardner said the district is monitoring the forecast to determine if closures will be necessary.
Dorchester County Emergency Management Division Director Jimmy Windsor said Dorchester County has warned all its departments of the predicted weather, including its Highway Division. He said the county's Highway Division is preparing its inclement weather plans.
Van Emburgh said on Friday that Easton was putting plows on the fronts of trucks and loading salt into the trucks that spread salt.
"And we have equipment that we're placing around town that we'll use to address alleys and some of the tighter spots that we plow," he said.
Windsor said it is important that residents make sure they take the usual winter preparedness precautions, such as making sure vehicles have gas in them. He said that residents who live in areas that are prone to power outages should make sure they have blankets and warm clothing in the event of an outage.
"And a supply of fresh water in case the power goes out and you're on well water and therefore you rely on the power for your water source," he said.
Van Emburgh said it's helpful if residents do not park their cars on main streets.
"When people park on the streets, we have to plow around the cars and sometimes that can — depending on how much snow we get — that can get tricky and then we plow the cars in," he said.
Van Emburgh also talked about the importance of not plowing snow from the sidewalks into the street.
"Because we then plow it back onto the sidewalk," he said, laughing. "It's just a battle. (Residents) plow it onto the street. We plow it back onto the sidewalk. And they get mad at us."
Van Emburgh said residents should plow snow off their sidewalks by starting in the center of the street and working toward a house or building so that the snow is plowed into a yard.
"Some properties don't have yards," he said. "But if you plow it out in the street, it's just going to get pushed back onto the sidewalk. So we ask that everything moves away from the center of the street."

title: Bikers try (and try) to gut a state helmet law
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
Bikers try (and try) to gut a state helmet law

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 955
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A group of bikers in leather vests and wispy beards greets lawmakers here each Monday of the legislative session, hoping this is the year they'll succeed in their galvanizing cause: gutting a Maryland law that requires them to wear helmets.The group, which calls itself A Brotherhood Against Totalitarian Enactments, has experienced decades of setbacks on the helmet issue. Its vociferous critics say ABATE's position is at a minimum, eccentric and at worst, dangerous.
But driven by a burning belief in personal freedom and a joy for riding, ABATE has used persistent, grassroots activism to keep the helmet issue alive in Maryland. It's why in nearly every legislative session since the state's mandatory helmet law took effect in 1992, the Maryland General Assembly has at least considered a bill that would make wearing a helmet optional for most riders.
"It's been 32 years this year to no avail," said Bob Spanburgh, Maryland ABATE's board chairman. "But we keep introducing it. We have some pretty ardent supporters. We have a lot of people who think we're nuts, probably."
Like many of its previous incarnations over the last three decades, this year's bill would make wearing a helmet optional if a motorcyclist is at least 21 years old, has been licensed for a minimum of two years and has completed a safety course. It is named in honor of Gary "Pappy" Boward, a former ABATE executive director and motorcycle rights advocate who died in 2020 of health issues.
ABATE and other supporters insist that they aren't opposed to riders wearing helmets if they so choose. But they feel the current mandate abridges freedom of choice and represents government overreach.
"I firmly believe that we as government do better when we educate people, (rather) than legislating something," said Sen. Mike McKay (R-Allegany, Garrett and Washington), the bill's primary Senate sponsor and a friend of Boward's. "There are people that would like to have the choice (to not wear a helmet). And I tend to believe that we should give people the choice but 100% support educating them about it."
Established in 1974, ABATE will mark 50 years of advocacy for motorcyclists' rights this June. Its animating issue has been eroding Maryland's helmet law, different iterations of which have been in place since 1968. Today, Maryland joins 16 other states and the District of Columbia in requiring all riders to wear protective headgear.
Spanburgh, a 66-year-old retired carpenter, only casually followed politics when he joined ABATE in the mid-1980s. Initially, he saw the group as a community of like-minded individuals, who shared his enthusiasm for bikes, firearms, the outdoors and rock and roll. But right away, ABATE turned Spanburgh into an unlikely activist.
"At the first meeting I went to, the thing they told me (was), 'You got to register to vote. It's very important in this organization,'" Spanburgh recalled. "That was actually the first time I ever registered to vote in my life. I was 27 at the time."
Each legislative session, the helmet bill faces cockeyed glances and prodigious odds. Contending with a wealth of scientific evidence, which shows crashes involving non-helmeted motorcyclists are much more likely to result in severe head trauma and death, the measure almost always dies in committee.
But ABATE ensures the issue is revived and relitigated, year after year, by finding ways to get in front of elected officials, despite limited financial resources and dwindling numbers. In the past, the group used a tactic it called "piss house politics," which involved following lawmakers into the bathroom to gain an audience and get its message heard.
"They're diehards for what they believe in," said Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Caroline, Cecil, Kent and Queen Anne's). "Thank God they do. They don't let go of this stuff. It's a tough fight over here to get that kind of legislation passed."
While Republicans are the most likely to sympathize with ABATE's cause, the group engages lawmakers on both sides of the aisle. This year's bill, cross-filed as HB639 and SB503, has bipartisan sponsors in both chambers.
"I don't agree with them that they shouldn't wear a helmet, but I do agree about the civil liberty issue," said Sen. Jill Carter (D-Baltimore City), one of the bill's Senate co-sponsors.
"They are adamant as dedicated motorcyclists that this is not something they want mandated to them," she added.
In a recent hearing of the House Environment and Transportation Committee, opponents included highway safety groups, medical associations and public health officials. They argued that a weaker helmet law would increase motorcyclists' risk of injury and death, impose an avoidable burden on taxpayers and encumber the healthcare system.
"A lot of people might say, 'Well, it's my free will to do whatever I want to do, no matter how stupid it is,'" Gene Ransom, CEO of MedChi, the Maryland State Medical Society, said in an interview. "The problem is, when it comes to healthcare … your decision then ends up costing the entire system a whole lot of money.
"Not only is it the right thing to do and the smart thing to do — logical people wear helmets when they ride a motorcycle or a bike or other things — it also is appropriate from a common good and cost point of view," Ransom added.
The bill is scheduled for a hearing before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee later this week. Spanburgh hopes to see the measure make it out of committee and get a vote on the House or Senate floor. If unsuccessful, proponents vow they won't stop trying.
"If I don't do it, who else is going to do it?" said Ken Eaton, Maryland ABATE's executive director. "We try to get other people to help us as much as possible. But if I don't do it, how can I convince other people to do it?" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a state helmet law, its safety implications, and legislative efforts to change it, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Easton woman charged with placing swastikas on political signs
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton woman charged with placing swastikas on political signs

 May 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Friday, police charged an Easton woman for allegedly placing swastika stickers on political signs and town property ahead of Easton's recent election.Jennifer Cristaudo, 53, has been charged with 20 counts of using a hate symbol, three counts of malicious destruction of property and one count of defacing property in a race/religion crime. All counts are misdemeanors.
According to charging documents, Cristaudo allegedly placed six swastika stickers on political signs and 16 stickers with red lines through swastikas on town property, such as light poles and stop signs.
The six stickers placed on Gunsallus signs were all in "high-minority areas," according to charging documents prepared by Detective Cory Schuch.
"The placement of a hate symbol, such as a swastika on campaign signs in these areas is a clear indication that Cristaudo's motivation was to intimidate minority voters in the Town of Easton to not vote for Frank Gunsallus," charging documents stated.
Police say the placement of the stickers began in late March and continued through early May. The election was held May 6.
According to the Easton Police Department, on March 26, officers located three swastika stickers on Gunsallus signs. They reviewed surveillance video, which showed a woman driving a blue Subaru as the person placing the hate symbols.
On April 1, police discovered another defaced sign. April 28, officers found two more Gunsallus signs defaced near the Easton Amish Market.
Per charging documents, police later found 16 swastika stickers with red lines throughout town, with 10 reported on April 1 and 2, and six reported between April 30 and May 6.
According to court documents, a town official told police removing the stickers causes "permanent damage" to the signs, "rendering them unusable." The town's public works department estimated $21,000 in replacement costs.
In addition to video footage linking Cristaudo to the stickers, court documents state police found a "large roll of matching swastika stickers" in Cristaudo's residence.
Matching clothing and more stickers were found in her car, police said in charging documents.
During the campaign, Gunsallus and his then-opponent Don Abbatiello both spoke out against sign vandalism. Gunsallus told The Star Democrat in March that "these types of things shouldn't happen during a campaign."
"This act of hate has escalated the situation into a deeply troubling reality that demands our collective attention," Gunsallus wrote in a letter sent to The Star Democrat, local police and various local officials in March.
Rabbi Fred Scherlinder Dobb, interim rabbi for Temple B'Nai Israel and Satell Center for Jewish Life on the Eastern Shore, said he was "disappointed" but not "shocked" by the use of hate symbols.
"I would say Easton and Talbot County are mostly a wonderful refuge from some of that national division," he said. "But sadly, and maybe inevitably, pieces of that creep in."
Dobb said the placement of hate symbols is "utterly unacceptable" no matter the intent. "Full-on continental devastation and genocide — which is the ultimate Nazi legacy — needs to be reserved for issues far greater than Town Council," Dobb said.
Lt. Milton Orellana, special operations commander for the Easton Police Department, said Monday that the department had also received a report of a Ku Klux Klan hood being placed on a Gunsallus sign during the campaign. Police were not sure who was behind that incident.
Orellana said police are actively investigating both incidents. A preliminary hearing for Cristaudo is set for June 20.
Gunsallus declined to further comment on the situation, citing the ongoing investigation. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a hate‑motivated vandalism case involving police charges, making it primarily a public safety/crime story, with secondary relevance to race/diversity and local government.

title: Three graduate from Caroline County's Problem Solving Court
author: Tom McCall
content:
Three graduate from Caroline County's Problem Solving Court

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — In a celebratory event at the Circuit Court for Caroline County, Judge Heather Price presided over the May 10 graduation of three remarkable women.Through a yearlong Problem Solving Court program, they have taken a giant step forward to step out of the cycle of substance use disorder and incarceration.
"Being the problem solving court judge is sometimes a very difficult job, but it is also one of the most gratifying parts of the job. You will hear some success stories today," Price said.
The back row of the courtroom was packed with people supporting the graduates — Nichole Meredith, Samantha Mitchell and Carole Rawding. There were tearful testimonies to the power of this program. Love ones were showed the before and after pictures that marked the women's journey from the beginning of the program to the end.
Problem Solving Coordinator Michelle Bethke spoke to the journey these women have taken and she presented certificates and flowers.
Each graduate had a presenter. Meredith had lawyer Dana Boston, Mitchell had Whitely, and Rawding had Bethke.
There were lots of local dignitaries present, including Caroline County Commissioner Larry Porter, Sheriff Don Baker, Police Chief Geroge Bacorn and State's Attorney Sloan Franklin. Even Roger McKnight, MTU program administrator, was there.
From state to county to town, there was community supporting these women to break the cycle of addiction and incarceration.
"It is an achievement and we are sending our graduates back out into the world to do good things," Price said.
Price noted the rigor of the program. Collectively the three graduates had submitted 382 drug tests. They completed 313 treatments of either substance abuse disorder or mental health treatment. They had to complete 146.25 hours of community service.
Bethke went up to the podium and addressed the crowded court room.
"The Caroline County Problem Solving Court employs science-based best practices to provide a pathway to sobriety for participants with diagnosed substance use disorders utilizing a combination of therapy, counseling, mentoring, encouragement and discipline when necessary," Bethke said.
The program received a $200,000 grant from the Maryland Office of Problem Solving Courts through a sub grant of the Bureau of Justice Assistance, which helped provide the program's staffing.
A graduate from 2022's program, and keynote speaker at the May 10 graduation, is Whiteley.
"I am a recovering addict and alumni from the Problem Solving Court. The definition of recovery is the process of change for which individuals improve their health and wellness, live a self-directed life and strive," she said. "The mindset and thinking pattern I once had, I needed to give up in order to change. Today I am a strong worthy loving and lovable woman, mother and friend."
The next speaker was Meredith.
"My addiction had taken everything that I ever loved away from me. I lost custody of my kids. I lost the trust and respect of my family. When I looked into the mirror, I didn't even recognize the person staring back at me," Meredith said. "This program has saved my life. I have full custody of my kids now. My family and friends can depend on me."
The next to speak was Mitchell.
"Drug court has given me the resources I need when I need people," Mitchell said.
The final graduate, Rawding, was introduced by Bethke. Rawding was described as quiet and determined.
"I am just glad I accepted this program," Rawding said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Health is a secondary theme due to the focus on addiction treatment, and local government is relevant because county officials participated.

title: Talbot County Sheriff's Office to place cameras in patrol cars
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County Sheriff's Office to place cameras in patrol cars

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is planning to add cameras to its patrol vehicles, a move that Sheriff Joe Gamble said will increase transparency with the public.Earlier this month, Talbot County council members approved the purchase of 30 in-car cameras for $415,000, spread across a five-year period. Body-worn cameras have their limits, Gamble said, only showing the steering wheel during situations like police chases.
The sheriff said the in-car cameras have two main benefits.
"One, it's another level of transparency with the public," Gamble said. "And the other is evidence gathering."
But Gamble noted that a state investigation into a fatal police-involved chase last year factored into the decision.
"It definitely played a role in it," he said.
In July 2024, Talbot County deputies and an Easton police officer engaged in a pursuit of a vehicle on U.S. Route 50 in Easton after the driver failed to pull over for a traffic stop. Police reached speeds over 100 mph, and the chase ended with the vehicle crashing into a tree on Black Dog Alley. An 18-year-old passenger died.
The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Attorney General's Office reviewed the incident, as it does for all fatal police-involved chases statewide. Body-worn camera footage was eventually released in September. It wasn't until January when state investigators determined they wouldn't seek charges against any of the involved officers.
At the time, Gamble said it shouldn't have taken that long for the state to complete its investigation and clear his deputies. Now, the in-car cameras will better show the actions taken by vehicles being pursued by police, he argues.
"You couldn't see the egregious disregard for public safety by the driver in that car," Gamble said in an interview this week, referencing the limited view of the chase provided by body-worn cameras.
"It protects our deputies in the sense that, this is what they did," he added. "And if there's allegations they did something else, it's on footage."
Other sheriffs on the Eastern Shore concur with the effectiveness of the cameras.
Queen Anne's Sheriff Gary Hofmann said most patrol vehicles have had the in-car cameras for a few years. Complaints are down, and it's increased trust with the community, Hofmann says.
"It's been extremely beneficial for us to avoid any type of complaints or allegations," he said.
Dorchester Sheriff James Phillips said he would love for his agency to buy them, although cost is a problem — the in-car cameras are more expensive than body-worn ones.
In Caroline County, the vehicle cameras were purchased under a former sheriff, current Sheriff Donnie Baker noted. They are key in providing a better perspective for traffic stops and other incident, he said.
"I think that they make a good cop better," Baker said, "and they limit false reports."
Gamble said the Talbot County Sheriff's Office hopes to install all 30 in-car cameras by 2026. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the sheriff's office installing in‑car cameras to improve transparency and evidence gathering, which directly relates to public safety and law‑enforcement operations.

title: 4 plead guilty to varying misdemeanors in 2024 Kohl's incident
author: Konner Metz
content:
4 plead guilty to varying misdemeanors in 2024 Kohl's incident

 July 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Crime 
 
 410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Four people have pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges in connection to an incident in the Easton Kohl's parking lot last year.Raven Todd, 24, of Laurel, Delaware, entered a guilty plea on June 26 to reckless endangerment and loaded handgun in vehicle charges. The state is not prosecuting previously levied charges against Todd for attempted murder and assault.
Todd was the last of four people to enter pleas for an incident that occurred in April 2024. Three others accused of assaulting Todd during the incident — 21-year-old Tucker Eason, 19-year-old Blake Dorman and 18-year-old Navelie White — have pleaded guilty to assault charges. They were each handed sentences that they are currently serving.
The incident occurred in the parking lot of the Kohl's on April 16, 2024. The Easton Police Department said Todd fired a gun after an assault took place, according to a press release from when Todd was arrested in October 2024. Police spoke with a person whose truck had been hit by a bullet, allegedly from Todd's handgun.
According to police, Todd told them that while in the parking lot that day, Eason hit him on the head with a beer bottle. Another person had a tire iron, Todd told authorities. Todd also told police he was punched several times.
Detectives interviewed a witness who identified Eason, Dorman and White as the people who attacked Todd.
At the time, Easton police said video showed the attack during which Todd fired his gun after the assault ended with people fleeing the area.
On June 26, Judge Philip Cronan sentenced Todd to one year for reckless endangerment with the full term suspended, and two years for the handgun charge with all but 212 days suspended. Todd was credited with 212 days served dating back to last November. Cronan ordered Todd to serve two years on probation and perform community service, among other conditions.
White, of Easton, entered an Alford plea for first-degree assault on March 21. He was sentenced to eight years with all but 18 months suspended, dating back to January.
Eason, of Easton, pleaded guilty in December 2024 to second-degree assault and was sentenced to a three-year term with all but 18 months suspended. The 18 months date back to October 2024.
Dorman, of St. Michaels, pleaded guilty on June 4 to second-degree assault and rioting. A three-year sentence for the rioting was fully suspended. For the assault count, Cronan delivered a three-year sentence with all but 18 months suspended, dating to June 3. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police arrest man on charges in overdose
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Police arrest man on charges in overdose

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 239
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A Henderson man was arrested Tuesday on a grand jury indictment for manslaughter and narcotic distribution in connection to an overdose death last September.Detectives from the Easton Police Department announced the arrest of 35-year-old Justin A. Bodman, who is charged with manslaughter, distribution and possession with the intent to distribute narcotics, distribution and possession with intent to distribute fentanyl or heroin, possession of a controlled dangerous substance, reckless endangerment and conspiracy.Police also announced that Elina Lazarieva, 23, of Easton was arrested in Baltimore on Aug. 2 on similar charges.The charges stem from the duo's alleged involvement in an overdose death in Easton.Easton officers were dispatched to the 100 block of Prospect Avenue on Sept. 5, 2022, for an unresponsive man.Talbot County paramedics also responded and pronounced the man, identified as 28-year-old Cristian Gonzales, dead.Easton police's criminal investigation division initiated an investigation, learning that Lazarieva had met with Bodman for the purpose of obtaining controlled dangerous substances.Police said Lazarieva contacted Bodman and the two traveled to Delaware to obtain heroin.After obtaining the heroin, the two traveled back to Easton and delivered the drug to Gonzales, who later overdosed, police said.Both Bodman and Lazarieva were turned over to the Talbot County Detention Center following their arrests.Lazarieva was released on bond Sept. 12, according to online court records. Her case is scheduled for a jury trial in Talbot County Circuit Court in early January.

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
'End of Watch'

 February 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 786
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE— As evening fell, the American flag proudly waved high up between ladder trucks welcoming the community to come, honor, and remember their fallen heroes. A date remembered and honored by many in Queen Anne's County for the last 22 years the Fallen Heroes Memorial continues to be observed Feb. 13. Hosted by Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 108, the location has varied through the years but was held this year at the Centreville United Methodist Church.The event began with the Pledge of Allegiance and a moment of silence led by Sheriff Gary Hoffman. Senior Pastor Rev. Karen Handy of Centreville Methodist Church welcomed and addressed families, friends, and community members.
Chase Armington, past president of Lodge 108 and current Queen Anne's County deputy, began, "Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes. It is our duty to never forget them, for they have paved the path forward with their lives. The path leading us here tonight was born from tragedy. Incredible losses. Unbearable pain for our families, friends, and the community. These honored in front of you served our community with pride, dignity, and honor. Knowing their lives could, at any moment be taken, so that we may live. So that we may continue on the path they have now paved."
The event started from tragedy, continues years later as a way to honor and remember those who have unselfishly given their lives for others. Sue Nickerson, who lost her son, Centreville Police Officer Michael Nickerson, in 2001 explains, "The FOP from QAC started [this event] and they will always have it on February 13th, the night that Michael [Nickerson] and Jason [Schwenz, Queen Anne's County deputy] were killed. But, it's to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne's County."
Nickerson is the Maryland Concerns of Police Survivors (COPS) Director.
As a mother who lost her son, this event is near to her heart. Nickerson said, "It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters, and our EMTs have done. It is very much appreciated."
First responders marched in for the Presentation of Colors, holding flags to honor those lost in the line of duty. Queen Anne's County State's Attorney, Lance Richardson, spoke about stoicism and how it applies here. "The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us. We don't have any control over that. But what we do have control over is how we respond to it, how we react, how we pick up the pieces and go on. Stoicism also places an emphasis on appreciating the unity and precious gift of life."
Richardson went on to quote the Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius, "When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive — to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love." Applying this quote, Richardson said, "So, tonight, we honor those who gave the ultimate sacrifice, their lives, so we could go on living our lives in peace and safety." He ended by encouraging all to 'earn this.' "We must continue to honor these brothers and sisters, live a life that would be a testament to their memory, and continue to do God's will and God's work."
During this powerful remembrance, family members came, first responder representatives saluted, and all placed long-stemmed red roses by the framed photographs. The names of the fallen heroes were read along with the date of their End of Watch. Ten Queen Anne's County residents and fallen heroes' pictures filled the front table: Queen Anne's-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company's Daniel Lister, Sudlersville Volunteer Fire Company''s "Buck" Clough, Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department's "Dougie" Thomas, United Community Volunteer Fire Department''s David Brinkley, Centreville Police Department's Michael Nickerson, QA Sheriff's Deputy Jason Schwenz, DNR Warden Charles Rider, and Maryland State Police troopers Thomas Noyle, Philip Russ, and Wallace Mowbray.
Radio transmission echoed for all to hear to mark the ultimate sacrifice given on that fateful Feb. 13, 2001, "Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland. May their dedication and sacrifice never be forgotten and may they rest in eternal peace." Bagpipes played 'Amazing Grace' from the balcony overhead. Silence filled every space of the church.
Handy closed, "Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others. Lord, mend those hearts that are broken in the loss of these loved ones. Lord, we pray that this memorial tonight has brought a bit of peace. Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons. We thank you and pray for those that they have left behind." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community memorial honoring fallen police, fire, and EMS personnel, which is directly related to public safety and first‑responder activities.

title: ‘High-risk targets’: New normal at churches, houses of worship after deadly attacks
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
‘High-risk targets’: New normal at churches, houses of worship after deadly attacks

 October 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: News 
 
 1448
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Security at churches, synagogues and other houses of worship is being increased significantly after recent deadly attacks.Since late August, there has been fatal, targeted violence aimed at a Catholic school during mass in Minneapolis that killed two young kids, a Mormon church in Michigan and a Jewish synagogue in Manchester, England.
The assassination of conservative Christian influencer Charlie Kirk has also raised concerns about political and religiously motivated violence.
"Places of worship are meant to be sanctuaries of peacemaking, prayer and connection," said Doug Andersen, a spokesman for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints after a man shot up and burned down a church in Michigan in September, killing four.
There were 900 "acts of hostility" (including vandalism, arson and gun-related incidents) against U.S. churches in 2023 and 2024, according to the Family Research Council (an Evangelical Group).
Those are up significantly from previous years.
The Anti-Defamation League (ADL) has reported more than 27,000 antisemitic incidents in the U.S. since 2023, in the years after the Oct. 7, 2023 terror attacks and as Israel's two-year war in Gaza against Hamas has drawn significant international criticism.
That includes incidents on college campuses.
A new ADL survey of American Jews shows 55% say they experienced antisemitism over the past 12 months and 57% "believe that antisemitism is now a normal Jewish experience."
"All of the houses of worship should consider themselves to be high-risk targets at this point," said Dan Skoczylas, vice president of CLS Background Investigations and executive director of Hawkeye Active Shooter Response (both based in Illinois.)
He said that should prompt more religious groups to look more proactively at security, including engaging congregations and staff.
'VIGILANCE & SECURITY'
Police across the country have increased their presence and patrols at churches and other houses of worship as well as at higher profile events.
On Sept, 30 in Venice, Florida, police responded to threats against the Jewish Congregation of Venice and determined those to be a hoax or "swatting."
Those types of threats have been increasing nationally.
In nearby Lee County, the local sheriff's office "continues to maintain vigilance and security" at houses of worship after the Sept. 10 killing of Kirk and other attacks.
Kirk, an ally of President Donald Trump who was popular with Evangelical Christians and young conservatives, was shot by a sniper Sept. 10 during a rally at Utah Valley University
"We have hundreds of individual places of worship and religious centers within Lee County. Deputies are familiar with those in their patrol sectors and conduct frequent area checks — this is standard practice," said Julie Sin, public information officer for the Lee County Sheriff's Office.
Sin said deputies receive active shooter training and the agency deploys surveillance towers and increases patrols during religious holidays and large gatherings.
In Madison, Wisconsin, the First Congregationalist Church of Christ had an LGBTQ pride banner vandalized in June. In December 2024 a mass shooting at Abundant Life Christian School in Madison killed three (including the 15-year-old shooter who police said took her own life).
Another shooter targeted a Christian school in Nashville in 2023, killing three young children and three adults before being shot and killed by police.
Anthony Vogel, a spokesman for the Madison Police Department, said local law enforcement has "threat assessment" and "criminal intelligence" to investigate threats and disseminate those leads to officers on patrol.
"The Madison Police Department offers the option of hiring officers for Special Duty to provide police presence and security," Vogel said of options for religious and other groups putting on events.
But Cathal Walsh, vice president and chief security officer for Guidepost Solutions (a New York-based security firm) said increased police presence can be temporary, centered around holidays, weekly services or special events as well as after high-profile incidents or threats.
"The police presence is always temporary," Walsh said, noting law enforcement can't be at churches 24/7.
'VERY SERIOUSLY'
There have also been increased police and security footprints at Jewish synagogues during the recent High Holidays and the anniversary of Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks in Israel (which occurred on the Jewish holiday of Simchat Torah / the Feast of Tabernacles).
"We take security very seriously," said David Holtz, Temple administrator for Temple B'nai Israel in Easton, Maryland, citing "the considerable uptick of anti-Semitic threats violence."
That includes the killing of a couple who worked at the Israeli Embassy in Washington D.C. and the attack on elderly demonstrators at a rally for Oct. 7 hostages in Boulder, Colorado, earlier this year.
"We have a gate that requires a code or approved entry for access to our parking area. We have magnetic locks on both the exterior entrance vestibule doors and the interior doors to our temple's lobby," Holtz said. "We have security cameras throughout the interior and the exterior of the Temple. We have both off-duty sheriff's officers (armed and in uniform with marked vehicles) and private security personnel available for every service, Religious School or gathering event."
Holtz said for the Yom Kippur holiday on Oct. 2 guards were posted both inside and outside the Maryland synagogue "both as deterrent against any malicious actions and as peace of mind for our members and congregants."
'I'M GOING TO BURN IT DOWN'
The Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) has published a best practices guide for mosques and security.
Its recommendations include having a "vigilant" security / usher staff that can give early warnings to congregants, approach suspicious individuals before they enter the house of worship and do their best to keep erratic or violent behavior outside.
"Unknown males with bulky, camouflage, or combat-type clothing, for example, need to be approached and asked if they can be helped, Should the attacker engage persons outside the mosque, every effort must be made to keep the intruder from getting inside the mosque in order to minimize casualties," the CAIR guide reads.
Some of the vandals and shooters have some kind of animus towards a specific faith or church. Others hold some kind of personal grievance or grudge.
On Oct. 1, police in Dearborn Heights, Michigan received a threat from a man in Texas saying he would burn down a local mosque.
'I'm going to burn it down," the caller said, according to Michigan police.
'TARGET NO. 1'
Security experts are seeing houses of worship upping their security efforts via increased staffing, surveillance and physical barriers. Some religious venues are considering or have deployed metal detectors at entrances.
"Many houses of worship are increasing security presence in response to recent shootings, including posting off-duty law enforcement officers, trained volunteers, or professional armed security," said Gene Petrino, CEO of Survival Response LLC, a Florida-based security consulting firm.
"Some facilities are adjusting access points, adding fencing, controlled entrances, or security checkpoints," he said.
Others are adding surveillance cameras, motion detectors and alarm systems.
Skoczylas, a former law enforcement officer, said larger churches and dioceses have more resources and money than smaller congregations to have paid security guards or to buy security cameras and other equipment.
"They're not going to have the funds to hire a security force," Skoczylas said.
He said small churches and other groups can look at training volunteers.
Skoczylas said that can cost in the range of $1,500 for a security training versus hiring off-duty cops or security, which he said can regularly cost thousands of dollars.
He said the reality for security personnel (paid or volunteer) is to be armed.
"A security agent who is unarmed is nothing more than target number one," Skoczylas said.
That can run up against churches and other houses of worship wanting to be welcoming places.
"The goal is a visible deterrent while maintaining a welcoming environment," said Petrino, a former SWAT commander.
Walsh agrees it's a balancing act between security and feeling like a welcoming place.
Roman Catholic churches, for example, have long prided themselves on having sanctuaries open for those who want to come in and pray or meditate.
But Walsh said parishioners now will be concerned if they don't see some security, especially during holidays and big events.
"They kind of get a little bit worried," he said.
ASSESSMENTS & SOLUTIONS
Walsh suggests houses of worship look at entrances and exits and parking lots for vulnerabilities and how they fit into security plans and emergency responses.
He also said religious groups could look at having attendees register in advance for some events.
Walsh also said there are federal grants available through the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and U.S. Department of Homeland Security for nonprofits and religious venues to upgrade their security infrastructure.
"You might receive the funding to install more security cameras," Walsh said. "Those opportunities are out there."
Some houses of worship are looking at how much to advertise events on social media and are looking more at potential threatening individuals making menacing online comments.
That is also a balancing act with social media serving as a primary conduit for religious groups connecting with local communities.
"Social media is very touchy," Skoczylas said. "It's the conduit of all things good and bad." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Suspect arrested in Chester homicide
author: Staff Writer
content:
Suspect arrested in Chester homicide

 May 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Crime 
 
 196
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER — Police have made an arrest in a May 17 incident, now ruled a homicide. Few details surrounding the arrest are being released at this time due to the sensitive nature of the ongoing investigation, police said in their official statement.According to the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office, deputies responded to check on the welfare of a resident in Chester and discovered an alleged domestic-related homicide had occurred.
An immediate investigation began, and allied agencies were notified of a potential suspect. The individual was located in Virginia and taken into custody without incident, police said.
At this time, the victim's identity and suspect information are not being released, pending the investigation status.
Sheriff Gary Hofmann and State's Attorney Lance Richardson said, "We commend the deputies and allied agencies that assisted in this investigation, ensuring a quick apprehension in a tragic domestic related situation. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family as they deal with this tragedy and senseless act."
The investigation is ongoing. Further details will be released after the conclusion of the investigation, police said.
Anyone with information regarding this case is asked to call the Anonymous Tip Line at 410-758-6666 or the Sheriff's Office at 410-758-0770.

title: Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore

 August 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Flooding was prevalent as the remnants of Hurricane Debby hit the Eastern Shore Friday morning, with communities bracing for unusually high tides later that day."We've gotten a report on email from Emergency Management. It's been minor flooding so far," said Rescue Fire Company Chief Adam Pritchett Friday afternoon. "I believe the high tides are expected to be tonight of concern for Cambridge. But as of right now, it's been minor flooding so far."
The Town of Oxford warned residents that higher-than-expected tides could cause further flooding in the area Friday evening.
"Please be aware that the NOAA prediction for this evening's high tide has changed significantly and is now anticipated to be 4.5 feet, which could produce major flooding," the town said in an email to residents Friday afternoon. "By comparison, this morning's high tide that resulted in flooding throughout the town registered as a 3.9-foot tide at the Cambridge marker. With a 4.5-foot tide, the Causeway area will be impassable for a period of time."
Debby was downgraded to a tropical depression late Thursday afternoon, and was a post-tropical cyclone on Friday, the National Hurricane Center said. It made landfall early Monday on the Gulf Coast of Florida as a category 1 hurricane. Then, Debby made a second landfall early Thursday in South Carolina as a tropical storm.
Pritchett said his department was ready to help with any impacts from Friday evening's tides.
"We pretty much stay at a ready pace for things like this because it's becoming more normal all the time now with each storm that passes on," he said. "So we're kind of always ready for events like this. Have our equipment ready, checked out and so forth." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Eclipse Tips
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Eclipse Tips

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Travel 
 
 189
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The total solar eclipse on Monday, April 8, could be one of the most traveled days in U.S. history. The entire continental U.S. will be able to view the event with parts of 13 states from Texas to Maine able to see the moon completely block out the sun for 3 to 4 minutes.It will be the second largest total solar eclipse in the U.S. since 1806
All the travel, spending and social media activity could also cause some issues.
Destination Mansfield, an Ohio tourism group, has put together a list of eclipse tips in addition to wearing protective eclipse glasses.
Those tips include being prepared for overloaded internet networks, traffic congestion at popular viewing spots and having some cash in case payment networks are overwhelmed or disrupted. The group recommends filling up cars with gas and stocking up on food and other staple items just in case.
Many schools, especially in the eclipse path will also also be closed April 8.
Police, fire departments and hospitals could also see increased volumes.
There will be livestreams of the event broadcasted online by NASA (nasa.gov), the Exploratorium museum in San Francisco (www.exploratorium.edu/eclipse) and TimeandDate.com (https://www.timeanddate.com/eclipse/solar/2024-april-8). 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on safety-related advice for the upcoming eclipse, highlighting traffic congestion, overloaded networks, police, fire, and hospital preparedness, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic.

title: Queen Anne-Hilsboro firefighters honored for service
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Queen Anne-Hilsboro firefighters honored for service

 February 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE — The Queen Anne-Hillsboro Volunteer Fire Company awards banquet filled the fire hall on Feb. 10 with formal firefighter attire and fancy dresses.There were simmering meatballs as appetizers and flowers at every table as Fire Company President Phil Starkey Jr. emceed the evening. Around 100 people attended the affair to celebrate their firefighters' volunteer efforts.
Johnny Mautz, Maryland state senator, handed out years of service awards.
"You work hard all year. You get to celebrate one day, so I want to give you something back. We have years of service awards for U.S. Senate, Congress and the governor's office, from your state Senate office and your House of Delegates office," Mautz said.
He spoke on the value of emergency services to the community.
"The general public has no idea of the value and the service that is provided by all of our emergency volunteers. There are some paid paramedics. I get it. But it is a package deal, and we are so deeply grateful for this volunteer network. For everything you sacrifice, everything you give, all the time and your family commitments. I say it from the heart. Thank you for all you do," Mautz said.
Starkey recognized the adjacent fire companies, like Oxford, Greensboro, St. Michaels, Cordova and Easton, that respond to help fight fires in Queen Anne.
Then it was time for a litany of awards. There were membership awards, active service awards, fire awards, EMS awards, administrative awards, the President's Award and the installation of officers.
Awards from the chief included Firefighter of the Year Eric Voorhees and Officer of the Year Donnie Clark. There were two winners the Chief Award — Chris Kintop and Grady Motter.
The EMS awards included Chris Kintop, Tina Kintop, Eric Voorhees and Brandon Stiles. The Administrative Person of the Year is Dawn Starkey. The President's Award went to Nancy Baker, Jack Carson, Kenny Hope, Stephanie McNeal, Barbie Utz and Stacy Voorhees.
There were six top responders who were recognized: Donnie Clark, Kenny Hope, Chad Chaires, Eric Voorhees, William Townsend and the No. 1 responder was David Chaires.
At the end of the ceremony, Talbot County Council members Pete Lesher and Lynn Mielke presented the Queen Anne Hillsboro firehouse with a check for $37,088. Mielke said this was a third of their annual allotment.
Lesher said, "You serve three counties here, which is a big lift. It takes money to provide this protection, and Talbot County remains committed to paying for our part of what you do."
Before the tables were moved and the DJ could be brought in, there was a video highlighting all the fires the department responded to and emergency services that they provided throughout the year. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a volunteer fire company's awards banquet, highlighting emergency services, firefighter recognitions, and funding from county officials, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: EMS team coordination astonishing
author: Staff Writer
content:
EMS team coordination astonishing

 January 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 184
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thank God I live in Easton.The Monday evening of the snowstorm, I called 911 because my wife was experiencing a medical emergency. The 911 operator listened, gave me directions, kept me calm and told me that the medical team was on its way. Within 15 minutes of the call, the crew arrived. I call it a crew because at least two trucks from the Easton fire department accompanied the ambulance.
The fire department members shoveled the snow off the entrance to my house within a matter of minutes to give a safer passageway for the EMS crew. The EMS crew handled my wife's situation quickly and efficiently, moved her to the ambulance for transport to the emergency room. They kept apologizing for bringing snow into the house — the least of my concerns.
The entire team put themselves at risk to help us. The quickness of their response, especially considering the weather, was amazing. The coordination among the team was astonishing.
Again, I thank God for those who dedicate themselves to the well-being of our Easton community. By the way, my wife is doing OK.
BILL MOCARSKY
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes an emergency medical response and coordination between EMS and fire services during a snowstorm, which pertains primarily to public safety services.

title: Kayak group offers law enforcement, firefighters, vets a chance to relax
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Kayak group offers law enforcement, firefighters, vets a chance to relax

 June 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 734
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sure, dropping his fishing rod overboard while his son Shane fought to land a chain pickerel during the Heroes on the Water event Saturday at St. Mary's River State Park could have been an embarrassing moment, but Thornton Jackson was just planning ahead.Kayaks can be very temperamental when it comes to balance, so the Waldorf resident was just jettisoning weight in anticipation of the weight of the fish being added to the tandem kayak. Or that one excuse, anyways.
"I did do that," he said happily — and somewhat relieved — when it was suggested to him.
The event was held to allow first responders, law enforcement, firefighters and military veterans a chance to relax and and take a few casts if they so desired.
"It's not serious fishing. We're just out to have a good time, relaxing time on the water," said Maryland Chapter Coordinator Chris Vassallo, who spent 21 years as a senior chief in the U.S. Navy on submarines and recently retired following a career with the Office of Naval Intelligence. "You're maneuvering the kayak, you're using your fishing tackle to try and outsmart [the fish] and it takes your mind off everything else. It shuts that noise off and gives your brain some peace and for me that's what this is all about."
Thornton Jackson spent 13 years as a Yeoman in the U.S. Navy and was deployed "multiple times" and even missed the birth of Shane, "but it was also nice getting back and meeting him at the pier."
And Thornton Jackson certainly appreciated the father-son bonding time.
"It's definitely nice to get away from everything and just being out here spending time with him and just be a dad," said Jackson, who has worked in naval intelligence for the past two years. "Right now I'm here for a bit, but with deployments you never know when they're going to pop up. Just getting some time out on a Saturday and putting the work away to focus on him is great."
"It was fun to spend time with him," said 8-year-old Shane, who reeled in several fish. "I miss him a lot [when he's gone]."
Vassallo found out about the organization while listening to a podcast and attended an event in Montgomery County.
"That was something that I wanted, something that I wanted to establish here in Southern Maryland," he said. "To me this is what it's all about; having the camaraderie and being out on the water and enjoying the time on the water."
He co-coordinated two events and coordinated previous events this year in Laytonsville and Salisbury. The next event will be held July 26 at Mallows Bay in Charles County.
One of the volunteers at the event was Wayne Stinchcomb, a retired U.S. Army chaplain.
"Some of these guys are going through trials and tribulations for what they're going through. They're going through counseling. But when you do something like this it gets them back into real life," he said. "[They think] I can do this, I can be around my guys and I don't have to worry about something or what somebody might think because we're all going through it or been through it. One guy was here just to float in the sun. He didn't even take his pole out. He said the whole idea was to be and relax. If you've been in combat or anything you've been around, and you're around like-minded folks, there's an ease in that."
Mark Anderson of Kent Island drove about two hours to volunteer for the event.
"I didn't serve but I've shot [guns and rifles] competitively with a lot of people who are veterans," said Anderson, who is works in information technology and captured the event with his drone. "I just got to know a lot of them and really appreciate what they do for this country and the sacrifices they've made."
"I just love the military and fishing so that's how I figured I could at least give back," said Nathan Miller, who drove down from Westminster to assist at the event. "My friend brought me out once [to a Heroes on the Water event] and I've been hooked ever since. If there's an event and I know about it ahead of time, I'll figure out a way to help. It's good to see [them relax]. It's worth the drive."
For more information on how to participate or to volunteer at the Mallows Bay event on July 26, email maryland@heroesonthewater.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community event designed for law enforcement, firefighters, and veterans to relax and relieve stress, linking directly to first‑responder well‑being, which aligns best with the Public Safety category. Secondary relevance to Health (mental‑wellness) and Sports (recreational kayaking/fishing) is noted.

title: Federalsburg man arrested after fleeing police
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Adrian Jerrod Jenkins, 29, of Federalsburg—wanted by Cambridge Police for attempted murder and assault—was arrested Wednesday after fleeing Talbot County Sheriff's deputies. “Jenkins was charged with possession of a controlled substance, intent to distribute heroin/fentanyl, fleeing and eluding, driving without a license and other traffic violations,” the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office said in a news release.

The release said Jenkins was driving east on Ocean Gateway in the Trappe area when deputies attempted to stop him for moving violations. Police said deputies also determined Jenkins' vehicle registration was suspended. “Jenkins accelerated in an attempt to elude deputies,” the release stated. He led the pursuit into Dorchester County, where Talbot deputies were joined by Dorchester County Sheriff’s Office deputies.

“In Cambridge, Jenkins lost control of his vehicle, hitting a retaining wall and disabling his vehicle on Academy Street near Cedar Street,” police said. Upon arrest, “they discovered through a records check that he was wanted for attempted murder and assault stemming from charges in September of 2023,” and that “at the time of those charges, Jenkins was on probation for a second degree assault conviction in 2022.”

Jenkins was taken to the Talbot County Central Booking Center and “held pending further court action.” He is scheduled for a Talbot County hearing on traffic and drug charges and a later violation-of-probation hearing, followed by a June hearing in Dorchester County on the attempted murder charge.

title: Crash at Route 50, Black Dog Alley sends one to hospital

content:

Tim Larrimore reported that “one vehicle traveling on eastbound Route 50 ran the red light at the intersection, striking another vehicle coming onto the highway,” and added that “a Jeep Cherokee involved in the crash rolled over.”

Only the two drivers were involved; “one driver refused treatment at the scene, and the second was transported locally.” Eastbound Route 50 traffic was temporarily diverted onto Longwoods Road (Route 662).

title: Firefighters battle blaze at auto salvage yard in Cambridge
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Firefighters responded to a third-alarm fire at Threesome Auto Salvage on Cordtown Road in Cambridge around 11:45 a.m. Tuesday, according to a release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal.  

The blaze, ruled accidental, was “the result of dismantling a junk automobile,” the release said. No injuries were reported.  

The fire caused an estimated $80,000 in damage to a garage structure and $100,000 in contents damage. Brush task force units were called in “to help prevent the fire from spreading to surrounding woods,” according to Dorchester County emergency radio correspondences. Fire units from Talbot and Caroline counties assisted in the firefighting efforts.

title: Dorchester County may need to add to detention center
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Dorchester County may seek state funding to add a wing to its 34-year-old detention center after a surge in juvenile offenders left the facility unable to meet Maryland’s mandate that youths be housed separately by “vision and audio.” During Tuesday’s County Council meeting, Warden Don Satterfield told lawmakers, “Unfortunately, I’m going to be coming before you to add a wing (to the center). … We are already in violation of the law because of the audio part … and I don’t see it concluding. And they are, quite frankly, they’re a holy terror.”

Council members placed juvenile crime on their top-priority list for the upcoming General Assembly session. Councilmember Mike Detmer urged action, saying, “It’s absolutely insane that we have so many people that have had direct and directly affected by this, multiple people in this room directly affected by juvenile crime,” and added, “There are kids that are still kids on paper. They’re not acting like children.” Council President George Pfeffer noted the topic is “equally important to us,” while Councilmember Ricky Travers said the system is “setting up a whole group of young kids for failure.”

The county’s push mirrors regional concern: Caroline, Queen Anne’s and Kent counties are also exploring a jointly built facility. A March Cambridge police report found “the overwhelming suspect profiles for these crimes are male juveniles under the age of 16,” and Chief Justin Todd noted one 12-year-old has been arrested for vehicle theft 11 times in three years.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on rising juvenile crime and the need to expand a detention center, issues primarily related to public safety, though it is discussed in a county council setting.

title: Man charged with threatening to blow up Delaware mall
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
A 20-year-old Bear man, Devin Cunningham, was denied entry to the Christiana Mall at 7:45 p.m. Saturday for refusing to remove his ski mask, Delaware State Police said. After arguing with security, Cunningham allegedly made “threatening statements to them about returning to the mall with a bomb, blowing it up, and killing everyone inside,” according to police.

Cunningham fled before officers arrived but was located and arrested the next day. He was charged with terroristic threatening, wearing a disguise during the commission of a felony, and disorderly conduct, and was released on $2,000 unsecured bond.

title: Adams brings experience, potential K-9 to Greensboro Police Department
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Sgt. Jeff Adams chose the Greensboro Police Department as his next endeavor because of his great relationship with Police Chief Lenox Trams. "I was looking at different agencies but I reached out the chief. Chief and I go back to 2005 or 2006," Adams said. "I didn't know if I wanted to come here or not. We just had a brief conversation, then I came and did an interview and instantly fell in love. Ever since talking to him and doing a ride along, I was pretty much sold."

Adams, originally from New Jersey, came to the Eastern Shore in 2004 after careers in the Navy and Army Reserve. He began in law enforcement as an Easton Police Department dispatcher for one year, then spent the past 17 years with the Federalsburg Police Department. His decision to join Greensboro PD was also influenced by living in Greensboro. "I think the people here are very nice," Adams said. "They're genuine, and it just seem like a really good fit after we went for a ride along. Just the environment alone was was good enough."

Adams describes himself as approachable: "I'm easy going," Adams said. "So what you see is what you get. I think Chief can attest to that, but I'm just laid back, professional, polite and kind. Hopefully we'll be community-oriented. We're just trying to make our interactions are police-public friendly."

Adams brings his K-9 partner Mosley, who has been with him since 2017. Despite losing a leg to cancer in October 2023 and undergoing chemotherapy and radiation, Mosley continues to work. "She's done everything," Adams said. "She's already certified in tracking and narcotics. Now we took off the tracking because she lost her leg to cancer in Halloween of 2023... she's she's still working. She's did awesome with the training last Wednesday, she nailed it."

While Mosley hasn't officially joined the force yet, both Trams and Adams expect her to become part of the team soon. "We're really excited to be able to bring her on," Trams said. "We're going through our budget cycle, and we put the K-9 program in the budget so the Town Council has to approve it. Hopefully we'll get the thumps up and then she can start working because we need one."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police officer joining the Greensboro Police Department and the K‑9 program, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
The Talbot County Sheriff’s Office is investigating a new social-media threat that surfaced after a Friday post already deemed harmless to Easton schools. Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said Monday the latest image “is not a specific threat to Talbot County Public Schools, but to the 410 area code,” describing it as “a photo of a ‘clearly’ photoshopped Instagram message that includes the 410 area code.”

“We’re taking it very seriously, as we do every threat,” Gamble emphasized, while noting that investigators do not believe there is “any viable threat to the safety” of TCPS students. A district letter to families stated officials are “closely monitoring the situation” and that “school operations will continue as normal.”

A criminal investigation is underway, all school resource officers have been briefed, and extra deputies are patrolling campuses. The Friday incident that preceded this threat—placing students in modified lockdown—originated overseas and mirrored threats made to Easton, Pennsylvania schools. Gamble said other jurisdictions “have had 40 or 50 of these types of threats,” adding, “It’s happening all over our country where, for whatever reason, somebody is trying to disrupt school operations and put our kids in fear.”

He recalled a prior school year when “about half a dozen non-specific threats” were made and expects more this year, concluding, “This just seems like the thing to do these days for some reason.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a sheriff's office investigating a social‑media threat to schools, emphasizing safety measures and law‑enforcement response, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Sheriff Joe Gamble, Talbot County Sheriff's Office

title: Easton Man Gets 18 Years For Enticing Child For Sexual Activity
content:
An Easton man was sentenced Wednesday to 18 years in federal prison for attempted coercion and enticement of a minor to engage in illicit sexual activity. U.S. District Judge George L. Russell III handed down the prison term to Samuel Charles Hardeman, 55. His prison term will be followed by lifetime supervised release.

Hardeman had a previous federal conviction in a 2002 case in the Northern District of Georgia for use of a computer to entice a child to engage in sexual activity, for which he was sentenced to 174 months in prison. Upon his release from prison, Hardeman must continue to register as a sex offender in the places where he resides, where he is an employee and where he is a student, under the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act, per the judge's order.

According to the guilty plea, from Dec. 11, 2022, through Dec. 26, 2022, Hardeman engaged in conversations with an undercover law enforcement officer who purported to have a 10-year-old daughter. During the conversations, Hardeman expressed how he wanted to have sex with the 10-year-old, sent a video containing child pornography to the undercover officer and made plans to drive to New York, where the undercover officer purportedly lived, to have sex with the 10-year-old. Hardeman communicated with the undercover officer by phone via video call, text and through the use of encrypted messaging platforms. The Maryland U.S. Attorney's Office said the conversations occurred while Hardeman was on the sex offender registration for a previous federal sex offense conviction.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal sentencing for child sexual exploitation, involving law enforcement agencies and court actions, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Sewage truck crash closes eastbound U.S. Route 50
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
An 18-wheel sewage truck crashed through a guardrail on the right lane heading east on U.S. Route 50 near Hiner's Lane on Monday morning. The truck veered off the passenger lane, through the guard rail and slid over 100 yards into a wooded ravine, tearing through a front yard and leaving pieces of the guard rail and fragments of the truck.

Easton firefighters and State Patrol officers responded to the scene, along with a blue emergency response team truck from the Department of the Environment. According to an official on the scene, "at least no one died." The accident closed the eastbound lanes, with traffic detoured off Route 50 to Longwoods Road and reconnected near Easton Airport. There was no odor of sewage at the site.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a traffic accident involving a sewage truck and the resulting road closure, which is primarily a public safety issue.

title: Students warned of 'imposters' with offers of 'DoorDash-style' marijuana deliveries
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
A fraudulent marijuana operation is targeting University of Delaware students and Newark residents through illegal delivery offers, prompting an investigation by the Delaware Division of Alcohol & Tobacco Enforcement. The agency issued a public alert Thursday after receiving reports of flyers and business cards being distributed around Newark that falsely claim association with Fresh Cannabis, the licensed dispensary on Ogletown Road.

"The impostors are attempting to mislead potential customers into purchasing marijuana products illegally," said Jon Peterson, a spokesman for DATE. One advertisement features a cartoon marijuana leaf character holding a joint with the message "UDEL-iver? Yes we do!" targeting UD students. The ad promises "Quick delivery for on-campus students only! (DoorDash/Uber Eats Style!)" and includes the Fresh Cannabis logo along with an offer of free marijuana samples for students who sign up. Another ad displaying the Fresh Cannabis logo shows a menu and claims 24/7 delivery service.

Peterson emphasized that no licensed Delaware dispensary is authorized to deliver marijuana products. "Any business claiming to offer delivery services is operating illegally," he said. "Delaware's adult-use marijuana marketplace includes strict regulations and testing standards designed to ensure consumer safety. Products sold through illegal channels bypass these safeguards and may contain dangerous contaminants such as mold, pesticides or heavy metals." Despite Delaware's legalization of recreational marijuana, selling outside licensed dispensaries remains illegal.

Anyone with information about these fraudulent materials should contact Cpl. Tristin Burris at tristin.b.burris@delaware.gov. "DATE's Marijuana Enforcement Unit is actively investigating this matter and encourages anyone with information about these fraudulent materials to come forward," Peterson said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a law‑enforcement alert about fraudulent marijuana deliveries targeting students, emphasizing illegal activity and consumer protection, which aligns most closely with Public Safety.

Cpl. Tristin Burris, Delaware Division of Alcohol & Tobacco Enforcement
