title: Stevensville man charged with sexual solicitation of minor
author: Staff Writer
content:
Antonio Blaine Nicely, 20, of Stevensville, was arrested Tuesday, March 5, by the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office on charges of sexual solicitation of a minor and obscene telephone misuse. After an investigation involving "numerous interviews, multiple search warrants and suspect identification," an arrest warrant was secured by the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff Criminal Investigation Unit, according to a report from the sheriff's office. Deputy First Class Zane Doyle served the arrest warrant, and Nicely was later released on his own recognizance on Wednesday.

"This arrest underscores our unwavering commitment to protecting our community's most vulnerable," Sheriff Gary Hofmann said in a statement. "We commend the diligent efforts of our criminal investigation unit for their unwavering commitment and tireless work." Officials with the sheriff's office said the ongoing investigation does not allow the release of specifics surrounding the case at this time; however, parents are encouraged to "be always be mindful of their young children's device use." Anyone with information related to the case or wishing to report similar incidents involving the suspect should contact Detective Chase Armington at carmington@qac.org or call 410-758-0770, ext. 1938.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal arrest for sexual solicitation of a minor by a local sheriff's office, focusing on law enforcement and community protection, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Delaware woman killed when falling tree hits SUV during storm
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
A Delaware woman was killed and another person injured when a falling tree struck their SUV during a thunderstorm late Monday night. “The incident happened just after 10 p.m. Monday, June 30, in the westbound lane of Lancaster Pike, approaching the intersection of Hedgerow Place in Newark,” Delaware State Police reported.

According to investigators, “A severe thunderstorm knocked a tree down over the roadway as a Lexus RX SUV was passing by. The driver of the SUV swerved but couldn't avoid the tree, which hit the front of the vehicle.” The crash claimed the life of passenger Beverly Wolfe, 79, of Newark, who “died at the scene,” while the 79-year-old male driver from Newark was hospitalized with serious injuries.

State troopers continue to investigate; anyone who witnessed the incident is asked to contact Master Cpl. J. Forester at 302-365-8485.

title: State Supreme Court hears arguments on police stops for cell phone use while driving
author: Konner Metz
content:
The Maryland Supreme Court heard arguments Friday at Easton High School on whether police can stop drivers for cell-phone use “in a manner that is consistent with sending a text message or initiating a phone call.” The case, State of Maryland v. Michael Eugene Stone, asks the high court to overturn an appellate ruling that threw out controlled-dangerous-substance evidence found after Washington County officers stopped Stone in May 2023 when they saw him “manipulate a cell phone that was attached to his windshield.”

The Washington County Circuit Court had denied Stone’s motion to suppress, but in January the Appellate Court ruled “There is insufficient evidence in the record from which the trial court could properly conclude that the officers had reasonable suspicion to conduct a traffic stop.”

Assistant Attorney General Jillian Chieppor urged reversal, contending officers had reasonable suspicion because Stone pressed his phone in a way “consistent” with typing a text. She warned that “forcing officers to wait until the consequence occur goes against the law's purpose.” Justice Brynja Booth pushed back: “It seems like if we accept the state's position, any time somebody touches a cell phone device, that would constitute reasonable suspicion. Wouldn't we be casting a really wide scope?”

Public defender Douglas Nivens II countered, “This is a case about Mr. Stone … reaching up to touch the screen of his cell phone mounted on his dashboard,” adding, “One touch being the grounds for a traffic stop is a bridge too far.” Asked what officers would need for reasonable suspicion, Nivens said location of the phone and observation time matter because “We don't want officers just stopping people at random because they have a hunch.”

A decision is expected later.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a legal debate about police traffic stops for cell phone use, directly relating to public safety concerns about distracted driving and law enforcement practices.

people: Michael Eugene Stone, defendant
Jillian Chieppor, Assistant Attorney General
Douglas Nivens II, public defender
Justice Brynja Booth, Maryland Supreme Court
incident_type: Fourth Amendment challenge to traffic stop

title: Easton Elks Veterans Affairs Committee hosts a USO dance
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
On Saturday evening, Bridget O'Brien, 2024 Miss Maryland, opened the dance floor at Easton Elks Lodge by singing the "Star Spangled Banner." The Easton Elks 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee hosted the USO-themed benefit to raise funds for disabled veterans attending Pleasant Day Adult Day Care in Cambridge, with over a hundred people enjoying dancing, food, a silent auction and raffle.

Michael Feehley, chair of the 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee and lead planner, said, "We believe in taking care of veterans, the veterans that use services at Pleasant Day, whether it's just for two meals, whether it's for medications, whether it's to meet with medical people, whether it's transportation to their medical appointments, they're only funded for two days a week through (Veteran Affairs), we feel it's necessary to fund those guys for five days."

Easton High School's Navy Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps members assisted throughout the event, while Vietnam veteran and committee member Tom Carlson noted the broad appeal: "It wasn't just people in their 60s and 70s and 80s. There were a lot of people in their 20s and 30s, and they had a great time too. It's amazing that some of these youngsters really knew the music. They know our songs that we grew up with."

Feehley encouraged everyone to honor veterans daily: "When you see that Army hat or the Coast Guard bumper sticker on the back of a car, or anything that says, 'Hey, I was in the service,' say, 'Thank you for your service.' Because that veteran, the person who wears that hat, or the person who drives that car, they gave an awful lot of themselves. They took time away from their families, away from home, in some but not all cases, they put themselves in danger, so you and I can do what we do today, and who are we not to give back to those people."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community event organized to support disabled veterans, a group often associated with public safety and veteran affairs. While it involves local community involvement and fundraising, the primary focus on veteran support aligns best with the Public Safety category.

title: Easton airport runway closed for construction work
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
One of the runways at Easton Airport has been temporarily closed. As you drive by, you can see a large glowing X that alerts pilots not to land there. This is due to the construction phase of the Airport Modernization Program.

"Those are an added safety feature anytime we have the runway closed," said Micah Risher, airport manager. "Runway 4/22 is closed. The Xs are out there as a reminder for pilots from the air. They can see them very clearly flashing, and they know not to land on the runway."

The airport has gone to further lengths for extra layers of safety. "In addition, we have physically turned off the instrument landing system for Runway 4/22, so pilots cannot inadvertently receive the landing data," Risher said. "We have got some barricades out there. We have turned off other visual aids for that runway."

There is another runway in use while 4/22 is closed until April 9. "We have a second runway, 15/33, that is still operational," he said. 4/22 will be closed for a month, then will reopen for a month before being closed again for construction.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a runway closure and safety measures at a local airport, emphasizing public safety concerns rather than broader governmental or economic issues.

people: Micah Risher, airport manager

title: Officials emphasize firework safety ahead of July 4
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
With the Fourth of July approaching, Maryland safety officials are urging residents to follow strict precautions if they plan to use fireworks. Master Deputy State Fire Marshal Oliver Alkire advises residents to “go to public fireworks shows,” noting that any fireworks sold legally at local stands or retail stores “has been inspected.” For those determined to use fireworks themselves, Alkire cautions, “If you are going to be using any fireworks, just to keep in mind that you should only be purchasing and using fireworks that you are buying within your county or your area.”

Alkire emphasizes adult supervision: “If you're going to light fireworks, only allow the adults to light the fireworks, only light one firework at a time, and also keep all children and pets away from fireworks.” Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson adds that anyone handling fireworks at home should keep a water hose ready. For duds, Alkire instructs, “putting the fireworks in a bucket of water for 24 hours, then disposing of them properly.” The state fire marshal’s office warns against placing fireworks on the body, citing two Maryland deaths in 2023 from fireworks held to the chest or head. In emergencies, call 911.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on firework safety guidelines and advice from fire marshal and fire department officials, which directly pertains to public safety concerns.

people: Master Deputy State Fire Marshal Oliver Alkire
Chief J.R. Dobson, Easton Volunteer Fire Department

title: Dollar Tree in Denton Plaza small HVAC fire
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
At 9:06 a.m. on January 23, 2025, the HVAC system at the Dollar Tree in Denton Plaza caught fire. Firefighters arriving on scene “saw a light haze in the building,” the Denton Volunteer Fire Department reported.

The blaze caused “no structural damage to the building and there were no injuries,” the same department confirmed. The Dollar Tree closed for the remainder of the day and “could not be reached for comment.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a fire incident and the response of the volunteer fire department, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: Woman killed, two others injured in Preston crash
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
A 30-year-old woman was killed in a fatal crash that occurred in Preston on Tuesday, according to Maryland State Police. Police say just after 6:30 p.m. Tuesday, officers responded to a crash involving two vehicles at the intersection of Harmony Road and Grove Road. One vehicle, a Ford, was heading south on Harmony Road when the other vehicle, a Chevrolet, did not stop at the intersection and struck the Ford.

The driver of the first vehicle, identified as Courtney Dunn of Salisbury, was pronounced dead at the scene. The driver of the second vehicle and a 16-year-old passenger were flown to TidalHealth Peninsula Regional in Salisbury and the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore for treatment.

According to police, Harmony Road was closed for around three hours for an investigation. The crash investigation is still ongoing and is being led by the Maryland State Police Crash Team. Police said the investigation's findings will be sent to the Caroline County State's Attorney Office to determine if charges will be filed. Anyone with information may contact the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack at 410-822-3101.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a fatal traffic crash and police investigation, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: Easton woman charged with assault of correctional officer
author: Konner Metz
content:
Latoia Handy, 35, of Easton was charged with second-degree assault for biting Cpl. Michelle Armstrong at the Talbot County Detention Center on Jan. 11.  
According to the statement of charges, Armstrong wrote that “Handy had hit her (own) head against several walls in several different areas” after stating she had mental health problems, prompting officers to place her in a restraint chair.  
Armstrong added, “I was putting her left wrist in the restraint strap when she bit me on my right inner forearm.”  
Handy’s trial in Talbot County District Court is scheduled for March 3.

title: Community block party brings resources and fun together
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
CHESTER — A community block party held at the United Methodist Church in Chester on Aug. 2 brought together citizens, law enforcement, faith-based organizations, county agencies, civic groups, neighborhood organizations, and businesses “to address prevention issues.” Sponsored by CSAFE (the Collaborative Supervision and Focused Enforcement Group) and partners including the Queen Anne’s County Department of Health Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services, Citizens Against Smoking Tobacco Coalition, the Office of the Sheriff and the Wellness Coalition, the annual event “promotes police-community partnerships to make neighborhoods safer.”

Long-time organizer Dorine Fassett said, “I love to see people come out and support each other,” noting that “community festivals are excellent ways for neighbors to learn more about the resources and organizations surrounding them in a casual, fun environment.” Alongside music, food vendors and giveaways, participants included the Queen Anne’s County Sheriff’s Department, the County Health Department, and the Maryland Army National Guard. While National Night Out is traditionally held the first Tuesday in August, Fassett explained that holding the party “on the first Friday prior … giv[es] the community more events to attend and more opportunities to get out and meet their neighbors.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community block party that highlights police-community partnerships, prevention initiatives, and involvement of the sheriff's office and health department, making public safety the most fitting category.

title: Ridgely police force saga is far from over
author: Konner Metz
content:
Nearly 18 months after Ridgely commissioners suspended and then laid off every officer and employee, the defunct Ridgely Police Department is back in the headlines: seven former personnel—ex-chief Jeff Eckrich, six former officers, and a former employee—have filed a federal lawsuit accusing town officials and Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker of orchestrating a “coup” to wipe out the agency.  

The suit claims that “Baker and former Ridgely officer James Joles devised a plan that would eliminate the RPD and allow the Sheriff’s Office” to assume policing duties under the current coverage contract. Joles, who resigned in 2024 and supplied documents that sparked a state misconduct probe against Eckrich, told The Star Democrat on Wednesday that he denies the lawsuit’s allegations.

title: Water main break shuts down Washington, Harrison streets intersection

content:
A water main break in front of the Easton Utilities building shut down the intersection of North Washington and North Harrison streets early Thursday. The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services first announced the closure of North Washington Street “around 3 a.m. Thursday morning,” then expanded the closure so that “the intersection of North Washington and North Harrison streets was completely closed” by 7 a.m.

Crews worked along North Washington Street throughout the day to repair the break and redirect traffic. An Easton Utilities spokesperson said crews made repairs “with as minimal impact to customers as possible,” and the utility confirmed the road reopened “around 7 p.m.” after work was completed.

title: Trial Begins For Cambridge Man Charged In Fatal Shooting
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub.Com
content:
Jury selection began Tuesday for Tramelle Williams, 23, charged with first- and second-degree murder, armed robbery and gun crimes in the Dec. 8, 2022, fatal shooting of 24-year-old Taijay Brian Daniels on Pleasant Street in Cambridge just after 7 p.m. Dorchester County State’s Attorney Amanda Leonard, prosecuting with Senior Assistant State’s Attorney Ella Disharoon, told jurors Daniels “was just a normal 24-year-old” walking home in a Space Jam jacket and “had no idea he was about to be killed ‘execution-style.’” She said Williams, masked, shot Daniels in the back and then “shot again, striking Daniels in the head twice before taking Daniels’ belongings and leaving.” A passer-by found the victim facedown within minutes, but CPR by police and EMS failed and Daniels was pronounced dead at the scene; the medical examiner ruled the death a homicide by multiple gunshot wounds, two “rapidly fatal.” “He didn’t stand a chance,” Leonard said, adding Williams didn’t count on surveillance cameras capturing the shooting, on police arresting him still wearing the same backpack, or on officers finding Daniels’ phone in his pocket. Williams was arrested the next evening after a foot pursuit on Lincoln Terrace during which an officer shot him in the leg.

Defense attorneys Michelle Moodispaw and Stephanie DeLang countered that the video and forensic evidence have “limited value” and urged jurors to consider what isn’t being shown, arguing prosecutors offered only “maybes and possibilities.” By Tuesday evening seven witnesses—including Daniels’ mother, police officers, crime-scene technicians and the medical examiner—had testified; more law-enforcement and forensic witnesses are expected Wednesday, with a verdict anticipated Friday. Williams also faces a separate January trial for the Dec. 8, 2022, 10 p.m. fatal shooting of 69-year-old Lory Eugene Fields in the 700 block of High Street, roughly three hours after Daniels was killed.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal trial and homicide investigation, which falls under public safety concerns rather than sports, education, or other categories.

title: ‘Cutting edge’: Talbot County first responders create mental health peer program
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
EASTON — Talbot County first responders have launched Talbot FiRST!, a collaborative peer-support initiative uniting the Department of Emergency Services, 911 dispatch, Sheriff’s Office, Corrections, Easton Police and Easton Volunteer Fire Department to tackle mental-health stigma. EMS Division Chief Tina Kintop said the program lets any first responder “come from the bottom up, meaning that they will know who all the peer (team members) are … They will be able to contact who they want to contact,” bypassing the chain of command for help.

County Manager Clay Stamp praised the effort during the Oct. 22 council meeting, noting, “The things that we expose our 18-year-old kids to — that become EMTs or dispatchers or police officers — are horrendous. We have got to come up with a better way to arm these individuals to deal with these things in a healthy manner and to give them a support system. And right here in Talbot County, out of the 23 counties and Baltimore City, they've stepped up, and they're making it happen first.” Former EMS Chief Matt Watkins added, “Talbot County should be extremely proud of the fact that we're on the cutting edge of this.”

After more than a year of planning and a “rigorous” four-day training led by ex-NYPD detective Jeff Thompson, a second training phase will enlarge the peer team and expand outreach. For All Seasons CEO Beth Anne Dorman said a $30,000 Rural Maryland Council grant funded the clinical training. Council President Chuck Callahan, recalling his own 18-year-old firefighter days, told first responders, “You kind of feel like you're out there alone sometimes, and you need to talk to somebody … As long as we're up here, you guys are never ever going to get forgotten, because you're our heroes in Talbot County, and we love you guys and you protect us.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a new peer‑support mental‑health program created by county emergency services, police, fire, and corrections agencies to aid first responders. While mental health ties to Health, the primary focus is on a safety‑agency initiative, making Public Safety the best fit.

title: Delaware cocoa processing plant damaged by fire again
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
A two-alarm fire “damaged a cocoa processing plant near Glasgow Oct. 12,” the latest in a string of blazes at the facility. The fire at United Cocoa Processors in the Pencader Corporate Center off Del. 896 was reported “shortly before 11 p.m.” and “firefighters arrived to find fire coming from the building.” Crews had “the flames … knocked down in approximately 40 minutes, and the situation was declared under control shortly after midnight.”

The response involved “firefighters from 10 local fire departments as well as New Castle County paramedics,” and “no one was injured.” The state fire marshal is investigating the cause.

Saturday’s incident “is at least the fifth fire there since 2015,” including blazes in “November 2023,” when “two employees had to be rescued from the roof of the burning factory,” as well as fires in “July of that year,” “March 2021,” and “February 2015.” In 2020, “the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration fined the company $53,000 for five safety violations, including exposing workers to slip and fall hazards, failing to maintain proper egress routes out of the roasting room and having machinery with rotating parts that were not fully enclosed or sufficiently guarded.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on a fire incident, emergency response, and safety investigations, which fit the Public Safety category, though it also involves a business facility.

title: School bus crash sends 11 to hospital
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Eleven patients were transported to the hospital after a Kia Sportage failed to stop at a stop sign at the four-way intersection of Matthewstown Road and Three Bridge Branch Road just before 8 a.m. Monday and crashed into the side of a Caroline County school bus, causing the bus to roll over.

According to a statement from Caroline County Public Schools, the bus was transporting high school students involved in the Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps program to Easton High School. Nine students and the bus driver were transported to area hospitals, and all parents of children on the bus were notified. The juvenile driver of the Kia Sportage, whose identity is being withheld by police, was also transported to an area hospital for treatment of injuries. In an email sent to parents Monday morning, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the driver was an Easton High School student.

Police said the cause of the crash is under investigation and charges may be filed. Fog blanketed the area, though neither school system issued a fog delay. Troopers from the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack, Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division and crash team responded, along with deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Caroline County Sheriff's Office. All lanes on Matthewstown Road at Three Bridge Branch Road were closed for several hours; they closed off Route 328 at Black Dog Alley and at Councell Road, allowing only parents of the students and emergency services through.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a traffic accident involving a school bus and injuries, which is primarily a public safety incident, though it also involves a school district.

title: Trappe Volunteer Fire Company seeks funding for firehouse
author: Lily Tierney
content:
The Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, housed in a station built in 1951 and never updated, is campaigning for a $6 million replacement. “We probably have the oldest one in the county,” Assistant Secretary Treasurer Cheryl Lewis said, explaining that the current building cannot accommodate modern apparatus. Because Trappe relies on volunteers, “projects like this rely heavily on government and local support,” Lewis noted.

The department had secured a line item in the recently approved federal budget, but it was later removed. “We’ve been in the process of trying to get assistance,” Lewis said. “In the last budget year … we had successfully worked with Andy Harris’s office to be included in the budget. But with the cuts that were done early on this year, it was removed.” Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st) said the appropriations bill failed “due to negotiations in Congress leading to a continued delay,” though the project has been resubmitted. “We hope the appropriations process has a better outcome, but then that’s not up to us because it involves the minority party as well,” Harris said.

To qualify for federal aid the company must raise 25 percent of the cost—$1.5 million—and has already banked $450,000. Their next fundraiser is the annual fair, July 31–Aug. 2 at the firehouse, 6–10 p.m. daily, featuring rides, food, games, and Saturday’s parade. Harris stressed that final funding hinges on bipartisan agreement: “In the end, this is going to depend on the minority party. And you know, if they’re not willing to negotiate in good faith, that could end up being a problem. The people in Trappe have to know that their member of Congress was working hard to get that money to the fire company.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a volunteer fire company's need for funding and infrastructure upgrades, which directly relates to public safety services. It also mentions government funding processes, making Local Government a secondary relevance.

title: JONES NAMED EMS COORDINATOR
content:
Caroline County’s Department of Emergency Services has a new Emergency Management Safety Coordinator: Mark Jones, introduced by DES Director Mark Sheridan at the county commission meeting on Sept. 19. Jones brings more than 35 years of emergency management work from Wicomico County and has also served recently as a volunteer firefighter in Accomack County, Virginia.

“So he’s been there, he’s done it,” Sheridan said. “And he’s hit the ground running right in the middle of our hazard mitigation plan update. He’s getting acclimated, and I think he’ll be an asset to the county and to DES.”

title: SMITH BECOMES GREENSBORO's NEWEST POLICE OFFICER
content:
Jacob Smith was sworn in as Greensboro’s newest police officer Monday, Nov. 13, by Mayor David Spencer, according to the town. Smith had just completed the comparative compliance training through the Maryland Police Training Commission on Friday, Nov. 10.

Acting Greensboro Police Department Chief Lt. Lenox Trams, who welcomed Smith during the ceremony, will now oversee Smith’s next phase: 160 hours of field training. Smith previously served as a police officer in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

title: Kyleigh remembered - Community rallies around family of girl killed in Christmas morning fire
author: Carl Hamilton; cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
ELKTON — Tom and Nancy Minor stood in front of the charred remains of 317 Willow Drive and remembered 10-year-old Kyleigh Nicole Treadway, who died in a Christmas-morning fire. “Kyleigh was so sweet. She was a most vivacious girl, always smiling. She loved to give hugs and loved animals. She loved our cats and always asked about them whenever she saw us,” Nancy, 67, said. Tom, 66, added, “Nothing seemed to faze her. Kyleigh always seemed to be upbeat, like nothing was impossible.” Nancy recalled their last encounter: “It was right before school was out for Christmas break. She was telling me about all of her animals… She said, ‘I love you’ and hugged her grandmom. Then she hugged me, too, and said, ‘I love you’,” prompting Tom to observe, “I don’t think she encountered anyone she didn’t love.”

Singerly Volunteer Fire Company and others responded about 7:30 a.m. to the blaze, Master Deputy State Fire Marshal Oliver J. Alkire reported. “Upon arrival, firefighters found the family standing outside their home, stating a young girl was still inside. Firefighters heroically entered the home and located the child. However, she was later pronounced deceased on the scene,” Alkire said, adding, “Investigators later learned that after family discovered the fire, they made several attempts to save Kyleigh during the fast-moving fire; however, they were unable to due to thick smoke and intense heat.” The medical examiner ruled Kyleigh’s death “thermal injuries and smoke inhalation.” Alkire stressed, “While the fire remains under investigation, they have not recovered evidence that it was an intentionally set fire, nor do they believe or suspect that this was an intentionally set fire, and continue to explore all possible accidental causes.”

The blaze displaced 17 residents, including Kyleigh’s five surviving relatives, and most of the family’s pets perished. The American Red Cross is assisting all displaced residents. Community tributes appeared at the scene; Rising Sun resident Kathi, who did not know the family, said, “I did not know Kyleigh and I do not know her family, but I just wanted to come here today.”

Coworker Theresa Retz launched a GoFundMe on Tuesday with Kyleigh’s mother Theresa Moats’ permission. “We work together, but we are also good friends,” Retz said, recalling, “I only met Kyleigh a couple of times. But I can say Kyleigh made everyone smile. Her personality brightened a room, and she was the life of the party.” Retz related Moats’ first message after the fire: “She messaged me from a friend’s Facebook account because her laptop had burned up along with everything else inside the house. She told me her house burned down and Kyleigh did not make it.” Retz sensed Moats was “emotionally discombobulated,” explaining, “She wanted to know how to get up with the (Terumo) supervisor to let the company know that her badge and scrubs burned in the fire. That’s how I knew her head was nowhere in the right place. I let her know that it’s OK and don’t worry about that right now.” After meeting at the Red Cross-arranged hotel, Retz said, “There was a lot of crying.” By Thursday the fundraiser had raised $17,414; Retz noted, “People have been awesome. In addition to (monetary) donations, there has been an avalanche of donated clothing.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a residential fire, the fire department response, investigation, and community safety concerns, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Multiple crashes at Easton intersection lead to resident concerns
author: Konner Metz
content:
Three February crashes at the intersection of Brookletts Avenue and South Aurora Street in Easton have alarmed residents, especially because only 13 crashes had been logged there in the previous 11 years, according to the Easton Police Department, which attributed all three recent incidents to driver error. "You stand out here for about five, ten minutes, you'll see how fast people go," Ruffini said. "It's insane. They don't care, and they're always in a hurry."

Lydia Pinkney, who lives nearby, said she fears for her 9-year-old daughter and her dog after a car once careened into her yard and neighbors’ parked cars have repeatedly been struck. "The speed limit's 25, and I know people are going more than 25," she said. "Our kids play out here. And what worries me about everything is if … someone's not paying attention or whatnot, them running the red light or just going way too fast and clipping me and my daughter."

Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh confirmed engineers have adjusted the traffic-light timing to reduce red-light running and are reviewing further safety tweaks. "While this location is being monitored, officers have begun targeted traffic enforcement and will continue to do so at different hours of the day," the department wrote.

Broader Brookletts Avenue safety efforts this month included converting two nearby intersections to four-way stops and adding on-street parking lines. "The white lines give the drivers cues as to where they're supposed to be in the travel lanes," Van Emburgh said. "Because one of the things that we struggle with is when you have a road that can accommodate on-street parking, but no one's actually parking on it, it looks like a wide-open raceway."

Residents are split on the pending 123-unit redevelopment of the former Perdue AgriBusiness site. "I have seen so many near accidents at the intersections, particularly Hanson and Brookletts," neighbor Lisa Stone said. " … I think that's a good improvement." She added, "Hopefully it will just be an increase in traffic and not a decrease in safety," while Ruffini warned, South Aurora Street "will be a main road before you know it."

title: Trial begins for Cambridge man accused of murder, kidnapping of woman
author: Konner Metz
content:
Jury trial opened Tuesday for Kenneth Bradley, 43, charged with first- and second-degree murder and kidnapping in the Feb. 7, 2024 disappearance and presumed death of 31-year-old Tiyavauna Britt at Gerry Boyle Park at Great Marsh in Cambridge. Prosecutors asked the jury for first-degree murder and kidnapping convictions, while defense counsel urged not-guilty verdicts on those counts, arguing second-degree murder or manslaughter fit the facts.

Dorchester County State’s Attorney Amanda Leonard told jurors the case is full of “rage, control, domestic violence,” saying evidence shows Britt’s relationship with Bradley was “toxic.” Leonard promised testimony from Bradley’s former employer and a close friend to whom, she said, Bradley confessed to the murder and disposing of Britt’s body. “She vanished,” Leonard said. “She was never seen or heard from again. No phone calls or text messages.” Jurors will see park video whose audio is “chilling,” Leonard said, showing Bradley drag Britt and throw her in the trunk of a car.

Public defender Matt Connell acknowledged, “We are fine acknowledging that that was him in the video,” but objected that Bradley could have a “reasonable expectation” for privacy during some conversations, noting “90% of the verbal communication occurred inside the vehicle.” Judge William Jones indicated it’s “quite likely” the full recording will be admitted. In his opening, Connell conceded, “He lost it. He hit her too hard, and she died,” adding Bradley tried to resuscitate Britt. “He didn’t mean to do it.” Connell urged, “Hold him responsible for what he’s really guilty of, not above and beyond that.”

Thirteen witnesses testified, including Britt’s mother, Linda Harris, who recalled Feb. 12, 2024: “She wouldn’t miss anything.” Trial continues through Friday.

title: Ridgley commissioners vote to continue MOU with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
RIDGELY — The Ridgely commissioners voted unanimously Monday to continue the town’s memorandum of understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office. Commissioner Brad Sears, who backed the motion, said, “I think at this point we’re to a point where we would entertain a motion to give the town authorization to meet with the county to negotiate any changes to the MOU and go from there,” adding that he still intends to negotiate details with the Sheriff’s Office.

The town has relied on the Sheriff’s Office since suspending its entire police department in March 2024 during a state investigation. On July 25, 2024, the Office of the State Prosecutor reported no “sufficient evidence of criminal activity warranting further investigation or prosecution,” but the Ridgely officers had already been laid off.

At last month’s meeting commissioners weighed three options. Sears recalled, “I know last month we talked about three options, one completely going back to the sheriff’s department regular patrol pattern. Second was to attempt to re-establish an original police force, and even that price was conservatively estimated at $852,000 for the first year if we could find the police officer.” The third option—continuing the MOU—carries a fiscal-year 2026 cost of $493,415.

Caroline County Sheriff Donald Baker urged adoption, stating, “The sheriff’s office is providing what is going to be a high quality of law enforcement in the town. The town going with the MOU with the sheriff’s office, they get everything the sheriff’s office has to provide as far as criminal investigations handled by a investigator or detective, as well as the sheriff’s office is a member of the Caroline County Drug Task Force and we have two deputies assigned to that.”

Addressing resident questions about the $493,415 allocation, Baker clarified, “There was some confusion that this money is dumped right into the Sheriff’s Office budget. That’s not true. The county is billing the town based upon the usage. So, if we don’t use something or there’s money left over, the county does not bill it and it goes back to the town or the town keeps it and it’s never filled.” Commissioner John Hurley was absent for the unanimous vote.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a town commission's decision regarding law enforcement services and funding, which directly pertains to public safety matters, while also involving local government actions.

Sheriff Donald Baker, Caroline County Sheriff's Office

title: Juveniles injured after chase ends with car hitting house
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Three juveniles were injured—one critically—after a stolen Kia Optima slammed into an Owings home shortly before 6 p.m. Sunday, Sept. 14. Deputies had been alerted that the car, reported stolen out of Prince George’s County, was entering Calvert County on Route 260. Deputy Justin MacWilliams spotted it, and investigators reported the driver “accelerated at a high rate of speed, passing vehicles on the shoulder and operating recklessly.”

A pursuit began eastbound on Route 260, turned west onto Mt. Harmony Road, and continued despite stop-stick deployment. The sheriff’s office said the driver even “swerved the vehicle toward officers.” The chase ended when the Kia failed to negotiate a turn near Alyssa Way, struck a telephone pole, crossed a yard, and “ultimately crashed into a residence.”

Three of the four juveniles inside were hurt; the driver was air-lifted in critical condition, while two passengers were taken by ambulance with non-life-threatening injuries. A fourth occupant fled on foot but was caught uninjured after deputies, K9 units, and drones set a perimeter. No names will be released under state law. The Office of the Attorney General’s Independent Investigations Division declined to investigate; the Sheriff’s Office Crash Reconstruction Unit now leads the case. Witnesses are asked to e-mail Deputy Jeffrey Hardesty at Jeffrey.Hardesty@calvertcountymd.gov and reference case 25-76666.

title: Hoarding turned deadly: Mother takes plea deal in Christmas Day 2023 fire that killed her daughter
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Theresa Ann Moats, 41, entered an Alford plea to involuntary manslaughter on Jan. 24 in Cecil County Circuit Court for the Christmas Day 2023 fire that killed her 10-year-old daughter, Kyleigh Nicole Treadway. “In an Alford plea, the defendant maintains his or her innocence but, at the same time, he or she does not dispute the incriminating evidence possessed by the state.” Prosecutors agreed to drop 11 related charges; Moats faces up to 10 years in prison and will be sentenced after four months of house arrest.

The fire began shortly before 7:30 a.m. at 317 Willow Dr. near Elkton. Kyleigh, asleep in a second-floor bedroom, was trapped while her mother, grandmother, two brothers and mother’s boyfriend Kevin Neal Summerfield escaped. “As firefighters battled the blaze, Moats alerted Capt. William Ryan of Singerly Volunteer Fire Company that ‘her baby was right inside the front door.’” Crews could not reach her because of “the magnitude and intensity of the fire.” Kyleigh died of smoke inhalation and burns over 90 percent of her body.

Assistant State’s Attorney Gavin Patashnick detailed that “an overload situation” existed after extension cords were chained inside an 8’-by-8’ first-floor addition “to bypass non-functioning outlets.” A freezer, refrigerator and backyard grill drew power the system could not handle, while “strewn clothing, trash and other combustible debris — including a coating of animal feces left by numerous pet dogs and cats — covered the electrical cords.” Court records show Moats admitted keeping “as many as 35 pets” inside the 1,100-square-foot townhouse. “An extensive amount of hoarding conditions… increased the magnitude and intensity of the fire,” Patashnick said, and no smoke detectors were present.

Five days earlier, animal-services officers impounded 14 dogs and four cats, “planned to make a report to Child Protective Services, as the children in the home were subjected to poor living conditions.” Cecil Manor Elementary staff reported Kyleigh arrived reeking of animal waste; the nurse washed her clothes and hair “3-4 times per day,” replacing backpacks cats had soiled. “Absolutely no involvement to address concern brought forth by the school” came from Moats, records state. After the fire Moats told investigators, “this all could have been preventable,” that she “felt bad and felt it was her fault,” and that she missed Kyleigh.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fatal house fire, hoarding conditions, and a criminal plea for involuntary manslaughter, all of which pertain to safety hazards and law enforcement response, fitting the Public Safety category.

title: Few show for police town hall meeting
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Only five Cambridge residents came to the police department’s town-hall meeting Oct. 3 at the Empowerment Center, where officials outlined community-policing plans and crime trends. “All I ask of you, is that you take this tonight and make sure that the information—whether it’s good information or bad, if you agree or disagree—and you put it out there to the public that we, the police department, want to work with our community to better the situation out on the street,” Police Chief Justin Todd told the sparse audience.

Capt. Shane Hinson said the entire 39-officer force—up from 29 when Todd took over—now practices community-oriented policing after specialized training. “It’s all of our jobs to go out and make meaningful connections with the community,” Hinson said. Capt. Antoine Patton added, “If you look on the news, it would have you to believe sometimes that police officers are only there when bad things happen. But we want our community to know that we love them, and we’re here to work together.” He announced plans for a “12 Days of Christmas” shopping program Dec. 12-24 and a repeat Thanksgiving dinner for youth and seniors, noting, “In five to 10 years these children will be teenagers and these teenagers will remember the things that we did.”

Todd reported that officers have seized 114 illegal guns since 2019 and that homicides dropped from last year’s record seven to two so far in 2023. “I don’t call that success by any means,” he said. “The day we have zero is the day we’ve been successful. [[---]] But it’s progress.” He warned that juvenile crime is worsening: “Out of the 300-and-some assaults that we’ve had this year, 127 have been committed by juveniles,” and blamed the 2022 juvenile-justice reform that bars charges for children under 13. “And the juveniles know it,” Todd said. “We have 12-year-old kids telling us, ‘What are you going to do to me?’” A new city curfew took effect Oct. 1; Todd said, “But at the end of the day, if we can help one child or one family, one parent to better parent their child, and get them out of the streets, then we’ve done something right as a community and it’s a start.”

The department is recruiting to reach 43 officers by December and to diversify a workforce that is 67.5 % white, 22.5 % Black, and 5 % each Hispanic and Asian. “We want to mirror our community,” Todd said. “But I just want the public to know we’re working hard to get there.” Resident Gary Gordy, one of the five attendees, said Cambridge needs more officers and surveillance cameras, adding, “We wait for years to get things done.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police department town hall meeting, discussing community policing, crime statistics, and public safety initiatives, which directly aligns with the Public Safety topic.

title: Police investigating 'sabotage' of Greensboro's water system
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
GREENSBORO — The Town of Greensboro announced Monday that it found “deliberate sabotage” of its water system after residents reported higher-than-normal chlorine levels over the weekend.  
“After examining the tower wells, it was discovered that one of the chlorine regulators had been tampered with,” the town stated, adding that the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office has opened a criminal investigation.

The issue surfaced Saturday when the public works department asked contractor Susquehanna Operational Services to test the water. Resident Jose Miranda said “the smell is still really strong,” noting no discoloration but an obvious chlorine odor.  
Weekend readings peaked at 2.2 milligrams per liter—well above the typical 0.56 mg/L—before dropping to 1.0 mg/L on Monday; EPA standards flag levels above 4.0 mg/L as potentially harmful. A July 19 boil-water advisory had already been issued, and despite Sunday’s Facebook assurance that “the water is safe to drink and within Maryland Department of the Environment regulations,” multiple residents still reported noticeable chlorine taste and smell.

Resident Chris Mason said the water quality issue has been recurring in the last few weeks, adding that poor drinking water will especially effect those without refrigerator filters and mothers who need it for baby formula.  
Town Manager Tammy Kelledes said the town changed its locks to prevent further tampering with the regulators. Residents can request water testing at 410-482-6222 or greensboro@greensboromd.com; tips on the sabotage can be reported to the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office at 410-479-2515.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a criminal investigation into sabotage of the town's water system, focusing on safety risks to residents, which aligns most closely with Public Safety.

title: Cambridge police investigating two weekend shootings
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The Cambridge Police Department is investigating two weekend shootings, according to a department press release. “On Saturday just after 4:30 a.m., police responded to reports of shots fired on Pine Street,” the release states. Officers followed a blood trail to a 19-year-old Easton man inside a Moores Avenue residence; he had been shot in the leg and was transported to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The department says “the victim was at a bar in Easton and was then given a ride to Cambridge.” The victim told police he “heard approximately five gunshots” and reported seeing a “black style SUV” in the area, though police are unsure if that vehicle was involved.

The second incident occurred “on Sunday night just after 9 p.m.” when officers responded to shots fired at the 1000 block of Pine Street. Police located shell casings at the intersection of Pine Street and North Drive but “have not located any victims.”

The Cambridge Police Department is requesting community assistance for both shootings; anyone with information can anonymously call 410-228-3333.

title: Tuesday night storm was loud, but damage was minimal
author: Staff Writer
content:
Tuesday night’s storm rolled through Easton with hours of lightning, thunder and driving rain that swamped yards and streets. While most damage was limited to downed limbs, “a bolt of lightning hit the church and started a fire” at Faith Chapel United Methodist Church near Trappe. Trappe firefighters quickly responded and doused the flames, and the state fire marshal’s office set the loss at $25,000.

The Rev. Gary Moore said the damage is “very, very significant” for the small church, which dates to the 1880s. “I was there last night,” Moore told Star Democrat reporter Konner Metz on Wednesday. “Assessing the building will be a difficult decision as we move into the future.”

title: Motorists encouraged to watch for deer as breeding season approaches
author: Tom McCall
content:
EASTON — With deer breeding season beginning in October and running through mid-December, motorists are being warned to watch for white tails on the road. TJ Jefferson of Grants Automotive in Easton says his shop sees a clear spike: “It is about 20% to 30% more this time of year. I get more calls early in the morning, ‘Can you come get my car? I just struck a deer or a deer just struck me.’” State Farm data show U.S. drivers filed an estimated 1.8 million animal-collision claims from July 2022 to June 2023, with about 1.5 million deer-car accidents annually causing more than $1 billion in insured losses; Maryland drivers face a 1-in-116 risk.

Trooper Ian Rola of the Easton Barracks explained the seasonal surge: “The incidents that rise this time of year are car accidents. (Deer) are in rut and are running all over and crossing the roadway. It is usually up this time of year — in the November time frame.” To keep roads clear, “It is between law enforcement and SHA. We try to keep the roads clear. We rely on the public. If you see a carcass, give us a call, and we will come out. If it is a mess, we call SHA (State Highway Administration) to help,” Rola said, urging drivers to slow down and buckle up: “You have got to imagine, you hit a deer, you slam on the brakes and you are going forward at the same time. The seat belt will stop that forward momentum. This saves a lot of injuries from deer accidents.”

State Highway Administration representative Charlie Gischlar cautioned against evasive swerves: “Making sudden, sharp turns is dangerous as it could place the driver in the path of oncoming traffic or cause your vehicle to strike a fixed object such as a tree or utility pole.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on road safety warnings, police and highway agency actions, and driver precautions during deer breeding season, which aligns best with Public Safety.

Trooper Ian Rola, Easton Barracks, Maryland State Police
Charlie Gischlar, Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration

title: Easton firefighters respond to blaze on Glebe Road
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Firefighters from the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, St. Michaels Fire Department, and Cordova Volunteer Firemen’s Association responded to a blaze at 366 Glebe Rd. in Easton late Tuesday afternoon after “smoke could be seen from a house … around 5 p.m.”  

“No injuries were reported, according to first responders at the scene,” while “the road was closed to traffic by more than 10 emergency response vehicles.” Crews remained on-site at 5:30 p.m., “tending to the upper-story of the residential building.”

title: Game called, police investigating assault
author: Staff Writer
content:
CENTREVILLE — The Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff is actively investigating an assault that took place this evening on a Queen Anne's County High School basketball player during the state quarter final championship between Carver Vocational-Technical High School and QACHS at Queen Anne's County High School. A representative for the Sheriff's Office confirmed they had obtained and are currently reviewing video surveillance footage as part of ongoing efforts, and the Sheriff's Office is encouraging anyone who may have witnessed the alleged assault or has any additional video footage to contact the investigating deputy.

No arrests have been made at this time, and one player sustained minor injuries and refused treatment at the scene. In an effort to ensure the accuracy and integrity of the ongoing investigation, the Sheriff's Office is requesting speculation and rumors regarding suspect information from the community be withheld.

"We understand the concerns within the community and assure you that we are committed to conducting a comprehensive investigation and ensuring a safe place in our schools as we work with school officials to bring a conclusion to this investigation," Public Information Officer Kaitlyn Briselli said on behalf of the department.

"Our players, teams, community, and school staff deserve a safe environment, we have a zero tolerance for this type of behavior at our public events, and we can assure our community that this investigation will be thoroughly completed, and appropriate charges will be done at the conclusion," added Sheriff Gary Hofmann.

Anyone with additional information or video footage regarding this assault is urged to contact Deputy Rhyheem Johnson at rjohnson@qac.org or to call 410-758-0770 ext. 1945. Information can also be submitted anonymously through the Queen Anne's Sheriff app or by calling the anonymous tip line at 410-758-6666.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a police investigation of an assault that occurred at a high school basketball game, emphasizing community safety and law enforcement response, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Maryland police officer retires at 40 years of service
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Dennis Wood retired Thursday from the North East Police Department after 46 years in Maryland law enforcement. "Forty-six years, all I ever wanted to do was serve the people of Cecil County and the people of North East, and I think I did that to the best of my ability," Wood said during the ceremony in front of the station on Cecil Avenue. After walking between two rows of saluting officers, Wood slid into a patrol car and radioed, "I'm off duty — and retired."

Cecil County Executive Adam Streight, who had retired from the Sheriff's Office less than two months earlier, presented Wood with a county proclamation. Streight noted, "There is no other job like police work. It is who you are." Wood traced his own calling to childhood: "Ever since I was a kid, I wanted to be a police officer. That's all I ever wanted to be. I wanted to be able to help people."

Wood, 40-year veteran corporal and firearms instructor, spent 25 years with North East PD and over 20 with the Cecil County Sheriff's Office. "You could count on Cpl. Wood to take extra shifts and to do whatever needed to be done. He also was great as a community liaison for the department, working with the homeowners associations," said NEPD Chief Stephen Yates. A dispatcher closed the radio tribute with, "We thank Cpl. Wood's wife, Lou, and his family for sharing him with us for 46 years. Cpl. Wood, thank you for all you have done to make Cecil County a better place . . . Enjoy your camping trips and cutting firewood."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the retirement of a long‑time police officer and details his service in local law‑enforcement agencies, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Oxford man with loaded gun charged with assault
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
An Oxford man is facing multiple charges after allegedly pointing a loaded shotgun at someone following an argument. Robert McWilliams, 63, is charged with first-and second-degree assault, using a firearm in a crime of violence, reckless endangerment and intoxicated endangerment in connection to a Sunday, Aug. 6, incident.

Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the 100 block of Third Street in Oxford just after 10 p.m. that day for a reported assault in progress. According to charging documents, the caller, a family member, said McWilliams had a shotgun and had threatened to shoot him. The threat followed an argument between the two men at a local restaurant earlier that evening.

After leaving the restaurant with the rest of his family, the man said they walked to McWilliams' house and knocked on his door. The man told police McWilliams came to the door armed with a shotgun, pointed it at him and said that, if the man entered the home, he would shoot him.

Police who spoke with McWilliams at the home said they could smell the odor of alcohol on his breath and on him. McWilliams told police that he left the restaurant after the argument and returned home. When he heard the man knock at the door, he armed himself with the shotgun and went downstairs to answer. McWilliams also told police he did not point the shotgun at the man and that he felt "threatened" by something the man said earlier in the evening.

Police recovered the shotgun, identified as a Remington 870 20-gauge. The gun was found with one live shot shell in the chamber with the safety off, police wrote in charging documents. McWilliams appeared in the county district court Aug.7 for a bail review. He was ordered to remain held without bond. A preliminary hearing in the case is scheduled for Aug.28.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal incident involving assault, a loaded firearm, and police response, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Robert McWilliams, 63, of Oxford

title: UPDATE: Fire marshal investigating arson attempt at Ridgely business
author: Konner Metz
content:
RIDGELY — Four trucks at SunnySide Energy on West Belle Road were doused with gasoline in an attempted arson early Monday, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.

Owner Bryan Saathoff said a driver alerted him around 3 a.m. that fuel was running out of a truck door. “The seats were soaked, they had gas running out of the floor,” Saathoff said. “Then the very last one, we could tell when we open it, it had burned.” Estimated damages stand at $100,000.

Surveillance footage shows two people—one inside the fence and another in a vehicle outside—during the incident. The fire marshal’s Upper Eastern Regional Office is investigating; tipsters can call 410-819-3500.

SunnySide Energy is offering a $1,000 reward for information leading to an arrest. “The loads that were lined up for the trucks, we have to get them back and you have lost revenue,” Saathoff said. “But we still got the same expenses.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports an arson attempt and the fire marshal's investigation, focusing on crime, safety hazards, and emergency response, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Video of presumed ICE arrest sparks confusion, fear in Cambridge
author: Lily Tierney
content:
A Facebook video showing federal agents in ski masks and bulletproof vests arresting four men on Maryland Avenue in Cambridge on June 4 has ignited fear in local immigrant communities. “You know, it’s definitely something we knew was coming, but we didn’t know it was gonna be handled this way,” said Julie Martinez, who recorded and uploaded the footage around 7:15 a.m. after seeing four unmarked cars surround a work truck. “As you can see in the video, they didn’t even give them time at all to even explain or say why you’re getting pulled over,” Martinez said. “It was very quick, so when I saw it, my first thing was ‘oh my gosh, there’s no way this is happening.’” Agents’ vests only said “Police,” and the Department of Homeland Security has not responded to inquiries; Cambridge police and the Dorchester County sheriff said they had no prior knowledge.  

Immigration attorney Matthew Famiglietti, who has practiced for more than 25 years, said the legal landscape has shifted rapidly under the Trump administration: “Talking about what’s legal and what’s not legal, that’s changed quite a bit since Trump.” ICE arrests are up 25 % since inauguration day, driven by five executive orders that ended safe-space protections for churches, courts, hospitals and schools. Famiglietti urged families searching for detained relatives to “call their senators and representatives for information. That’s the No. 1 thing.”  

Nationwide “No King Day” protests against the administration’s immigration policies are scheduled for June 14, with demonstrations planned in both Easton and Cambridge. Martinez advised immigrants to “Drive at the speed limit. Do everything you’re supposed to be doing,” adding, “You know we contribute to this country a lot, and unfortunately, we can’t stay home. We can’t do much but to keep going forward, but definitely stay more on the low.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on ICE arrests, law‑enforcement actions, and community fear, which are central to public safety concerns. While it references national immigration policy and impacts immigrant communities, the primary angle is the safety and policing aspect.

title: CASA of the Mid-Shore is thankful for dedicated volunteers
author: Casa Of The Mid Shore
content:
CASA of the Mid-Shore, a private, nonprofit organization, advocates for children under the protection of the Talbot, Dorchester, Queen Anne's or Kent Circuit Courts because of abuse, neglect or abandonment to ensure the children's right to thrive in safe, permanent homes. A CASA volunteer's role is unique. As a caring and consistent adult, CASA volunteers attempt to identify the specific needs of each child, advocate in court and with agency partners for services to meet those needs and assist in seeking a permanent resolution for each child's life as quickly and safely as possible.

Most importantly, the CASA gets to know their appointed children, often becoming one of the most consistent adults in children's lives. This is especially poignant during the holiday season, when all children need to know that someone cares and is looking out for them. For many children, the holidays are a time for building happy memories with family. However, holidays can be very difficult for children who have been removed from their homes and placed in foster care. Rather than enjoying the magic of the season, these children may be adjusting to new foster homes and transitioning to new schools. That can be a heavy burden, and CASA volunteers can help by being present for the children.

CASA's involvement can lead to children's hope for a better tomorrow. Studies support the fact that children and youth with CASA volunteers have higher levels of hope than foster children who do not have CASA in their lives. Greater hope can lead to children being more likely to succeed in school, having greater self-control, increased optimism and a healthier sense of well-being. "Speaking up for children is our proverbial North Star. It guides us in the certainty that a better future is a real possibility for each child we serve," said Robin Davenport, CASA's executive director. "As we enter the holiday season, we are filled with gratitude for our CASA volunteers. Their compassionate dedication to vulnerable children is a treasure in our service region."

CASA volunteers come from all walks of life, varied experiences and professions, and are at least 21 years of age. After completing the application and screening process, individuals participate in pre-service training before being sworn in as an officer of the court. CASA welcomes volunteers from all cultures, ethnicities and backgrounds. To learn more about becoming a Court Appointed Special Advocate, visit casamidshore.org or email jc@casamidshore.org.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on CASA volunteers advocating for children in the court system to protect them from abuse, neglect, and abandonment, which aligns most closely with child protection and public safety concerns.

people: Robin Davenport, executive director, CASA of the Mid-Shore

title: Vehicle break-in cases move to Talbot County Circuit Court
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Criminal cases for two Talbot County teens have moved to the Talbot County Circuit Court from the Talbot County District Court. Nihjay Greene, 18, of Trappe, and Aamad Turner, 19, of Easton, were charged at the end of 2024 for their alleged involvement in multiple vehicle break-ins and thefts that occurred at the end of December in the La Trappe Heights community in Trappe.

On Monday, the state entered nolle prosequi for all of Greene and Turner's charges in the district court. "This means the state will not prosecute for those charges." In an interview Monday, Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said the charges against Greene and Turner will be recharged in the Talbot County Circuit Court. Coale said this process is standard practice for more complex district court cases that move to the circuit court.

The charges stem from an incident on Dec. 30 where deputies responded to a report of an attempted vehicle break-in in the 3800 block of Seymour Drive in Trappe. According to a Jan. 3 news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, deputies determined after further investigation that "three men wearing all black clothing and masks attempted to enter multiple vehicles, stealing various items." Police said the same day, deputies were dispatched to Harrison Circle in Trappe, where a resident noticed three men dressed in black clothing and wearing masks looking into vehicles.

Police said the three men barricaded themselves in a residence in the 3900 block of Main Street and after a short time, deputies were able to make contact with them. Police identified the three men as Greene, Turner and a 16-year-old boy, who was not named by the sheriff's office. The Sheriff's Office said Greene attempted to resist arrest and assaulted a deputy as he was being detained. According to the news release, deputies found evidence during the investigation that also connected the three teens to vehicle break-ins that occurred in Easton earlier in 2024.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on criminal charges, police investigations, and court proceedings, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

Joseph Coale, Talbot County State's Attorney

content: Cambridge police arrested a 15-year-old after the teen allegedly shot his stepfather in the face Friday, according to a police news release. “Just after 11:30 a.m., Cambridge Police responded to the 400 block of Skinners Court regarding a shooting at a residence,” the release said. Officers found a male victim with a gunshot wound to the face; he was flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma for his injuries. “The police department said a more detailed press release will be forthcoming with further details.”

title: Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home
author: Konner Metz
content:
Daniel Fuentes Espinal, pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015, returned home to Easton Friday after nearly a month in ICE custody. His daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, flew to Louisiana last week to bring him home, according to family friend Len Foxwell’s Facebook post. “It was an emotional time for me — to see him after almost a month of not seeing him,” Diaz told The Baltimore Banner.

Espinal was arrested the morning of July 21 while heading to his construction job, taken first to ICE’s Salisbury field office, then to Baltimore for three nights, and finally to a Louisiana detention center. He was granted bond Tuesday, family told The Baltimore Banner. ICE stated Espinal, an Honduran national, “entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years,” calling it “a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa.” Espinal, in the country since 2001 with no criminal record, according to his family, had his arrest spark regional outcry and weekly Easton protests.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on an ICE arrest and detention, which are law‑enforcement and immigration‑related matters, fitting the Public Safety category. It also mentions actions by the Easton Town Council, giving relevance to Local Government, and the case attracted broader attention, touching on National News.

title: Lawmakers battle between cracking down and easing up on prison sentences
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Maryland lawmakers are clashing over two competing prison-reform bills this session. The Maryland Second Look Act, sponsored by Democrat Del. Cheryl Pasteur of Baltimore County, would let people who have served at least 20 years petition courts for sentence reductions if they show sustained good behavior. "They have done every single thing possible to be better folks, better than a lot of the folks that I work with here," Pasteur said, adding, "When do we ever have to spend 20 years to be vetted? Never."

Republican Sen. William Folden of Frederick County is pushing the opposite approach with his Real Time for Violent Crimes bill, which would bar or limit diminution credits for violent offenders. "If you commit a violent crime and you prey on our communities, and you're that two percenters that are the worst of the worst, then you should get real time and not allow it to be watered down through dim credits and things of that," Folden said. Kurt Wolfgang, executive director of the Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center, called the measure "long overdue," arguing, "There are so many ways to already diminish a sentence in Maryland. This is just one more hole in the bucket that needs to be plugged up by taking away or diminishing the use of diminution credits to release violent offenders."

Both proposals drew emotional testimony in February and March hearings. Theresa Darvish, whose son was murdered in 2021, opposed retroactive sentence review: "My son will never return to his home. No murderer should be given a free ride home." She labeled the Second Look procedures "rampant and ambiguous at best."

Supporters countered with stories of transformation. Anthony Muhummad, released under the Juvenile Restoration Act after 29 years on two homicide charges, testified, "There are dozens of individuals who are still incarcerated throughout the Maryland prison system who have served 20, 30, 40 and yes, sometimes even 50 years of incarceration who are not juveniles, who have demonstrated their maturity and rehabilitation and we believe are worthy of a second opportunity." Pasteur, a former city school educator who counts two formerly incarcerated students among her "very favorite," said, "It's about appreciating and recognizing that some folks under the most horrific circumstances have made themselves better. Much better than a whole lot of us on any given day."

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses state lawmakers debating legislation on prison sentencing and criminal justice reforms, which directly relates to public safety issues.

Sen. William Folden, Republican representing Frederick County
Kurt Wolfgang, executive director of the Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center
Theresa Darvish, mother of 2021 murder victim
Anthony Muhummad, formerly incarcerated individual

title: Drivers need patience on roadways
author: Staff Writer
content:
A 70-year driver from Easton, Joel S. Strobeck, writes in The Star Democrat that he has “finally reached my frustration point in what I (correctly or incorrectly) perceive as unwarranted impatience, if not absolute rudeness and discourtesy, on the part of drivers in Talbot County.” Strobeck, who describes himself as “a competent, not perfect, operator of a motor vehicle,” says younger motorists honk, tailgate, pass on the right or even cross double-yellow lines when he takes “a needed extra second or two to double check” before turning, entering an intersection, or pulling away from a light.

“An absolutely unneeded honking horn is startling and rather than achieving its likely objective of hurrying me along … actually slows me down,” he warns, adding, “You will be senior drivers someday yourself, and you will understand certain facts — namely your reaction time slows a touch, your hearing and vision … are not what they used to be.”

Strobeck cites heavy traffic, narrow streets with double parking, oversize pickups and SUVs, and “dangerous intersections lacking traffic controls — one of these is one I use daily, the intersection of the Parkway and Tristan Drive” — as reasons older motorists need “that extra moment of time to cope safely.” He closes with a plea: “I can cope if I get just a minimum amount of cooperation from all of you others on the road.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses driver behavior, road safety concerns, and the need for patience and cooperation on public roadways, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: JOEL S. STROBECK, senior driver, Easton
places: Parkway and Tristan Drive intersection, Easton

title: Easton police seek permits for future protests
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey told the Town Council Monday that, although Saturday’s No Kings protest on Dover Road “remained civil,” the department wants the town to require public-assembly permits for future demonstrations.  
“As with any big event, my concern with police coverage is the unexpected, the person who does not appreciate that (protest),” Lowrey said. “We’ve seen it all across our country. It’s a little frustrating when these events are not going through the public assembly event process, to allow us to plan.”

The rally—one of thousands nationwide against the Trump administration—drew an estimated 800-1,200 people and coincided with an 11:30 a.m.–5 p.m. mass-casualty training exercise at Temple B’nai Israel.  
“We were able to respond to a call here or there, but if something happened, at that point, it comes at the expense of all the other citizens in the town because we have no officers available to respond to other emergencies,” Lowrey said, noting the patrol division was “essentially wiped out.”

Town code already mandates permits for “any open air public meeting, rally, conference, assembly or similar gathering,” but Lowrey said the wording should be clarified so protests like No Kings—neither Saturday’s nor June’s obtained permits—must apply. Permits cost $100 plus added fees if extra police or equipment are required; police review and the council approves.

Talbot County Democratic Central Committee Chair Phil Jackson, whose group co-organized the rally, said local planners are willing to comply.  
“We are very interested in ensuring that these events comply with local policy,” Jackson said. “Should the Town of Easton move forward with changes to their public gathering permits, we will look to comply with those and follow the process.”

Lowrey stressed the goal is preparedness, not cost: the department usually covers events with on-duty officers at no charge.  
“But when you have 800 to 1,200 people lining streets and stuff, things can go wrong very quickly,” he warned. “And that’s always my biggest fear. It takes a car driving through 30 people, and we have a mass casualty, actually, incident, and not an exercise.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on police concerns, crowd control, and emergency preparedness related to a protest, which are core public safety issues, while also involving town council decisions about permits.

people: Chief Alan Lowrey, Easton Police Department
Phil Jackson, Chair, Talbot County Democratic Central Committee

title: Woman faces neglect charges after officers rescue toddler
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Sheena N. Hutchins, 40, was arrested at her Dill Court home in Elkton on Aug. 24 after officers discovered her unresponsive 18-month-old child lying on an upstairs bedroom floor around 6:40 p.m., police said.

"The home was in a state overwhelming filth and decay, showing severe signs of neglect, with surfaces covered in grime, clutter everywhere, and foul odors filling the air. The child was likewise soiled in dirt, feces, urine, fleas and lice, in addition to untreated rashes," an EPD spokesperson outlined.

Cecil County paramedics and Child Protective Services agents responded, transporting the child to Christiana Care Union Hospital in Elkton, where the child is expected to recover, according to police. Hutchins was charged with neglect of a minor and reckless endangerment and released on a $3,000 unsecured bond.

"The investigation is far from over and the child has been removed from his mother's care while this investigation continues," the spokesperson said, adding, "We thank our partners with the Cecil County Department of Emergency Services, Child Protective Services and Christiana Care Union Hospital for their response and assistance in the rescue and treatment of this child."

Anyone with information is asked to email EPD Det. J. Beamer at jbeamer@elktonpd.org.

title: Farmers, residents raise safety concerns regarding potential Route 662 closure
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
As site preparation begins for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health’s new regional medical center in Easton, a stretch of Route 662 (Longwoods Road) is slated for temporary closure from Oct. 1 to May 1 while the hospital—construction starting spring 2025 and finishing summer 2028—is built. Greg Gannon, co-operator of C.H. Gannon & Sons on Longwoods Road, said the shutdown will “represent an inconvenience at some level” to all users, warning that “moving large farm equipment and construction equipment these days is dangerous.”

Shore Regional Health said in a statement: “The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health is committed to advancing the health of Mid-Shore residents and the new Regional Medical Center project is one of the most significant developments in the history of Talbot and its surrounding counties. We recognize that building a state-of-the-art hospital to replace an aging and outdated facility may cause inconveniences and have worked tirelessly with state, county and city officials to ensure interruptions to daily activities are minimized. The necessary decision for a temporary closure of Route 662 was made in conjunction with the State Highway Administration, Talbot County officials and the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office.”

Nearly 70 residents wrote the Talbot County Council opposing a land-transfer bill that removes a 2013 requirement for a replacement road before closure; the council approved it 4-1, with Lynn Mielke dissenting. Wittman resident Mark Marshall, who signed the letter, said: “It’s going to put a hardship on a lot of people who basically depend on that road, especially on weekends with the traffic and everything going to and from Easton.” He added: “If you have to go down (Route) 50, you’re taking your life in your own hands.”

The Maryland State Highway Administration, which must approve the state-road closure, stated: “SHA continues to work with all involved parties and will review the proposed detour plan to ensure it meets standards and provides for a safe alternate route.”
