While local government actions and agricultural impacts are discussed, the primary focus is the public safety implications of the closure.

title: New patrolman to join EPD
content:
On Monday, Dec. 18, 2023, Easton Police Department welcomed Patrolman Christopher Mueller to the force after he completed the six-month Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy at Wor-Wic Community College. The graduation ceremony, held at the Roland E. Powell Convention Center in Ocean City, included additional awards for Mueller in pistol marksmanship and academics.

Before joining the department, Mueller worked as a service technician II for ADT Commercial. He must now complete a three-month field training program with Easton Police Department to earn full certification as a Maryland law enforcement officer.

After the ceremony, Deputy Chief Gregory Wright congratulated Mueller on a job well done. Deputy Chief Wright said, "We're excited to have Patrolman Mueller join our team. He's going to have a positive impact on our community."

title: Tractor-trailer driver charged with assault in alleged hit-and-run
author: Konner Metz
content:
David Dziergowski, 33, of Glen Burnie, was charged Thursday with first-degree assault, reckless endangerment and five traffic citations after allegedly hitting a car three times at a red light in Easton. According to court documents, just after 7:30 a.m. that morning, police met with a woman who said her car was hit three times by a tractor-trailer going eastbound on Route 50 at the Dover Road intersection. She said she was stopped at the intersection's red light.

The woman told police that the tractor-trailer hit her rear bumper once, reversed and hit her car again and then struck her car for a third time, according to court records. The tractor-trailer driver, later identified as Dziergowski, continued driving when the light turned green and did not attempt to stop, the woman told police. Easton police wrote in charging documents that "dispatch (had) received several calls in reference to the same tractor trailer driving all over the roadway."

The Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Cambridge Police Department stopped the tractor-trailer stopped on Route 50 in Cambridge. Easton police arrived on scene and arrested Dziergowski around 8:30 a.m. Dziergowski was released on his own recognizance Thursday. A preliminary hearing in Talbot County District Court is set for Sept. 16.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a criminal incident involving assault and traffic violations, focusing on police action and public safety concerns.

title: Never plug these into power strip
content:
August 8, 2023 – Never plug high-draw appliances into a power strip, safety experts warn. “Hairdryers, curling wands and flat irons are required to produce heat, which means they pull large amounts of amperage to get them good and hot. Plugging them into a power strip is just asking for trouble,” the article states, adding that these tools “must be plugged directly into a wall outlet – preferably one with a ground-fault circuit interrupter breaker to avoid danger should those tools accidentally be exposed to water.”

Refrigerators, freezers, toasters, toaster ovens, microwaves and space heaters are also singled out. “These appliances pull too much current for a power strip because they are continuously cycling on and off. That will quickly overload a power strip,” the piece notes, stressing that “these items need to be plugged directly into a wall outlet dedicated solely to that appliance.”

Toasters are flagged because “it has exposed wires inside those slots that heat up to become red-hot. It takes a lot of current to fire up those wires, which can easily overload a power strip. So, no, do not plug your toaster into an extension cord or power strip. Ditto for your toaster oven.”

Microwaves demand “more energy than what a power strip can deliver,” and space heaters pose a special risk: “Most portable heaters consume 1,500 watts of energy on their high settings. Connect one to a power strip and it becomes potentially hazardous due to allowing them to run for an extended period.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article provides safety instructions to prevent electrical hazards, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: Seaplane crashes into Harris Creek, pilot uninjured, state police say
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
A seaplane crashed into Harris Creek around noon on Thursday, according to Maryland State Police. The pilot, 62, was the sole occupant and did not sustain injuries, an MSP spokesperson said.

Police identified the aircraft as an Aviat Husky, a small, two-seat seaplane. Per MSP, the aircraft "experienced an unknown mechanical malfunction while approaching its designated water landing site."

State troopers and Maryland Natural Resources Police responded to the scene. At around 7:00 p.m., Towboat U.S. began towing the vessel out of the water.

title: Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department marks 100 years with parade Saturday
author: Konner Metz
content:
The Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department, founded in 1925 with “a wagon with tanks,” will celebrate its 100th anniversary Saturday with a parade that starts at 10 a.m. near the Knapps Narrows Bridge and includes food, live music, games, and a junior firefighters’ hose-stream contest at 11:30 a.m. “It might help them to say, ‘I wanna join,’” secretary Linda Gottleib said. A private ceremony honoring key life members will follow the public events.

Department president Jesse Gottleib attributes the century-long survival to community backing: “So many small companies don’t see 100 years because of not only funding, but more so because of lack of participation, lack of volunteers for the department.” About 30 volunteers—12 of them firefighters—staff the station, which responds to two-to-ten calls monthly and recently assisted state searchers with a July 4 water rescue in Broad Creek. “We would’ve never thought it,” Jesse Gottleib said of the milestone. “And I think the reason is because people in this side of St. Michaels down, they realize that we’re gonna be there when they need it.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the centennial celebration of a volunteer fire department, its role in emergency response, and community safety activities, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Eastern Shore fire companies aid areas affected by Hurricane Helene
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Eastern Shore fire companies have rallied to support Hurricane Helene–ravaged areas, donating fire and EMS gear after members of the Oxford and Tilghman Fire Company saw online videos of the destruction and decided to help Tennessee first responders.

Oxford Fire Chief Graham Norbury said the impulse was natural: “We do a lot of mutual aid to other departments in the area and elsewhere. The Brotherhood of the Fire Services is pretty tight. When we see someone in need, then we want to be able to help any way we can.” After the department recently received a new ambulance and fire truck, Norbury spread word through the Maryland State Firefighters Association; Bill Killan of a Tennessee department soon coordinated a drop-off site in Butler, Tennessee.

Oxford Fire President Tim Kearns and three other drivers took turns on the 500-plus-mile haul, making two key deliveries. The first, in Bristol, Virginia, handed off “a skid brush unit, which is a pre-assembled piece of equipment that can fit into the back of a pickup truck and turn that pickup truck into a brush truck for fighting land fires and small house fires”—vital because “the roads in the area were so badly destroyed that any vehicle would have a difficult time navigating through.” The second stop was Faith Camp, a campground owned by Darren Clark of the Elk Mills Poga (Fla.) Volunteer Fire Department, who has turned the property into a satellite fire station for displaced residents.

Maryland departments in Oxford, Tilghman, Cordova, Easton, Queen Anne Hillsboro, Suddlersville and Hollywood contributed. “It took a lot of folks to coordinate and manhandle the transfer of this equipment, from the paperwork, insurances, transfer of titles and tags, to all of the logistics here, there and in between,” Kearns noted, crediting Chief Engineer Stacy Dulin and Assistant Chief Engineers Mike Greenwak and Tom Bixler for readying the gear, and Oxford Ferry for lending the heavy trailer.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on fire companies providing emergency assistance and equipment after a hurricane, which directly relates to public safety services.

title: Democrats say no big changes to cannabis law
author: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service
content:
Maryland Democrats are rejecting Republican efforts to repeal the state’s 2023 law that bars police from stopping or searching drivers based solely on the smell of marijuana. Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) said the party will pursue only minor tweaks. “I think we're going to have a cannabis bill this year that sort of does some — I don't want to call it cleanup — but adjustments to the system that we passed last year,” Ferguson stated. “I don't think you'll see major changes to the program, but implementation adjustments.”

The law, backed by the Legislative Black Caucus, was enacted last year to curb unwarranted searches disproportionately affecting people of color. Critics contend it hampers policing. “The irony is, if we see someone chugging a beer, police can pull them over,” said Sen. William Folden (R-Frederick), a legislator and police officer. He argued the statute removes probable cause “just because you're saying, well, you're not allowed to use your nose anymore.”

After voters legalized adult-use cannabis, the General Assembly crafted licensing, taxation, and equity rules. Del. Jheanelle Wilkins (D-Montgomery), Black Caucus chair and odor-law sponsor, said the measures were meant to address “the harms of the past when it comes to criminalization of cannabis.” Sen. Jack Bailey (R-Calvert, St. Mary’s) countered, “The public clearly wanted marijuana legalized, fine, but we shouldn't do away with the requirements.”

Democratic leaders reiterated that only small administrative changes—such as refining the Maryland Cannabis Administration’s structure—are on the table. “It was hugely complicated, lots of moving pieces for the cannabis bill last year,” Ferguson noted. Wilkins added the caucus is “working closely with the administration to make sure that our intentions of the bill are carried out.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on police powers and a law restricting vehicle searches based on marijuana odor, which directly relates to public safety and law enforcement issues.

Sen. William Folden (R-Frederick)

title: Talbot County places burn ban
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
The Talbot County Council enacted a 30-day burn ban Friday morning, effective immediately. The measure prohibits all “open-air burning,” defined by the county as “burning any material in the open or in a receptacle other than a furnace, … including use of fireworks, sparklers, or sparkling devices.”

Brian LeCates, county director of emergency services, said in a memorandum that the request for a burn ban came from volunteer fire chiefs and the county’s burn ban committee. “Their concern is that we have had abnormally dry conditions with no appreciable precipitation in the weather forecast,” LeCates wrote. He noted the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is “currently classifying Talbot County as having abnormally dry conditions,” adding, “Looking at our weather forecast, we do not show any significant precipitation in the near future. The Maryland Department of Natural Resources Forest Service has listed our area as highly susceptible to fire due to these conditions.”

The ban will last 30 days unless extended or terminated. Dorchester and Wicomico counties enacted similar bans last week; Wicomico extended its ban on Oct. 22. Talbot’s most recent prior burn ban began July 21.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a county council's burn ban to prevent fire hazards, a measure primarily concerned with protecting residents from fire risk, fitting the Public Safety category, while also involving local government action.

organizations: Maryland Department of Natural Resources Forest Service

title: PAUGH JOINS SHERIFF's OFFICE
content:
Lt. George Paugh, former chief of the Greensboro Police Department, joined the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office on Nov. 1, Sheriff Donnie Baker announced. “Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker, left, welcomes Lt. George Paugh … who joined the agency Nov. 1,” the department said, adding that Paugh “will serve as commander of the criminal investigation division.”

A Marine Corps veteran, Paugh began his law-enforcement career with the town of Goldsboro, serving “fewer than two years,” before spending 26 years with the Easton Police Department.

title: Stolen delivery truck found burning on train tracks
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
A stolen FedEx truck was discovered “billowing with flames after being dumped along the train tracks by Red Toad Road and Bethel Church Road on Sunday, Feb. 23,” the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal reported. Authorities say “the commercial delivery truck was stolen from the nearby FedEx center in North East before an unknown arsonist left the vehicle several miles away along the train tracks and set it on fire.”

A CSX train operator spotted the blaze, which caused approximately $200,000 in damages. “Seven firefighters from the North East Volunteer Fire Company responded to the incident, controlling the flames in the cab of the delivery truck within 20 minutes.” Investigators urge anyone with information to call 410-386-3050.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a criminal incident involving arson and a stolen delivery truck, focusing on the fire response and investigation, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: After two deadly work zone crashes, Maryland officials press for change
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
Maryland Gov. Wes Moore on Tuesday signed the Maryland Road Worker Protection Act, a measure his administration calls “a moral imperative” that lets work zones deploy multiple speed cameras and, effective June 1, raises the base fine for speed-camera violations to $80; beginning in January 2025 fines will range from $60 to $500 depending on speed and will double when workers are present. Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller, a former transportation engineer, said the law was inspired by two fatal incidents: “We saw it happen on March 22, 2023. And we saw it happen again on March 26, 2024. It’s a moral imperative that we protect workers who provide critical service, public service for all of us.”

Also signed was the PORT Act, amended in the session’s final hours to create the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program, offering up to five years of full-time or eight years of part-time tuition aid to children and spouses of transportation workers who have died on the job since 2022. “Certainly, we wish there were no one participating in that fund, but sadly, we know how dangerous this work is,” said Senate President Bill Ferguson. Del. Ashanti Martinez explained the caucus push: “When someone passes, particularly as the breadwinner or primary breadwinner of their family, it trickles down.” While Del. Deni Taveras voiced concern over immediate needs—“Something is definitely better than nothing. I’m happy that they can have a secure future for themselves through access to college.”—Del. Joe Vogel added, “I want the families to feel like the lives lost were not in vain and that the state appreciates and recognizes the immense value of those six individuals.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on deadly work‑zone crashes, new safety legislation, and enforcement measures, which are core issues of public safety. It also involves state government actions, but safety concerns are the primary theme.

title: Easton officials weigh in on Complete Streets study, pedestrian safety
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton officials met Monday to review a Wallace Montgomery engineering study—branded “Complete Streets”—that will classify every town road by use (residential, collector, commercial-urban, commercial-industrial) and by surrounding land type (downtown, residential, commercial, industrial) to decide which mode—walking, biking or driving—should predominate. Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said the forthcoming manual, with guidelines to be overlaid on a town map in November, “will make it easier for the town to require certain road safety steps be taken when residential or commercial developers apply for site plan approval,” and predicted the town will be “less likely to give developers breaks or reliefs from ensuring private roads are up to town standards.” “It’s a very practical document that I can think of a lot of different ways it will be used,” Van Emburgh said of the Complete Streets study.

Specific trouble spots dominated the hour-long discussion. Council President Don Abbatiello, joined by Councilmembers Maureen Curry and the Rev. Elmer Davis, complained that telephone poles mid-sidewalk on Port Street endanger walkers. “It’s gonna (be) awfully difficult to make Port Street pedestrian friendly unless we make some serious improvements,” Curry said. North Washington Street is already slated for sidewalks; survey and design money is budgeted for the stretch from Easton Hardware to Gay’s Seafood, and the Complete Streets guidance will dictate final bike, pedestrian and vehicular details.

The broader debate flared after a recent fatal bicycle crash on state-controlled Route 50. Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery warned, “Automobile transportation is pretty much what everybody uses in order to get into the center of town. So I’m very concerned about our sacrificing the flow of single-occupancy vehicles, sacrificing it to other things, that for my ward, don’t do any good at all by way of mobility,” noting many older west-side residents “aren’t interested in bicycling to downtown.” Talbot Thrive Executive Director Heather Grant countered that residents who “don’t want to drive everywhere” deserve “equal access to safe infrastructure,” adding, “Some council members who mention the difficulties in traveling by car during school drop off and pick up should consider that if we make our streets safer for kids to walk and bike to school, we can reduce vehicle congestion.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on pedestrian and bike safety initiatives and street design, which are primary public safety concerns, though it involves local government officials.

title: Federalsburg Police Department welcomes new officer
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Federalsburg Police Department welcomed Officer Chandler Dyott after he graduated from the Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy on June 11. Dyott, from Easton, had been with the department since December doing ride-alongs while preparing to become a full-time officer.

"Ever since I was little, I wanted to be a cop," Dyott said. "But when I got out of high school, you can't be a cop until you're 21. So, when I got out of high school, I thought, 'I'll join Talbot County Corrections.' That way in corrections, it teaches you how to talk to people, interact with the people. Just because they got locked up and you see them in the jail, you realize they're not a bad person. They're just people like us."

The 21-year-old previously worked two years as a Talbot County correctional officer. Now completing his required 240 hours of field training, Dyott has enjoyed meeting the community and wants residents to know "I'm going to be fair, 100%. I believe in respect goes a long way. You respect me, I'm going to respect you anytime… No matter what, I'm going to be fair, and I'm going to try to step up on community policing."

"We're proud to welcome Officer Dyott to our department," Lt. Michelle Schuerholz said. "Being so young, he brings a strong commitment to community and public safety, and we're confident he will be a great asset to both our department and the residents we serve. We look forward to seeing the positive impact Officer Dyott will make in our community. He comes from correctional, and he had a good reputation there, and I think he'll do well here."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police department hiring a new officer, which directly relates to public safety matters.

people: Officer Chandler Dyott, Federalsburg Police Department
Lt. Michelle Schuerholz, Federalsburg Police Department

title: Reporting when rumors spread faster than facts
author: Staff Writer
content:
A recent surge in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement arrests has challenged The Star Democrat newsroom as “reports of ICE activity spread quickly on social media, but with little publicly accessible information from official sources, it became difficult to determine the extent of what was happening in Mid-Shore communities.”  
With “rumors circulated faster than verifiable facts, and many details remained inaccessible,” the newsroom “pulled out some old-fashioned, on-the-ground reporting techniques.”  
This week reporter Konner Metz “knocked on doors in a small town on the Maryland-Delaware border with a large immigrant population” and “spoke with residents to learn first-hand how the community was grappling immigration enforcement activity.”  
“Konner's story, which you can read below, captures what that community is experiencing, but it is just one part of a larger, still unfolding story of ICE activity on the Eastern Shore.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses ICE arrests, rumors about law‑enforcement activity, and community impact, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Mother charged in killing of daughter, 3, extradited back to Maryland
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Darrian Lynnelle Randle, 31, was extradited from Delaware to Maryland on Sept. 23 and ordered held without bond after a bail review hearing Sept. 25 in Cecil County Circuit Court. Appearing by closed-circuit TV from the Cecil County Detention Center, Randle heard Assistant State’s Attorney Gavin Patashnick argue: “The state cannot think of any (allegations) more heinous . . .” Patashnick added that Randle—who has family in Indiana and no local ties—poses a flight risk, and noted that “Both governors in Delaware and Maryland signed the agreement. She must go back to Delaware immediately (after the adjudication of her Cecil County murder case).”

Randle is charged with first-degree murder and 10 related counts in the June 9 beating death of her 3-year-old daughter, Nola Dinkins, inside the Elk Nest Road home of her boyfriend, Cedrick Antoine Britten, 44. Court records say Randle confessed to striking Nola “15 to 20 times with a belt all over her body,” causing the child to collapse and stop breathing, then asked Britten to dispose of the body in a dark blue suitcase. Britten, also held without bond, allegedly provided a map that led police to human remains “consistent with an emaciated child” in a nearby vacant lot; the remains were positively identified as Nola’s. After the killing, Randle falsely reported a kidnapping near Newark, Del., triggering an Amber Alert; she must return to Delaware to face a felony false-report charge once her Maryland case concludes.

Defense attorney Michael Halter told the judge that Randle “vehemently denies the allegations” and “looks forward to her day in court.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, court proceedings, and extradition, which are matters of public safety and law enforcement rather than sports, health, or other categories.

title: Chester woman sentenced in 2024 multi-vehicle crash on Bay Bridge
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Gwendolyn Persina, 49, of Chester, was sentenced July 8 in Queen Anne’s County Circuit Court for causing a life-threatening injury while operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. “On July 8, Gwendolyn Persina…was sentenced to three years of jail time with all but 315 days suspended, which is the time Persina has served in jail from the time of her arrest,” the Office of the State’s Attorney reported. She also received five years of supervised probation, a mental-health evaluation, alcohol treatment, and was ordered to abstain from alcohol and drugs.

The crash occurred at about 7:46 a.m. on Jan. 27, 2024, when Persina, driving westbound on the Queen Anne’s County side of the Bay Bridge in heavy fog, “rear-ended another vehicle, which disabled her vehicle in the travel portion of the bridge, resulting in a 23-vehicle chain reaction collision.” One victim had his arm severed and it could not be reattached. Police determined Persina’s blood-alcohol level was “between 0.24 and 0.27 — three times greater than the legal limit.”

Persina was not charged until August 2024. “The state reported the delay in formally charging Persina was due to the incredible amount of vehicle data that had to be reviewed for the more than 20 vehicles involved,” and “medical records had to be obtained and then the large volume of records had to be reviewed,” Rob Penny, chief of staff to State’s Attorney Lance Richardson, explained. After her arrest, Persina’s attorneys filed a notice of incompetency, but on July 2 “the state doctor from the Maryland Department of Health deemed Persina competent to stand trial.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and traffic accident, which are matters of public safety and law enforcement.

title: Pilot dies in plane crash near Easton
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Robert Eugene Merlini, 56, of Annapolis was identified as the victim of the crash by MSP Tuesday evening. The Merlini called in an engine failure before crashing into the river at around 9:30 a.m., the Federal Aviation Administration said in a statement to The Star Democrat. The pilot was the only person on board.

Merlini was doing work with the Maryland Advanced Development Laboratory's University Research Foundation, according to officials at the scene. "It's a sad day for not only the aviation community, but for the scientific community," said David Abrams, the communication director for the Maryland Department of the Environment. According to David Heidhausen, president at the University Research Foundation, the plane was used for advanced research and development. Heidhausen said the projects included enhanced flight vision systems, cameras in the nose and helmet-mounted displays. Heidhausen said Merlini was not developing research but relocating the plane in a "ferry flight" when he crashed.

According to a preliminary investigation, the aircraft took off shortly before 9 a.m. from Tipton Airport at Fort Meade before crashing into the Tred Avon River, MSP said. Police believe the pilot was headed toward the Easton Airport when the crash occurred. Liz Underhill, who lives along the Tred Avon, received a call from a neighbor who had seen the plane in the water. Underhill got in her boat and attempted to assess the situation. She saw the plane in the water, but no one was out of the plane. There were numerous other people in boats trying to help.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a fatal aircraft accident and details the emergency response by police, fire, and coast guard agencies, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Federalsburg carport fire causes estimated $125K in damage
author: Natalie Jones
content:
A carport fire caused an estimated $125,000 in damage to a one-story, wood-framed home at 26955 Iron Gate Road in Federalsburg on Friday, Jan. 5. The blaze, reported shortly before 2 p.m., was discovered by the home’s occupant and drew a response of about 40 firefighters, “primarily from the Denton Volunteer Fire Company,” according to the report.

Crews needed roughly 30 minutes to bring the flames under control. Although “smoke alarms were present,” the Office of the State Fire Marshal noted they “did not activate.” The cause of the fire remains under investigation.

Anyone with information is asked to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal at 410-822-7609.

title: 39 indicted, accused of drug-trafficking ring
author: Staff Writer
content:
Thirty-nine people have been indicted for allegedly running a drug-trafficking ring on the Eastern Shore after a five-month probe by “Wicomico Narcotics, a collaborative effort between the Maryland Department of State Police, the Fruitland Police Department, the Office of the State's Attorney for Wicomico County, and the Drug Enforcement Administration,” that began in spring 2024.

In August 2024, “Wicomico Narcotics and the Drug Enforcement Administration Salisbury Regional Office served multiple search and seizure warrants in Wicomico, Dorchester, and Baltimore counties,” recovering “more than 2,500 grams of suspected cocaine and nearly 30 grams of fentanyl as well as other felony narcotics, 14 firearms, and four vehicles that allegedly were used to transport the drugs.”

More than two dozen agencies—including sheriffs’ offices across the Lower Shore, Homeland Security Investigations, Salisbury and Ocean City police, and the Maryland Department of Transportation Authority Police—assisted Maryland State Police in the takedown. The investigation was funded by “the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy and the Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Forces,” with Wicomico Narcotics designated as “a Washington/Baltimore HIDTA-funded initiative” and supported by the Maryland Criminal Intelligence Network.

title: Mid-Shore organization pioneers a 'hub' of resources for victims of domestic violence
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
For more than four decades, the Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence has led advocacy for victims on the Mid-Shore, and its new Geographic Information System program now extends help far beyond the region by mapping a free one-stop hub of essential resources.

Executive director Jeanne Yeager said rural clients face barriers such as limited jobs, spotty cell service, scarce transportation and housing, and geographic isolation; the pandemic made those barriers unmistakable.  
"I was really mindful of coming out of COVID, because everything we did at Mid-Shore was very one-on-one, personalized — our case management, our meetings, our support groups, everything — and we would say, 'Oh, well, we'll do an online group sometime.' Well, 'that sometime' became tomorrow," Yeager said. "So it normalized using technology, and I think there's no turning back."

What began as a five-county housing map grew, GIS senior data analyst Kazeem Anifowoshe explained, into a nine-county website now used by 25 agencies and stocked with pro-bono and legal resources through a partnership with Access to Justice.  
"When people kind of think of victim services, there's kind of like a formula that a lot of people have been doing for 20 to 40 plus years at their organization that works for them," Anifowoshe said. "But again, we're just trying to make things easier the best way we know how, by mapping things."

The hub, which recently earned the Domestic Shelters Purple Ribbon Award, layers data on housing, childcare, pet care, medical facilities, courts, law enforcement, and social services. Program evaluator Pamela Caudill Jordan hopes the model will push organizations beyond crisis intervention toward long-term survivor stability.

Yeager and Anifowoshe aim for wider adoption across Maryland and, eventually, nationwide.  
"We know what victims need," Yeager said. "We ought to work with victims, and we're making this available. Let's see where we're going with it."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a nonprofit's initiative to improve resources for domestic violence victims, which is primarily a public safety and victim‑support issue.

people: Jeanne Yeager, executive director, Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence
Kazeem Anifowoshe, GIS senior data analyst
Pamela Caudill Jordan, program evaluator, GIS Hub

title: St. Michaels VFD places new engine into service
author: Mike Detmer; mdetmer@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department’s new Engine 45—a 2023 E-One Cyclone engine-tanker carrying 1,035 gallons of water—was placed into service on July 27 and has already responded to calls, including pumping water at a recent attic fire. The apparatus, outfitted with a Cummins L9 engine, Hale QMAX pump, and more than $200,000 of tools and hose, replaced the 2009 Engine 49 as the first-due unit and supplanted the 1990 Engine 48, which after 33 years “exceeded the expected 30-year service window” and is now kept in reserve because “parts for repairs are getting harder to find and the apparatus lacks updated safety features,” according to SMVFD President Chris Thomas.

Designed by the department’s engine committee and bought through Patriot Fire in Grasonville, the $718,850 rig was funded by “a combination of fundraising efforts and money that we get from the county, town and state,” Thomas said. He praised supporters—“The department thanks the generous residents and businesses who helped make this purchase happen through their donations and support over the past few years”—and singled out the department’s pit beef and pit turkey as “off the charts … phenomenal.”

With about 70 members, half of them fire/EMS personnel, SMVFD faces the same staffing shortages seen nationwide; Thomas noted, “We’re hurting just like everyone else,” while adding that the area’s retirees help keep the administrative side staffed. Planning ahead for the three-to-five-year apparatus lead times, the department continues fundraising for the eventual replacement of its aging brush and tanker trucks.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a volunteer fire department acquiring a new fire engine, which is directly related to emergency services and public safety.

people: Chris Thomas, St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department President

title: 'Heartbroken': Delaware figure skaters, coach among those killed in D.C. plane, Black Hawk crash
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
An American Airlines jet carrying 64 people and an Army Black Hawk helicopter with three soldiers collided late Wednesday while the plane was landing at Ronald Reagan National Airport, leaving no survivors. The wreckage—found upside-down in three sections in waist-deep Potomac water—prompted a switch “from a rescue operation to a recovery operation,” said D.C. Fire Chief John Donnelly.

Among the 67 dead were Alexandr “Sasha” Kirsanov, 46, a University of Delaware-affiliated coach, and two of his young pairs-skating students, Sean Kay and Angela Yang, who had just competed at a national development camp in Wichita, Kansas. “Our hearts go out to the families and friends of all of the victims of this horrific tragedy,” UD president Dennis Assanis said. “Kirsanov and the skaters trained at the University’s High Performance Training Center… the training home for many years of multiple world-class skating champions,” he added. UD athletic director Chrissi Rawak said, “His dedication — and that of his skaters — forged meaningful connections throughout the UD family. Coach Kirsanov’s passion and commitment touched many lives, leaving a permanent mark on our campus.”

Kirsanov’s wife and fellow coach, Natalya Gudin, told ABC News, “I lost everything. I lost my husband, I lost my students, I lost my friends.” Kay and Yang, partners who won first place at a Texas competition in November, were returning with at least 14 other skaters from the Wichita camp. “It was a lot of fun watching all the skaters at Kansas,” Yang posted on Instagram three days before the crash. U.S. Figure Skating stated, “We are heartbroken to learn that figure skaters, along with their families, friends and coaches, are understood to be among those on board.”

Delaware leaders demanded a full investigation. “Here in Delaware, we’re mourning the loss of former University of Delaware Figure Skating coach Sasha Kirsanov, as well as two youth skaters and their family members who were aboard AA5342,” said Gov. Matt Meyer. Sen. Chris Coons added, “I’m devastated to hear the news that at least three Delawareans died during last night’s air collision… Delaware is a state of neighbors, and tonight we hold all of our neighbors a little closer.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a fatal plane and helicopter collision, a public safety incident, even though the victims are figure skaters. The primary focus is the crash and its investigation, making Public Safety the best match.

title: Cambridge woman pleads guilty to altering evidence in Sidetracked Saloon shooting
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge woman Chadnee Harris, 33, received a three-year sentence after pleading guilty to altering physical evidence in the Sept. 30 shooting death of 23-year-old Antonio Smith in the Sidetracked Saloon parking lot in Easton. “Judge Broughton Earnest handed down the sentence following a plea hearing on May 22,” and Harris “will serve 236 days followed by one year of probation, with the remainder of the sentence suspended.”

The charge was reduced from accessory-after-the-fact counts for first- and second-degree murder. Officers found Smith with a gunshot wound to the head just before 2 a.m.; he died at University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton.

Bar security footage showed “Chase and Harris standing between two cars near the entrance of the bar and Smith approaching the two.” After Chase pointed a handgun at Smith, “Chase put the handgun back toward his waistband area and then appeared to hand the gun to Harris.” During the ensuing fight, “Harris reportedly walked toward the men,” and moments later “Smith appeared to duck behind a car and Chase walked toward Smith, pointing a handgun at him.” The reviewing officer wrote that a muzzle flash was seen and “Smith collapse in between two cars.”

Kevron Chase, 35, of Cambridge, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder on May 20; his sentencing is set for July 19. Talbot County State’s Attorney Joseph Coale said Chase “then left the scene and drove to Cambridge, where he disposed of the handgun in the Choptank River.” Police later located and detained both Chase and Harris during a traffic stop on Race Street in Cambridge.

title: Woman faces murder charge after allegedly running over man with SUV
author: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com
content:
A 50-year-old woman faces a murder charge after she allegedly hit a man with a vehicle in Lexington Park Oct. 7. Maryland State Police homicide investigators arrested Simone Stewart, 50, of Lexington Park in connection with the death of Demeatrum Scarborough. Stewart is charged with second-degree murder, first-degree assault, homicide by motor vehicle and driving under the influence. She is currently at the St. Mary's Detention Center awaiting an appearance before the court commissioner, according to a release from the state police sent Wednesday night. Scarborough, 53, of Lexington Park was pronounced deceased Tuesday by hospital personnel at MedStar Washington Hospital.

"Police believe Stewart and Scarborough were involved in an ongoing relationship. Further investigation indicates they were involved in an alleged altercation at the time the incident occurred," according to the release. Shortly before 1 p.m. on Monday, Oct. 7, troopers from the Leonardtown barrack responded to Spring Valley Drive and Valley Court in Lexington Park for the report of a pedestrian struck by a Chevrolet Suburban. Upon arrival, troopers located Scarborough with apparent injuries. He was flown by Maryland State Police Aviation Command to MedStar Washington Hospital. The preliminary investigation indicated Stewart was allegedly the driver of the Suburban at the time of the incident, according to the state police. Based on additional information received, evidence collected and consultation with the St. Mary's County State's Attorney, Stewart was charged with the murder of Scarborough.

title: Four prison murders, but officials plead immunity
author: George F. Will
content:
On April 7, 2017, Jacob Philip and Denver Simmons—two inmates already serving life sentences for unrelated double homicides—spent two and a half hours murdering four fellow prisoners inside Simmons’s cell at a South Carolina facility that houses inmates with “persistent mental illness.”  
Court filings describe the sequence: they “lured John King with a promised coffee, strangled him with an extension cord, and stuffed him under a bed. Thirty minutes later … Simmons strangled a second inmate while Philip ‘stomped’ on his ribs, causing them to ‘pop.’ Thirty minutes later, they stabbed their third victim with a broken broom handle.” After using a trash bag to cover the cell-door window, they invited a fourth victim inside and “strangled [him] with their forearms, the extension cord and a broom handle.” When “apparently sated, they walked to the prison’s administration building and suggested that officers check Simmons’s cell.”

Sgt. DeWaun McKan, whose required 30-minute security checks never included looking into the cell, “neither checked for pulses nor performed CPR” once the bodies were discovered; he “instead radio[ed] for help.” King’s family sued McKan and prison administrators under a “supervisory liability” theory, arguing the death resulted from officials’ “deliberate indifference.” This month the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit “affirmed a district court’s judgment that King’s family cannot sue to hold anyone at the prison responsible,” granting qualified immunity to all defendants. The majority held: “There is no clearly established constitutional right to properly conducted security checks,” and therefore neither McKan nor others “‘knowingly’ disregarded the law.”

Judge James A. Wynn Jr., dissenting, wrote that the “atrocity” occurred because “two double-murderers could circulate through the prison unit unsupervised,” noting McKan’s checks were “risible” and that “he did not notice four corpses during five checks.” Wynn emphasized that the Supreme Court has affirmed “an Eighth Amendment duty ‘to protect prisoners from violence at the hands of other prisoners,’” and that the 4th Circuit itself has said “a prison official cannot hide behind an excuse that he was unaware of a risk, no matter how obvious.” He concluded: “Granting qualified immunity in a ‘failure-to-protect’ case constitutes permission for lethal neglect,” and warned that “when judges, with hairsplitting misapplications of qualified immunity, openly abet governmental malfeasance … mayhem proliferates, lethally.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses prison violence, qualified immunity, and government accountability, which relate to public safety and criminal justice issues.

people: Jacob Philip
Denver Simmons
John King
Sgt. DeWaun McKan
Judge James A. Wynn Jr.
organizations: U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Darian Braun, 23, of Easton has received a year-and-a-half sentence for child pornography charges.

A Delaware man has been arrested by Cambridge police on drug charges after allegedly striking a person — who police say appeared to be suffering from an overdose — with a vehicle before leaving the scene.

On Sunday, residents, friends, family and individuals from several states came together to support the Puckett family at the Mason and Bentley Puckett funeral fundraiser at Greater Impact in Greensboro. Mason, 1, and Bentley, 3, died on June 29 in an accidental drowning, according to the Caroline County Sheriff's Office. Michael Puckett, Mason and Bentley's father, described his children as "everything."

A Caroline County District Court case concerning a Talbot County woman charged with animal cruelty has been transferred to the Caroline County Circuit Court. Barbara Lemaire, 29, was charged in December on 34 counts of animal cruelty.

Four people have pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges in connection to an incident in the Easton Kohl's parking lot last year.

title: American Legion Post 77 donates $40,000 to local organizations and in scholarships
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
On Saturday morning, American Legion Post 77 in Easton distributed roughly $40,000 in scholarships and grants to local volunteer fire companies, children’s organizations, churches, and other nonprofits. “We feel very good about that,” Post 77 Judge Advocate Walter Black said, noting the gifts are “consistent with our mission of assisting veterans and their families, and children and youth, and the community at large.”

Recipients included Talbot County’s volunteer fire departments, nearly 20 churches, Critchlow Adkins Children’s Centers, the Talbot Senior Center, the Frederick Douglass Honor Society, the Neighborhood Service Center, and mental-health provider Channel Marker. Representatives came to the post to accept the donations, which Black said are funded largely by on-site slot-machine proceeds. “It was wonderful,” he observed, adding that all recipients were “very pleased.”

Cristy Morrell, executive director of Critchlow Adkins Children’s Centers, called the event “lovely,” adding, “They support such amazing organizations in our community. And they’re not always organizations that I think people are aware of. And so, that they include us in with those organizations is very humbling and we’re very honored.” Morrell said the “generous” donation will support enrichment programming and tuition assistance at the center’s Trappe and Easton locations. “I’m just honored that they consider us a worthwhile cause,” she concluded.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a charitable donation that includes support for volunteer fire departments and community safety-related organizations, making Public Safety the most relevant category, with Education (scholarships) as a close secondary match.

Cristy Morrell, Executive Director, Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers

title: Hillsboro house fire results in $100K in damages
author: Staff Writer
content:
A house fire that broke out in Hillsboro shortly after 8 p.m. Tuesday resulted in "$100,000 in damages," according to a release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal. A firefighter "was transported to a local medical center after sustaining an injury while combatting the blaze," the fire marshal said.

The occupants of the two-story, wood-framed house "were home at the time and initially observed smoke and fire coming from the interior first floor bedroom." They "were able to escape the house uninjured with their multiple pet dogs."

It took "60 firefighters approximately one hour to control the fire," according to the fire marshal. The cause of the fire is under investigation.

Anyone with information about the fire is asked to call 410-822-7609.

title: Background checks needed
author: Staff Writer
content:
A letter to the editor from Joseph Murphy of Newark, Delaware, published March 3, 2024 in The Star Democrat, endorses stronger gun-safety measures after the Kansas City parade shooting. “The shooting in Kansas City shows that there is an issue in our country. Juveniles carrying guns and firing upon a parade of innocent civilians should show that this is a crucial conversation to have,” Murphy writes.

Citing agreement with the earlier article “Why we cannot solve America’s gun problem,” Murphy contends, “I agree that in Missouri there needs to be better gun safety laws such as background checks and permits to carry. A requirement to lock up firearms countrywide is essential in a household because juveniles like this can get guns from family members.” He criticizes political alliances that block reform: “I agree that it is an issue that one party has made an agreement with the National Rifle Association, and they have their bias toward it. Opposing criminal background checks does not seem safe or smart in any capacity. Some lawmakers change and alter their ideals purposefully to receive votes.”

Murphy adds he does not seek an outright ban—“I do not think guns should be completely outlawed and banned. I think everyone should have the right to own a firearm barring obvious constraints such as mental illness or a criminal record”—but insists, “However, there absolutely needs to be background checks across the country and ensuring that guns in the house are locked up and out of reach from children.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses gun violence, background checks, and safety measures, which directly relate to public safety concerns.

title: Teen arrested for alleged assault with rock at park
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
An Easton teenager was arrested Thursday, Sept. 21 and charged as an adult after allegedly striking a woman in the head with a rock. Police said Denilson E. Mendez Tomas, 17, is facing first-and second-degree assault and reckless endangerment charges in connection to the incident Thursday evening.

Officers from the Easton Police Department were dispatched to the John Ford Park just after 6:30 p.m. Thursday for an assault. After arriving, police found a 46-year-old woman who was bleeding heavily from a laceration on her forehead sitting on a bench in the park. The woman told police that she was walking the Rails to Trails when she saw Mendez urinating in the woods. The woman told police that she did not pay attention to the teen and continued walking. But as she was walking, she heard footsteps coming from behind her. When she turned around, she was repeatedly struck in the head with a rock by Mendez, police said.

Police said Mendez took the woman to the ground when she started to scream for help. The woman told police that as she screamed, Mendez ran down the trail traveling south. About an hour and a half later, as officers were canvassing the Rails to Trails looking for a suspect, police found Mendez on the trail at South Street. Officers noticed that the teen matched the description of the suspect and had blood on his clothing. Police said Mendez was released to the custody of the Talbot County Detention Center.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal incident and police response, which falls squarely under public safety rather than other categories.

title: Rider trial postponed; bench warrant issued
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Fred “Trey” Rider III will not stand trial this week on 15 counts—including arson, malicious destruction of property and reckless endangerment—after Judge Thomas G. Ross learned Rider “had been voluntarily admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital” and issued a bench warrant for his failure to appear Monday morning. The trial, originally set for March 4, 2024, has been tentatively rescheduled for Aug. 19 at 9 a.m., according to the Maryland Electronic Courts website.

Rider’s attorney, Stephanie Shipley, filed a motion Friday requesting the postponement, stating Rider had been admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital “on an emergency basis for acute medical issues, with further transfer planned to an inpatient facility in the State of Maryland.” The State’s Attorney’s Office consented on the condition of “further appropriate medical documentation,” and Shipley presented an updated letter from the hospital at Monday’s status hearing. Once Rider is released, the bench warrant can be executed; his $20,000 unsecured bond, posted in February 2023, was revoked.

The charges stem from a Nov. 24, 2022, fire at 27930 Peach Orchard Road in Easton. Deputy State Fire Marshal Shayne McKinney wrote that a Talbot County deputy indicated Rider “had possibly attempted suicide that evening based on evidence found within the home,” noting Rider “had attempted suicide in the past as well.” A person connected to Rider told investigators Rider “had clearly indicated to him that he was attempting suicide and wanted to be left alone,” and that Rider said “he lit the house on fire” during their phone conversation. Officials classified the blaze as incendiary, and court documents state Rider’s actions “clearly” endangered more than 45 responding firefighters. Rider was arrested in February 2023 and in April 2023 entered a plea of not criminally responsible by reason of insanity.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an arson case, emergency response, and a bench warrant, focusing on safety concerns and law‑enforcement actions, which best fits the Public Safety category.

title: Body sits in Greensboro yard for hours due to traffic delay
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
On June 22 at about 1:57 p.m., the Greensboro Police Department were dispatched to 110 Maple Ave. in Greensboro in reference to an unattended death. "A male was found lying face up on the stairs of his apartment," according to a statement from the Town of Greensboro.

When EMS arrived, they moved the man, who was not identified, from the residence and stairs down to the front yard area near the driveway so they could conduct a full analysis. He was pronounced dead at about 2:06 p.m., the town said. EMS then placed two sheets over the man, preventing him from being viewed by the public.

The forensic investigator arrived on the scene at about 4:30 p.m., then they consulted the medical examiner's office in Baltimore that an autopsy would be needed. The forensic investigator contacted Springbok to transport the body to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore. The estimated time of arrival was initially an hour and a half, but due to a 16-mile Bay Bridge back-up, the transport was delayed and didn't arrive until 7 p.m.

"EMS, the forensic investigator and the Greensboro Police Department offered to moved the man out of the environment, back inside the residence or place him in a body bag. The family declined all options," the town said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a death investigation, police and EMS response, and forensic procedures, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

organizations: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner

title: Police fatally shoot Cambridge man Thursday evening
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
A 30-year-old Cambridge man was fatally shot by a Cambridge police officer Thursday evening after he “advanced on officers” with a knife, according to a department release. Officers had responded shortly after 5 p.m. to the Deep Harbor development around Seaway Lane and Riverview Wharf for “a report of a male subject chasing a female subject with a knife.”

“Officers on scene attempted to deescalate the situation and have the subject drop the knife,” the release said. “The subject refused and advanced on officers. Officers gave warnings for the subject to stop as they were attempting to retreat.” Police said the man continued to approach, and one officer fired multiple times. “Officers immediately rendered life saving measures to the subject awaiting EMS arrival,” the release said. “After EMS arrived, the subject was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Cambridge prior to being flown by Maryland State Police Aviation to Tidal Health Peninsula Regional Medical Center in Salisbury,” where he later died.

Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd confirmed three officers were present and said this is the city’s first fatal police shooting in roughly 15 years. The officer who discharged their weapon has been placed on paid administrative leave while the Maryland attorney general’s Independent Investigations Division conducts the state-mandated probe. Todd said press releases and body-worn camera footage will be released “as part of the transparency process.”

“I think the main thing I want to say is my condolences to the family of the subject that succumbed to his injuries. Unfortunately, it's a sad situation,” Todd said. “And speaking with some of the family, I just feel there needs to be thoughts and prayers kept for them as well.” Neither the deceased man nor the involved officer has been publicly identified.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police shooting incident, which directly pertains to law enforcement and community safety issues, making 'Public Safety' the most appropriate category.

30-year-old Caucasian male from Cambridge

title: Juvenile services department to move detained girls, again
author: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service
content:
Maryland’s Department of Juvenile Services will move girls awaiting court or long-term placement from a single unit at the boys-only Cheltenham Youth Detention Center to the Western Maryland Children’s Center in Hagerstown later this month, where all girls in the agency’s residential care will eventually be housed. The shift follows Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit reports that four moves of detained girls—and one of committed girls—between March and October 2022 “disrupted school, led to longer and more frequent periods of confinement and isolation, delayed medical services and exposed girls to sexual harassment.”

Investigators documented the fallout: “They just treat these girls like chattel, moving them constantly from one place to another without thinking of how it will impact them,” a staffer said in early 2023. A mental-health therapist added, “They are just replicating the streets here, it’s like survival every day,” noting the Victor Cullen Center was too “short-handed” to provide treatment. A 19-year-old at Cullen told an investigator, “There is nothing treatment-oriented about this program.”

The revolving-door placements began when DJS closed the Thomas J.S. Waxter Children’s Center in March 2022, moved girls to the refurbished Alfred D. Noyes center, then shuttled them twice more after a fire and a staffing crisis. At Cheltenham, girls were barred from the infirmary, endured 23-hour cell isolation during a COVID outbreak, and faced harassment: two girls reported in early 2023 that a boy “moved his hand over his crotch and told the girls to perform a sexual favor.” One girl said, “It’s so crazy here. It’s so hard to concentrate in school because it is so loud, and loud noises are my trigger,” while a pregnant girl who was assaulted twice stated, “Me and my child feel threatened.” JJMU concluded, “Relegating detained girls and young women to a single unit in a secure detention facility set up to serve boys and young men … demonstrates a casual disregard for the well-being of girls in DJS custody.”

DJS says WMCC staff are being trained in “gender-responsive programming and trauma-informed care,” but advocates remain skeptical. “We would prefer that the girls not be incarcerated in the first place,” said advocate Moroney, “but … having their own place is a better situation than being shoehorned into a boys’ place.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the state juvenile services department's handling of detained girls, facility moves, and related safety, mental health, and policy issues, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Hurricane Milton tests Tampa Bay’s Indian blessing, ‘Bay of the Holy Spirit’ legends; Storm projected to hit near Sarasota
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Belgrade News
content:
Hurricane Milton is testing long-standing Tampa Bay legends that the area is divinely shielded from direct hurricane hits. Local lore holds that the ancient Tocobaga Native Americans placed a protective blessing over the bay, reinforced in 1539 when Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto christened it “Bahia Espiritu Santo — Bay of the Holy Spirit.” Tampa has not taken a direct strike since 1921, and many residents cite storms that suddenly veer away.

As the Category-4 system—packing 155-mph winds—barrels toward Florida for an early-Thursday landfall, forecast models show the center coming ashore south of Tampa Bay, possibly near or below Sarasota. That track would spare the region the worst surge, though Tampa, St. Petersburg and Pinellas County remain in the cone for “high winds, power outages, possible tornadoes, thunderstorms and downpours.”

The legend still resonates. “I kind of believe it,” said Kristen Hendry, who lives in Brandon near Tampa. “I’ve seen weird things happen with other hurricanes. Storms will turn.” Faith is not stopping preparations: “We’re definitely getting ready,” she said. On Monday, St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Cathedral’s Fr. Athanasios Haros and Fr. Fanis went to the Gulf shore, where Haros said they were on the Gulf of Mexico shores to bless the waters and ask for blessing and protections.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an imminent hurricane, its projected impacts, safety warnings, and community preparedness, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Kristen Hendry, Brandon resident
Father Athanasios Haros, St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Cathedral
Father Pappa Fanis, St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Cathedral

title: Stranded boater rescued by MSP aviation crew
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
A Maryland State Police aviation crew helped rescue a 22-year-old man early Thursday morning after the boat he was operating ran aground, stranding him on a small island in Dorchester County.

MSP's Trooper 7, which is based at St. Mary's Airport, was dispatched to the area of Taylors Island around 12:40 a.m. Thursday for a report of a missing boater. "The request came from the Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department after they had exhausted efforts searching for the subject by boat."

Shortly after Trooper 7 arrived in the area, they located the victim in his boat that had run aground in a marshy area. Trooper 7 guided ground rescue crews to the victim location, but conditions proved to be inaccessible by foot or boat.

MSP's Trooper 2, which is based at Joint Base Andrews, was dispatched at about 1:20 a.m. to assist with a hoist extraction and take over rescue operations. Once overhead, the pilots on Trooper 2 hovered the Leonardo AW-139 helicopter approximately 50 feet above the marshy terrain while a trooper/paramedic was lowered below to assess the victim. The victim was extracted utilizing the air-lift rescue vest. The trooper/paramedic and victim were hoisted back into the aircraft.

Trooper 2 then landed at a landing zone established by the Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department, where the victim was transferred to ground paramedics for a secondary evaluation. The victim ultimately did not require treatment or transport.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a rescue operation conducted by Maryland State Police aviation crew and local fire/EMS, which falls squarely under public safety activities such as search and rescue.

people: 22-year-old man, stranded boater
organizations: Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department

title: Glen Burnie man sentenced for role in Eastern Shore Hospital Center escape
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Israel Labastida Jr., 20, of Glen Burnie, was sentenced Friday in Dorchester County Circuit Court to an effective 12-year prison term for helping 20-year-old psychiatric patient Darrin Jeter escape from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center on Aug. 1, 2023. Labastida received 25 years with all but eight suspended for first-degree assault, 10 years with all but five suspended for use of a firearm in a violent crime, and a fully suspended five-year term for first-degree conspiracy to escape; he will get credit for one year already served and must serve five years of supervised probation.

Judge Karen Dean imposed conditions that include mental-health and substance-abuse evaluations and treatment, abstention from alcohol and drugs, staying away from the Cambridge facility, and no contact with Jeter. Dean said she was “taken aback” by the state’s “lenient” recommendation of five years without parole, adding, “although I feel for Labastida's family and the pain they have been going through, I also feel for the people that were at the psychiatric facility on the day of the escape.”

Prosecutors said Labastida shot into a window several times, kicked out the glass with Jeter—who has schizophrenia and was committed to the hospital—and fled in a black vehicle; Jeter was caught the next day in Montgomery County and later sentenced to 10 years with eight suspended. Evidence of an escape plan was uncovered during the investigation.

Defense attorney Marvin Ochoa told the court Labastida “is sorry for his actions and is ashamed and embarrassed,” withdrew from family in middle school and “started hanging out with the ‘wrong’ crew,” and when he helped with the escape “his brain wasn't fully developed and didn't realize the consequences of his actions, including the ‘pain and suffering’ it would cause his family.” Ochoa added Labastida has “a lot to give to this world” and “just needs guidance and support.”

Labastida told Judge Dean, “There was no reason for me to do what I did on Aug. 1 2023, but there is also no reason for my life to be ‘stunted.’ I believe I can be a productive member of society.” His mother, Patricia Sanchez, said, “He has learned a lesson,” and lamented, “We should (have been) getting ready to go to a graduation or something else, not to this.” His brother Nicholas Sanchez said Labastida “is a hard worker and that with the right guidance, he can become a productive member of society.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and court proceedings, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Man killed after shooting at Baltimore County police
content:
PARKVILLE — “Baltimore County Police were called to the home in Parkville to check on a domestic disturbance and heard a woman screaming and gunshots when they arrived, the Maryland Attorney General's Office said in a statement.”

“As officers approached to enter the home, a man opened the door and started firing at them, investigators said.” Officers returned fire: “At least three officers fired back, prosecutors said.”

The outcome was fatal for both occupants: “The man was found outside the home dead from at least one gunshot and a handgun was found near his body, while the woman was also found fatally wounded, investigators said.” Authorities added, “No officers were injured.”

The incident unfolded late Friday; “The names of the people killed have not been released.” The Attorney General’s Office, which is leading the investigation, noted that “the officers were wearing body cameras.”

title: Dorchester County man acquitted of rape, sexual assault charges
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
A Dorchester County jury on Thursday acquitted Toddville resident Jason Groff, 42, of all 10 charges stemming from a Cambridge Police Department investigation into an alleged August assault. Groff was found not guilty of two counts each of first- and second-degree rape, third- and fourth-degree sex offense, plus one count each of second-degree assault and false imprisonment.

According to a September news release from the Cambridge Police Department, investigators spoke with a woman in the hospital on Aug. 16 who reported that on Aug. 13, a man engaged in conversation with her at a gas station. The woman reportedly told police that she and the man went to a Cambridge residence and he made "lewd comments and advancements" on her. Police said the woman reported that she told the man "no" and "stop," but the man ended up "overpowering" her and she was raped. Investigators gathered descriptions of the man and eventually matched those descriptions to Groff.

title: Some political signs vandalized in Talbot County
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
EASTON — Political signs supporting both Republican and Democratic candidates have been vandalized or stolen across Easton and Talbot County over the past month, authorities and party officials report. Easton Police Department Captain Greg Wright confirmed at least four incidents since early September, noting “This is a trend that usually occurs every election cycle. We’ve had two reported to us. One (sign) at the beginning of September and two (signs) over last weekend.” No suspects have been identified.

Talbot County Republican Central Committee Chair Robert Osborne said signs on Dover Street supporting Donald Trump and Talbot Board of Education candidates have been spray-painted or stolen, calling the situation “very frustrating that people don’t want a different view.” Osborne added, “It’s a shame that people have hate in their heart … Everybody’s in our prayers, we just want the election to be fair.”

Talbot County Democratic Central Committee Chair Patrick Firth reported Democratic sign vandalism in Oxford, Trappe and Cordova and issued a statement condemning all such acts: “These acts of vandalism are not just about signs; they are about the erosion of the democratic process and the suppression of free speech. We must hold ourselves to a higher standard, respecting the political views of all citizens, regardless of party affiliation.”

Wright urged residents to avoid placing signs too close to their homes and to report any vandalism. “Be vigilant. Report it if it happens to them. If for any reason, it gives us an idea if we need to concentrate on a certain area, or just so we know what’s going on. Because people are entering your property to commit a crime, and that should be concerning.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on vandalism of political signs, a criminal act investigated by police, making public safety the primary focus, with secondary relevance to local government and elections.

Robert Osborne, Chair, Talbot County Republican Central Committee
Patrick Firth, Chair, Talbot County Democratic Central Committee

title: No small feat
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
CASA of the Mid-Shore is recruiting volunteers to serve as court-appointed special advocates for children in Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne’s and Talbot counties who have been placed under court protection because of abuse, neglect or abandonment. “This is not something you just sign up for Saturday and show up if you can,” CASA of the Mid-Shore Volunteer Coordinator Jane Crawford said. After a lengthy application, interview and eight training sessions, volunteers are sworn in as officers of the court and assigned to one case at a time, often following children placed outside the four-county area.

Executive Director Robin Davenport called the work “heroic,” explaining that a CASA’s role is to “go around and soak up every bit of information you can about the child. Wring the sponge out. Figure out what is important for us to be paying attention to and bringing to the court’s attention.” Talbot County volunteer Janet Healy, a former educator who joined in 2008, said, “And it just seemed like the right fit.” She finds reward in “(building relationships) with kids, with foster parents, with social workers,” and still receives photos from an adoptive mother of siblings she advocated for four years ago: “That’s very rewarding to get some of that feedback. To see how well some of these kids are doing.”

Davenport noted that consistency matters because “the CASA volunteers end up kind of being the one consistent adult in these children’s lives,” adding, “Foster care is not a short turnaround usually. So it’s been really exciting for us to see that the CASAs themselves are not only helping the judge, but they’re actually really giving messages to the children that stick with them for years.” CASA of the Mid-Shore, which began 35 years ago serving only Talbot County, will celebrate its anniversary May 17 with a “Voices of Hope” fundraiser to kick off its next 35 years.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on court‑appointed special advocates (CASAs) who protect children at risk of abuse, neglect, or abandonment, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns about child welfare and protection.

title: Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge, Maryland recorded three homicides in 2023, down from seven in 2022. Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd, sworn in January 2023, called the difference progress and credits the decrease to “how the department polices and its partnerships with other agencies.”

Todd said CPD is now taking “well more than double” the guns off the street compared with 2022, averaging one firearm seized per week, and stressed that “being a part of the Dorchester County Task Force, getting support from Cambridge City Council and focusing on community-oriented policing has all made a difference.” He added, “I think a lot of people have come to the table in the last year.”

Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout said, “Every shooting that we can stop is a step in the right direction,” and noted, “It’s just started, but I think they’re building a trust within the community that just did not exist before now.”

Lieutenant Kyle Clark with Maryland State Police’s Homicide Unit stated, “We do concentrate on a lot of collaborative efforts with other units within the State Police and also allied agencies,” specifying the use of “task forces, gang units and gun units.” Clark estimated about 50 % of Cambridge homicides in the last two years have been gang-related and said agencies do “everything and anything” to combat gang violence.

Looking ahead, Todd said residents can expect more data-driven patrols—“patrolling with a purpose” by putting officers “in the areas where crimes are occurring on the specific days and at the specific times they have been occurring”—and the release of crime heat maps. Rideout concluded, “What we have to do is continue working on it and engage the community in working on it to hopefully keep these numbers down.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on homicide statistics, police department initiatives, and community policing efforts, which are core aspects of public safety.

Stephen Rideout, Mayor of Cambridge
Lt. Kyle Clark, Maryland State Police Homicide Unit

title: Lightning strike causes house fire in Toddville
author: Konner Metz
content:
A house on Toddville Road caught fire around 9:30 p.m. Saturday after it was struck by lightning, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. “No injuries were reported,” the fire marshal said in a press release.

The Lakes & Straits Volunteer Fire Company, based in Wingate, was the primary responding department. “The fire began in the living room of the home and was discovered by an occupant,” the fire marshal stated. Crews controlled the blaze in about 20 minutes, and damages are estimated at $35,000.

title: 11-year-old killed in hit-and-run remembered in Elkton
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Eleven-year-old Mesiah Lafayette, who “produced a big barrel of cheese puffs … and happily shared them with every fellow student,” was killed at about 8:30 p.m. on Nov. 16 while trying to ride his bicycle across Elkton Road at Belle Hill Road; the driver allegedly fled but was arrested three days later in Wilmington, Del., and charged with involuntary manslaughter.

Two candlelight vigils drew scores of mourners to the crash site, where speakers remembered the sixth-grader who had moved from New Jersey to Elkton in November 2023. “He was a kind, loving and gentle child. He spread joy through the school,” one Kenmore Elementary teacher said, while an administrator recalled, “He had a bright smile. He hugged people. And he always showed students and teachers affection.” A Kenmore administrator added, “He was a wonderful big brother to his sister. He walked her to her classroom every day,” and a teacher remembered, “I remember how friendly and outgoing he was.”

Spirit Life Ministries’ Rev. Moneira Hawkins told Tuesday’s crowd, “Mesiah was only here 11 years, but he touched a lot of lives — more than most people do in 50 years,” and urged, “His spirit is still alive. He touched every one of you.” After crisis counselors spent a busy Monday at Cherry Hill Middle, counselor Joanne Carradin said, “They had a lot of questions,” and a teacher softly told students, “It’s OK to feel sad. It’s OK to cry. Take a moment.”

Family members—mom, dad, stepdad, 8-year-old sister, 15-year-old brother and sisters aged 16 and 20—stood before a memorial of candles, photos, flowers and a football. Mesiah’s 16-year-old sister, who styled his “adorable hairstyles,” said, “I do his hair … He likes braids, straight backs — I guess you’d call them cornrows.” His stepdad, recalling kitchen dance sessions and Mesiah’s original rap “I Wish I Had You,” declared, “He’s a natural. He has a way with words … That kid was special,” while his dad concluded, “He was a bright light. When he walked into a room, he lit it up.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a fatal hit‑and‑run incident and the community's response, focusing on safety concerns and law enforcement actions, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic.

The Rev. Moneira Hawkins, Spirit Life Ministries International

title: QA, Kent approve regional jail agreement, Caroline not yet on board
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's and Kent counties have approved a final draft of the Mid-Shore Regional Detention Center Cooperative Service Agreement for a new 700 Flat Iron Square Road facility near Church Hill that would house inmates from Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent, while Caroline County has not yet committed. The Queen Anne's commissioners signed off on Jan. 28, followed by Kent.

Queen Anne's County would own the jail and employ its staff, aiming to absorb current Kent and Caroline correctional officers. "The agreement has been a collaboration between the three counties for several months," Queen Anne's County Administrator Todd Mohn said. Kent Commissioner John Price, who made the motion that passed unanimously, said the facility "will be built regardless," with bed count the main change if Caroline withdraws.

Caroline officials say they still lack precise cost figures. At a recent meeting, Commission Vice President Larry Porter asked, "Would it make sense for us to engage someone to do an independent evaluation of these operating cost? 'This decision is going to depend on the operational cost and I'm talking long range operational cost,' Porter said."

Each county currently runs its own jail, all either over capacity or in need of major renovation; Caroline's facility is about 100 years old. Maryland has pledged to fund up to half of design and construction costs. Queen Anne's Commissioner Phil Dumenil said the regional and state effort "is a savings for all three counties."

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the planning and approval of a regional detention center, focusing on jail operations, inmate capacity, and public safety concerns, while also involving county officials and inter‑governmental agreements.
