title: American Legion Post 77 looking to jumpstart Hometown Heroes banner project
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
American Legion Post 77 is reviving the Hometown Heroes banner program to honor Talbot County veterans, firefighters and police officers. Joan Harris-Brooks, representing Blake-Blackston American Legion Post 77, asked the Easton Town Council on Monday evening to partner with the group so families can honor their loved ones with banners on Ward 4 roads such as Glenwood Avenue, Port Street and West Street.

The banners cost $200 each, and Harris-Brooks emphasized "There will be no ask of the council to provide any money for the project." She requested the town office hold blank applications for interested families, with additional applications advertised on social media and at Post 77. "It will instill a sense of pride and unity in Easton and for our country," Harris-Brooks told the council. "It is our goal that you grant us approval. And we believe that if you grant us an approval, this will make a landmark for you as our councilmen."

Council members unanimously approved the request, expressing hopes the project could extend throughout the town. Ward 4 Council Member the Rev. Elmer Davis said, "I think that this is a great endeavor. (It's important) that we don't lose the memory of those persons who fought for our country. I believe it's our responsibility to help out with this project. Secondly, it doesn't cost the town a dime."

Post 77 will accept donations to help families who cannot afford banners and will work with American Legion Talbot Post 70, Easton Utilities and the town. Harris-Brooks noted, "I think our children need to be aware. We still have young people still enlisted in the service. I will just very passionately say my uncle was a member of Post 77 … He gave his ultimate self serving."

Following approval, Commander Victor Middleton thanked the council: "When people say thank you for your service, it really lifted me up just now to a higher level. And I thank you all."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community initiative to honor veterans, firefighters, and police officers, which directly relates to public safety personnel, with the town council’s involvement placing it secondarily under local government.

John Harris Jr., veteran and Post 77 member

title: Second fatal crash in three days prompts re-closure of Price Station Road crossover on U.S. 301
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
State transportation officials ordered the MD 405 (Price Station Road) median crossover at U.S. Route 301 in Queen Anne's County closed beginning Saturday, July 26, after two fatal crashes in three days claimed three lives. "This is a safety-focused decision," said State Highway Administrator Will Pines. "This closure is necessary to save lives and make the corridor safer for the tens of thousands of travelers and residents who use it every day."

The most recent crash occurred around noon on Thursday, July 24, leaving two people dead at the scene. Two days earlier, a woman was killed when her vehicle was struck while crossing Route 301, overturning her car; the other vehicle’s two occupants, a 22-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman, were flown to R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in critical condition. Between January 2019 and December 2023, the intersection recorded 76 crashes—62 in the southbound lanes—mostly due to driver inattention or failure to yield, prompting a previous closure in July 2024 and safety upgrades that failed to curb the toll.

Troopers from the Maryland State Police Centreville Barrack, Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann, and the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company all support the closure. "As we did in July of 2024, the department leadership reached out to SHA to ensure emergency access would be available to Fire, EMS, and Police units responding to emergency calls on the east side of Route 301," the fire company said, adding, "We have been assured by SHA leadership that they intend to use the same process as before and that emergency access will be available. While this will create a slight delay in response times, we appreciate the willingness of SHA to work with us to keep those delays as short as possible while long-term solutions for the crossover are worked."

Sen. Steve Hershey echoed the urgency: "Given the dangerous track record at this intersection — and now two fatal accidents in just three days — it is clear that further action is urgently needed. While I understand the temporary inconvenience to motorists, public safety must come first." Emergency vehicle access will be maintained, and alternate crossovers are available at MD 19 (Roberts Station Road) two miles north and Hayden Clark Road 1.7 miles south while the Maryland State Police Crash Team investigates both crashes.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on fatal traffic crashes and the decision by state transportation officials to close a hazardous road crossover to protect travelers, emphasizing safety measures and emergency response—core aspects of public safety.

Gary Hofmann, Queen Anne's County Sheriff

title: North East mom, boyfriend charged in murder of toddler
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Maryland State Police have charged Darrian Lynelle Randle, of North East, with first- and second-degree murder in the death of her 3-year-old daughter, Nola Dinkins. Her boyfriend, Cedrick Antoine Britten, 44, also of North East, is charged as an accessory and is being held in the Cecil County Detention Center on a $75,000 bond.

Dinkins’ body — described in charging documents as “consistent with an emaciated child and were completely wrapped in saran (sic) wrap” — was discovered inside a blue suitcase in the unit block of Dune Drive. Randle and Dinkins had been living in Britten’s Elk Nest Road home, sharing a room, when the alleged crime occurred. Charging documents state Randle beat the child 15–20 times Monday with a belt; when the toddler fell and stopped breathing, “Randle stated that Britten attempted CPR ... but eventually realized (Nola Dinkins) was deceased.”

Afterward, “Randle stated that once they returned to the residence she placed (the body) in a dark blue suitcase belonging to Britten,” where it stayed overnight on the basement stairs. Britten later told investigators he removed the suitcase and sent Randle a photo of a park. On Tuesday, Randle falsely reported to New Castle County Police that the child had been kidnapped at gunpoint; while officers searched, Britten showed “little to no reaction” to news of the missing child. Detectives noticed a strong bleach odor inside the home and recovered blue nitrile gloves in the trash and in the shared bedroom. Dinkins’ body was ultimately located—still in the suitcase—on a vacant lot near Britten’s house.

Randle, held in Delaware on a $1 million bond for filing a false report, now faces Maryland charges including first- and second-degree murder, assault, reckless endangerment, child abuse resulting in death, neglect, failure to report a child death, and unauthorized disposal of a body. Britten is charged with eight counts, among them accessory after the fact to murder, neglect of a minor, unauthorized disposal of a body, and failure to report a child’s death. The body has been sent to the Office of the Medical Examiner; police have not announced when Randle will be extradited from Delaware to Maryland.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal homicide, police investigation, and court charges, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Severe thunderstorm causes 'numerous' power outages
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
A severe thunderstorm that swept across the Mid-Shore on Friday evening—lasting only about 30 minutes—knocked out electricity to thousands. Easton Utilities announced on Facebook that “Crews are responding to numerous power outages scattered across our service territory,” adding that restoration would begin once the extreme weather passed. Delmarva Power reported more than 7,500 of its customers in the Salisbury area lost power.

The National Weather Service said the storm produced wind gusts up to 80 mph and hail. APG Chesapeake Regional President Orestes Baez noted that traffic on Ocean Gateway was “snarled as weekend drivers were not sure how to navigate the waves of wind and rain.” Talbot County Emergency Services had not released damage details by the newspaper’s print deadline.

title: Ridgely man indicted on rape, sex offense charges
author: Natalie Jones
content:
A 26-year-old Ridgely man was indicted Jan. 18 in Caroline County in connection to an alleged sexual assault in 2012. Rhett Ritter is facing second-degree rape; second-, third- and fourth-degree sex offenses and second-degree assault charges related to the incident. According to the indictment, the charges stem from a situation involving another minor, which is alleged to have occurred in January 2012 in Ridgely. Ritter was arrested Monday. He was initially ordered held without bond.

At a bail review Tuesday afternoon, Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin said he wasn't opposed to supervised release, saying "he didn't think Ritter was a danger to himself or the alleged victim." Ritter's defense attorney Chris Jennings advocated for release without supervision, pointing out "Ritter's lack of criminal history and unlikelihood of being a flight risk or danger to the community." Jennings also noted that "Ritter also would have been 14 years old at the time of the incident." Ritter is a founding member and the CEO of Purple Peake CBD in Denton. Mentioning Ritter's strong ties to the community and employment status, Caroline County Circuit Judge Heather Price ruled to release him on a $10,000 unsecured bond. Ritter is set to appear for a scheduling conference in Caroline County Circuit Court on Feb. 21.

title: Bradford House resident wants to feel safe at home after multiple assaults
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Tena Cheaton, 59, moved into Cambridge’s subsidized Bradford House Apartments five years ago while homeless and awaiting disability benefits. “So I wanted to come,” she recalled. “I didn’t realize it was this bad.”

Since then Cheaton—who has PTSD, ADHD, bipolar disorder, fibromyalgia and spinal problems—says she has been assaulted, threatened and robbed on the property. About two years ago, she states, “I was raped by a man who was staying with another tenant at Bradford House.” Cheaton says the assault occurred inside her own apartment, that she knew the man, and that “He drugged her before raping her.” After weeks of “throwing up constantly” and “crying uncontrollably,” she entered rehab on her therapist’s advice that “she didn’t have to face her assaulter in the Bradford House halls everyday.” Although she never called police, she later obtained a restraining order, yet “would still see her rapist in the halls at Bradford House.”

Cheaton reports she is “not the only tenant that has been raped in the building” and describes other dangers: she has “been held at knifepoint, threatened and assaulted on the property.” One night, after taking her dog outside, “I had just shut that door,” she remembers. “And somebody standing way down there at the end of the building was hollering at me.” The man demanded she leave the door open; when she refused, “he got in her face and threatened to shoot her” before disappearing before police arrived. Cambridge Police data show 18 threat-related calls among 1,099 total calls for service to Bradford House from Aug. 1, 2021, to Feb. 21, 2024.

Following that incident, Cheaton moved out for a month to live with her daughter. “To stay sober in a building like this is very, very difficult,” she said. Millennia Housing Management, which runs the complex, stated it “sends violations to anyone residing at the property that is the cause of an assault or theft,” and federal Violence Against Women Act provisions allow victims to request emergency transfers or remain in their subsidized homes while perpetrators can be evicted.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on assaults, threats, and safety concerns within a housing complex, referencing police reports and victim protection measures, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Easton man sentenced on child pornography charges
author: Konner Metz
content:
An Easton man has received a year-and-a-half sentence on child pornography charges. Darian Braun, 23, was arrested in September, 2024. He pleaded guilty in February to six counts of promoting and distributing child pornography. During the plea hearing, Braun said he pleaded guilty because he was guilty and it was in his best interest.

On June 26, Judge Philip Cronan handed down a five-year sentence with all but one year, five months and 29 days suspended. That nearly 18-month term began June 26. Braun was previously charged on 34 total counts — 17 for promoting and distributing child pornography, and the other 17 for possessing child pornography. As part of the six-count plea agreement, the state did not prosecute the remaining 28 charges.

At the February plea hearing, prosecutors said the Easton Police Department received a tip last year from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children about a person possessing child sexual abuse material. Investigators identified that person as Braun, prosecutors said. Braun will be registered as a tier II sex offender. He is under five years supervised probation among a number of other conditions.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case and sentencing for child pornography, which falls under public safety concerns rather than sports, education, or other categories.

title: Talbot County man convicted of sexually assaulting a child
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Kevin Halmiton Manning, 34, was convicted of sexually assaulting a 3-year-old child in Talbot County. Manning pleaded guilty to 10 counts between two cases in the Circuit Court for Talbot County.

In the first case, Manning pleaded guilty to a felony third-degree sex offense, which involved the 3-year-old. In the second case, Manning pleaded guilty to two counts of witness intimidation, two counts of electronic communication harassment and five counts of violation of a protective order. The counts in the second case were committed against the child's mother.

Manning's pleas followed an investigation by the Easton Police Department, Talbot County Department of Social Services and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office. The case was prosecuted by Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel. Sentencing is scheduled for July 24.

title: Two arrested in separate child-abuse cases
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstien@chespub.com
content:
The Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office announced two arrests in separate child-abuse investigations. On Sept. 18, deputies arrested Robert Wolfe, 59, of Stevensville, after the Fulton County Sheriff's Office in Hickman, Kentucky, contacted them about a full-extradition warrant for three counts of first-degree sexual abuse of a child younger than 12. Fulton County authorities advised that Wolfe had been entered into the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) database, the sheriff's office said. He was charged as a fugitive from justice and held pending extradition to Kentucky.

"This case highlights the value of interagency cooperation," public information officer Kaitlyn Briselli said in a statement. "By working closely with our partners in other jurisdictions, we were able to locate and apprehend a fugitive whose actions threatened the safety of our community and, most importantly, our children."

In an unrelated case, Jamie Lee Overton Jr., 23, of Essex, was arrested on Sept. 24 in Baltimore and held without bond. The investigation began Aug. 30 when a county resident alleged an unknown adult male contacted their child, younger than 12, for sexual purposes. After reviewing evidence, investigators obtained a warrant Sept. 19 charging Overton with sexual solicitation of a minor, two counts of child pornography and two counts of obscene telephone misuse.

Because the investigation is ongoing, the sheriff's office said it could not release specifics on how the child was contacted. Detectives are reviewing evidence to determine whether additional victims may be involved. Anyone with information is asked to contact Detective Cpl. Parker at gparker@qac.org or call the anonymous tip line at 410-758-6666.

title: Police investigating serious rollover crash outside Trappe
author: Konner Metz
content:
At around 4:30 a.m. Tuesday, the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to an accident in the area of Chloras Point Road and Claylands Road, according to a press release. The vehicle involved was "150 yards from the road and rolled over multiple times," police said.

Authorities say "a passenger was ejected from the vehicle and sustained life-threatening injuries." Police said the passenger was then taken to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton and later transferred to a shock trauma center in Baltimore.

The 18-year-old driver, Ellis Newcomb, "refused treatment at the scene," according to the press release. The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is actively investigating the crash and asks anyone with information to contact them at 410-822-1020.

title: Police arrest Dorchester County man on rape, sexual assault charges
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Jason Groff, 41, of Toddville was arrested just after 11 a.m. Monday by the Cambridge Police Department with assistance from the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office. Police had obtained information that Groff was heading to Cambridge from Toddville, about 20 miles south, and located him northwest of Toddville around the Lakesville area. He is being held without bond in the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on two counts each of first- and second-degree rape, third- and fourth-degree sex offense, plus one count each of second-degree assault and false imprisonment.

The charges stem from an Aug. 13 incident that Cambridge police began investigating on Aug. 16 after contacting a female victim in the hospital. She reported that after pulling into a gas station to inflate a tire, a man engaged her in conversation and they went to a Cambridge residence where, according to the release, “the male subject was reported to making lewd comments and advancements on the female victim.” The release states, “The female repeatedly told the male subject ‘No’ and to ‘Stop,’” and that “the male subject ended up reportedly overpowering the female victim and she ended up being raped.”

Investigators gathered descriptions of the subject, and on Aug. 27 an officer matched them to Groff. Detectives interviewed Groff on Aug. 28, and an arrest warrant was issued Aug. 29. The investigation revealed Groff is a registered sex offender on probation with restrictions. The investigation is ongoing; anyone with information is asked to contact the Cambridge Police Department’s Criminal Investigations Division at 410-901-8457.

title: Political vandalism reported in Easton ahead of Election Day
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Easton residents reported political sign vandalism in the days before the 2024 general election. Sandra Chappell said that on Monday her two yard signs backing Vice President Kamala Harris and Angela Alsobrooks were removed from her yard and discarded elsewhere. The incident, she noted, left her “surprised and concerned over political vandalism.”

Chappell emphasized respect for differing views, saying, “It’s just not right. You can have different opinions, but you should also respect the fact that others do too, and it doesn’t mean that the other side from wherever a person is bad, it just means that they differ with you and their opinions, because that should be a part of life.” The next day she saw close to 20 signs—mostly for Harris and Talbot County Board of Education candidate Candace Henry—vandalized and thrown in a pile. She reported both incidents to Easton Police.

Easton Police Department Captain Greg Wright noted that in September there had been reports of at least four signs damaged or stolen, with more reports since. Talbot County Sheriff’s Office Captain John Bollinger said reported vandalism of political signs and other property has noticeably decreased compared with previous years.

title: Easton police officer found guilty of misconduct
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
EASTON — An Easton police officer was found guilty on Tuesday of misconduct in office. Sgt. Jason Dyott, 38, was convicted of two separate instances of engaging in physical sexual conduct with two different teenage girls while on duty. Judge C. Carey Deeley Jr. found Easton Police Department Dyott guilty on two counts of misconduct in office.

During opening statements of the trial, Senior Assistant State Prosecutor Mary Setzer said that in the fall of 2022, Dyott engaged in physical acts with two teenage girls in separate instances. She said that on Nov. 11, Dyott picked up an 18-year-old from her friend's house in his police vehicle and had sex with her in the vehicle while on duty. Setzer said that two days later, Dyott met with a 17-year-old in the Target parking lot while he was on duty and made out with her.

Dyott's defense attorney Shaun Owens said during opening statements that Dyott is not denying the relationships with the teenagers. Owens said the conduct was not criminal, however, and that he does not believe there is evidence to support that Dyott's actions constituted misconduct. Owens said that in any profession, Dyott could have engaged in the exact same behavior. During closing arguments, Owens brought up that the radio call, which the then-18-year-old talked about during testimony. He said that it was not clear what the call was about, if it was for Dyott specifically or if it required Dyott's response.

Deputy State Prosecutor Sarah David said that in the two incidents, Dyott acted in his official capacity. Not only was he on duty, she said, but he was presenting himself to the public and to the teenage girls as an officer. A sentencing hearing is set for Nov. 1. According to a news release from the Office of the State Prosecutor, State Prosecutor Charlton T. Howard III said, "Law enforcement officers who abuse the power of their position, and betray the trust of the community, must be held accountable."

Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said Dyott is suspended with pay. He has been suspended with pay since the beginning stages of the investigation in 2023. According to a Wednesday press release, "upon this conviction, the Easton Police Department will now seek to impose the appropriate administrative penalties upon Mr. Dyott."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police officer's misconduct and conviction, which directly relates to public safety concerns and law enforcement accountability.

title: Talbot Police Accountability Board gears up for first annual report
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
The Talbot County Police Accountability Board is preparing to submit its first annual report to the Talbot County Council by Dec. 31, 2023. The Board, which “receives complaints of police misconduct, meets with law enforcement officials and reviews outcomes of disciplinary matters,” will use the report to “identify trends in police disciplinary processes and recommend policy changes that would improve police accountability in Talbot County,” as well as include “the number of complaints submitted by members of the public.”

Between January and August, the Administrative Charging Committee “has received 14 complaints,” according to the Talbot County Office of Law. At the Board’s Nov. 14 meeting, top law enforcement officials offered input for the report. Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble asked the Board “to include details on the amount of time local law enforcement agencies are spending on handling complaints, adding that it’s an added workload for his office.” Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey “said he appreciated how the Administrative Charging Committee’s opinions were reasoned out, though he believed some things were mischaracterized,” and also said “the ‘year and a day’ issue needed to be addressed.” State law requires “that a determination on whether or not an officer should be administratively charged be made within a year and a day of a complaint being made,” a rule local officials have raised concerns about in the context of parallel criminal investigations. Police Accountability Board Chair Mitch Ettinger “agreed to address the issue in the report,” with further discussion scheduled for the Dec. 19 meeting.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the Talbot County Police Accountability Board, its oversight of police misconduct complaints, and policy recommendations, which directly relates to public safety issues.

people: Sheriff Joe Gamble, Talbot County Sheriff's Office
Chief Alan Lowrey, Easton Police Department
Mitch Ettinger, Police Accountability Board Chair

title: Charges dismissed for Ridgley man
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Charges against 26-year-old Ridgely man Rhett Ritter have been dismissed. Ritter had been indicted Jan. 18 on second-degree rape, second-, third- and fourth-degree sex offenses, and second-degree assault stemming from an alleged sexual assault in 2012.

Court records show the Caroline County State's Attorney’s Office terminated the prosecution and dismissed the charges Feb. 22 because of “an absence of jurisdiction in the circuit court as presently charged.” The incident, said to involve another minor, allegedly occurred in January 2012 in Ridgely.

At a Feb. 6 bail review, defense attorney Chris Jennings noted Ritter “was 14 years old at the time of the incident.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the dismissal of criminal charges by the State's Attorney's Office, which pertains to law enforcement and court matters, fitting the Public Safety category best.

Chris Jennings, defense attorney

title: New commander joins Maryland State Police barrack in Easton
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Lt. Stacey J. Gappert has taken command of the Maryland State Police barrack in Easton, bringing more than 25 years of experience that began when she entered cadet training right after graduating from Queen Anne’s County High School in 1998.  
“You start out as a new trooper and then you make TFC (trooper first class). Then you make corporal, then sergeant, the first sergeant and then lieutenant. There are 23 barrack commanders in the state,” she said.  
“One day I had an epiphany. I knew I didn’t want to go to college. I really wanted to go to work. I had no law enforcement in my family at all. None. I am still here,” she said.

After six years as a lieutenant and commander at the JFK Highway Barrack, Gappert has returned to the Eastern Shore to oversee operations across Dorchester, Talbot and Caroline counties.  
“My main responsibilities are oversight of all barrack operations. I now have three assistant commanders. The administrative staff falls under me — not just troopers, but dispatchers as well. It is a good amount. You need to know your people and what is going to motivate them,” she said.  
Fred Stanco, assistant barrack commander, said, “(Gappert) is the captain of the ship. She is the beginning and the end of the installation. So everything is hers.”

Gappert said she values the cooperation among local agencies: “I love working at this barrack because we have three good sheriffs. The municipality chiefs are great. I have only been back a few weeks, but the troopers and the officers get along great. We all work together.”  
“I think what I am looking for the most would be the relationships with the sheriffs’ departments and the municipalities. We do monthly chief’s meetings. So community relationships and relationships with our allied partners are important,” she said.

Recruiting new troopers is her biggest challenge; the next cadet class is scheduled for late April.  
“It has always been a concern not having enough troopers. We are doing the best we can for right now,” she said.  
“The climate of getting people to want to be cops and troopers, it is exhausting trying to get people on board to do the job,” she said.  
“We do job fairs. We go out of state. We go to schools. The philosophy is to get them when they are young and have them go into the cadet program and then from there get them in the academy,” she said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the appointment of a new Maryland State Police barrack commander, discussing law‑enforcement duties, recruitment, and community safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Lt. Stacey J. Gappert, Maryland State Police Barrack Commander
Fred Stanco, Assistant Barrack Commander

title: Fire marshal investigating arson attempt at Ridgely trucking company
author: Konner Metz
content:
An attempted arson at Murphy Transport in Ridgely caused an estimated $100,000 in damage, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. The incident occurred at the West Belle Road trucking company, where “multiple vehicles” were targeted, the agency said in a Wednesday press release.

The owner “noticed significant fire damage to the interior of one truck” on Monday morning, the fire marshal reported, adding, “He later discovered other vehicles had also been targeted.”

The Office of the State Fire Marshal is leading the investigation and asks anyone with information to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office at 410-819-3500.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire marshal investigation of an arson attempt, which is primarily a public safety issue involving emergency services and crime investigation.

title: Two Cambridge men charged with assault
author: Staff Writer
content:
Two Cambridge men are facing assault charges after separate incidents that came to light when the first suspect told police he had previously been attacked by the second.

Marco Ray Wilkes, 42, was arrested May 30 after officers responded to “the 400 block of Willis Street … regarding a physical disturbance.”  
According to the Cambridge Police Department, “the victim and a witness, both of whom reported that the victim had been assaulted by Wilkes,” told officers that “Wilkes strangled and struck the victim multiple times, and the witness pepper sprayed Wilkes to stop the assault.”  
Police added that Wilkes “left the residence and damaged the windows of the property,” then “fled from officers on foot into a wooded area” before being found “in the 500 block of Edgewood Avenue.”  
Wilkes was taken to University of Maryland Shore Medical Center “for injuries sustained while damaging the windows of the Willis Street residence” and later “transported to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond” facing first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment and malicious destruction of property.

While being processed, “Wilkes told officers that he had been assaulted by Rajame Charaka Zague Cooper, 30, of Cambridge, several days before Wilkes was charged with assault,” and that “Cooper had threatened him with a knife.”  
Cooper was arrested May 31, charged with first- and second-degree assault and possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to injure, and likewise “transported to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local assault incident, police response, arrests, and charges, which directly pertains to public safety and law enforcement matters.

Rajame Charaka Zague Cooper, 30, of Cambridge

title: Three teens charged in attempted carjacking
content:
Three teenagers are facing attempted carjacking, attempted robbery and other charges after a series of alleged incidents early Monday, Aug. 14, in Cambridge.

At approximately 6:23 a.m. on Aug. 14, Cambridge Police responded to the 1400 block of the Cambridge Beltway to a report of an attempted carjacking. The victim told officers he was sleeping in his vehicle in the parking lot when he was woken up by an African American male teenager who reached into his vehicle and unlocked the door. Police said the victim reported that several other African American male teenagers opened the car doors and the trunk and started to rummage through the vehicle. The victim then reported that one of the juveniles started to reach into his pockets of his shorts, demanding the victim's wallet and the keys to the vehicle with the threat of a handgun. According to the victim, he began to defend himself and was then jumped and assaulted by the other teenagers, being punched several times and struck multiple times with sticks. A neighbor saw the incident happening and called 911. Police said the suspects then entered a Ford Edge with a Delaware registration and fled the area.

Police said officers had responded to Walmart earlier that morning to respond to a report of a vehicle that had been gone through. In video footage, police say a small SUV was observed pulling into the parking lot at approximately 5:47 a.m., parking next to a Hyundai passenger car, exiting the SUV and getting in the Hyundai. Footage showed them returning to the SUV later and leaving. At 7:06 a.m., CPD officers responded to the Holiday Inn on the 2700 block of Ocean Gateway to a report of a Kia Sol that had been gone through and the steering column being pulled in an attempt to steal the vehicle. Through further investigation, detectives observed the same Ford Edge pull in the parking lot at approximately 5:33 a.m. Investigators found that the same Ford Edge had returned to Walmart at approximately 7 a.m. Police said three males exited the vehicle and entered the store, allegedly stealing several items before returning to the vehicle and leaving the area. Detectives identified one of the individuals as a 15-year-old from Cambridge. The Laurel Police Department in Delaware told Cambridge police that the Ford Edge was stolen in their jurisdiction.

At approximately 10:47 a.m., CPD detectives were contacted by the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, who advised the Ford Edge had been located in Trappe. TCSO deputies were standing with the stolen vehicle when another vehicle came to the scene, and one of the deputies saw the 15-year-old juvenile in the back seat. Police placed the 15-year-old under arrest for the stolen vehicle. The 15-year-old was also found to have been reported missing through the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office and had an active warrant for his arrest in Delaware. The 15-year-old was later transferred to the Lower Shore Juvenile Detention Center to await pick up by Delaware law enforcement. CPD detectives identified two additional suspects as a 15-year-old male juvenile and a 17-year-old male juvenile, both from Cambridge. CPD detectives have also referred all three teens to the Department of Juvenile Services on the charges of attempted carjacking, attempted robbery, second-degree assault, theft less than $100, rogue and vagabond, malicious destruction of property, attempted motor vehicle theft and theft of $1,500 to under $25,000. Police said detectives notified the Laurel Police Department of the teens' identities so charges can be filed in Delaware.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal incident involving attempted carjacking and police response, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

title: Newark man charged in DUI crash that killed local hockey coach
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Shortly after 10:30 p.m. Tuesday at the intersection of Del. 896 and U.S. 40 in Glasgow, Delaware State Police say Fidel Villatoro-Martinez, 28, of Newark drove a Chevrolet Express van west on U.S. 40, ran a red light and collided with a Dodge Ram pickup heading south on Del. 896. The truck’s driver, 51-year-old Centreville resident David Funk, was seriously injured and died the next day; his 16-year-old son sustained non-life-threatening injuries.

Funk coached with the Delaware Ducks Hockey Club at The Patriot Ice Center in Newark and was involved with the Eastern Shore Hockey Association in Easton and the Queen Anne's County High School hockey team. "He was a father, husband, friend and coach," the Delaware Ducks wrote in a statement. "This season he coached on our Ducks 10B team and worked with the 18U and Lady Ducks as well. He is a beloved member of our hockey family and will be greatly missed. Please keep his family in your thoughts."

Troopers found several containers of alcohol in Villatoro-Martinez's van and smelled alcohol on his breath, police said. After hospital treatment he was charged with first-degree vehicular assault, second-degree vehicular assault, DUI, driving without a license, failure to stop at a red light and additional traffic offenses, and was jailed after failing to post $3,500 secured bond. Police said additional charges are pending now that Funk has died. A GoFundMe page has been established at gofundme.com/f/support-the-funk-family-after-tragedy?qid=5cb41c34e4bcb4cbb075e1484f8fbe89 to help the family pay for Funk's funeral and other expenses.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a DUI crash resulting in death and injuries, focusing on criminal charges and safety concerns, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic.

title: Talbot sheriff's office operating out of new facility
author: Konner Metz
content:
The Talbot County Sheriff’s Office has moved into its new quarters on Mary’s Court in Easton, completing the relocation from the old Glebe Road site during October and early November as part of the new Talbot County Public Safety Complex. Sheriff Joe Gamble praised the facility, saying the new offices are “great” and that his department now has “high-tech” filing and storage systems. “We have an armory in there where we can clean and store firearms, ammunition, which is a very nice space,” Gamble added. “All the spaces are very nice. They really did a nice job with the layout of it.”

The sheriff’s office occupies the first floor; the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services is slated to move into the upper level later this year. Davis, Bowen, and Friedel Inc. and Willow Construction LLC are handling the phased project. Work continues on the rear parking lot and sally port, with the secure garage—where “they can’t take off running anywhere … they can just enter our building there”—expected to wrap up this summer. Once Emergency Services is fully in place, Gamble said the county will host “an open house or ribbon-cutting event,” noting, “Everybody’s really enjoying it … Once everything’s done, we should be in good shape.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the relocation and new facilities of the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, which is a law‑enforcement agency and part of the county's public safety infrastructure.

people: Joe Gamble, Talbot County Sheriff
organizations: Talbot County Department of Emergency Services

title: Ignited fuel vapors cause fire at Dave's Riverside Garage
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Fuel vapors ignited during mechanical work caused a two-alarm fire at Dave’s Riverside Garage Inc. on Main Street in Queen Anne Monday afternoon, according to a report from the Office of the State Fire Marshal.

An employee discovered the blaze, which started inside the garage under a vehicle. It took 69 firefighters an hour and 25 minutes to bring it under control, with the Cordova Volunteer Fire Department serving as the primary responding agency. “There were no injuries or deaths resulting from the blaze,” the Office of the State Fire Marshal confirmed.

The fire caused an estimated $750,000 in damage.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a fire incident, emergency response, and safety outcomes, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Kent recognizes Child Abuse Prevention Month
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County commissioners proclaimed April 25 as Child Abuse Prevention and Child Advocacy Appreciation Month during their April 22 meeting in Chestertown. Department of Social Services Director Shelly Neal-Edwards accepted the proclamation alongside her multidisciplinary team and child advocacy center representatives.

Commissioner Albert Nickerson noted that the Child Advocacy Center in Kent County serves more than 35 of the county's "youngest and most vulnerable citizens" each year. "Preventing child abuse is a community-wide responsibility," Nickerson said.

Neal-Edwards explained that effective child abuse prevention relies on partnerships among law enforcement, social services and health care officials, supporting Maryland laws that protect child victims' rights and provide essential services in public and private sectors. She thanked the commissioners, emphasizing that everyone plays a vital role in connecting victims with resources for healing and justice.

"Child Abuse Prevention Month reminds us of the long-term devastating effects but also reminds us of the strength in the community to prevent the abuse," Neal-Edwards said. The advocacy center planted blue pinwheels, the symbol of Child Abuse Prevention Month, in the Circuit Court courtyard. Neal-Edwards described them as representing "the carefree and joyful childhood that every child deserves."

"Let us stand together, advocate for those who have no voice and work toward a brighter future for every child in our community and our county," she said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on child abuse prevention, involving law enforcement, social services, and community safety initiatives, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

Albert Nickerson, Kent County Commissioner

title: Ridgely man arrested on 2nd-degree murder, abuse charges
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Around 9:30 a.m. Monday, Caroline County Sheriff's Office and fire officials responded to a house on Maple Avenue in Ridgely for a man in cardiac arrest. "Upon arrival, police said it was immediately apparent the victim was dead and had sustained injuries consistent with an assault," according to the report. The victim was identified as 65-year-old Robert Daywalt.

Tyler Davis, 22, of Ridgely, is accused of physically assaulting Daywalt on or around the night of Sept. 28. "Davis is Daywalt's great-nephew, court records indicate." Police say Davis and Daywalt lived together, and "Davis was a state-certified care provider for his great uncle, per court records."

In a statement of probable cause, police said Davis admitted to them during an interview that he assaulted Daywalt overnight on Sept. 28 or Sept. 29. "Davis told police he 'had consumed alcohol and did not recall the event' that night, court records state." Davis said he made a comment he shouldn't have made to Daywalt, "at which time (Daywalt) punched" him. Davis told police he grabbed Daywalt's arms and then assaulted him. "(Davis) advised during the assault, he was pushed into the dresser, at which time he 'blacked out' and the assault" continued, police wrote.

Davis was taken into custody without incident and charged with second-degree murder, manslaughter, first- and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, causing physical injury to a vulnerable adult and other abuse counts. He is being held without bond at the Caroline County Detention Center and is set to appear for a preliminary hearing in Caroline County District Court on Oct. 28.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal incident (second-degree murder and assault) and the police response, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Tyler Davis, 22, of Ridgely
Robert Daywalt, 65, victim

title: Dispute over girlfriend led to shooting, police say - Suspect arrested in D.C. area after massive manhunt
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
The victim of the shooting near Unionville on Sunday was targeted over a dispute with a common girlfriend, police said Wednesday. Stewart Orlando Ray, 37, of Clinton, was located Tuesday afternoon in northern Virginia in connection to the shooting, which occurred Sunday evening. Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton around 9 p.m. Sunday for a shooting victim. The victim, identified as Jahari De'Mon Cooper, 39, of Talbot County was driving near Unionville when Ray passed him and pulled off to the side. As Cooper passed Ray's vehicle, Ray shot at him multiple times, striking both him and his car. Cooper drove himself to the emergency room for treatment, police said.

Police said Ray fled the area in his vehicle, failed to stop for a stop sign at the intersection of Unionville Road and Bruffs Island Road, left the roadway and struck several parked vehicles, disabling his own car. Ray then fled on foot into the nearby woods, prompting a 24-hour manhunt beginning in the early morning hours Monday. The search for Ray continued despite severe storms hitting the area Monday night into early Tuesday morning. Police said investigators uncovered information early Tuesday morning that Ray may have slipped through the search area during the storms and made his way toward the Washington, D.C., metro area. Around 12:46 p.m. Tuesday, the Alexandria Police Department responded to a shooting in the Potomac Yard Shopping Center, located in the 3600 block of Richmond Highway in the city. After arriving, officers learned that the U.S. Marshals task force had found a wanted fugitive, who was later identified as Ray. Ray was shot when the task force attempted to apprehend him, police said. He was taken to the hospital with life-threatening injuries.

Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble expressed his appreciation to the multiple agencies involved in the manhunt. "I am incredibly grateful to the countless state, local and federal law enforcement officers on the Eastern Shore, CARTIF, and the Alexandria Police Department who willingly put themselves in harm's way to make our community safer during this manhunt," Gamble said in a statement. He added: "During these strange times, as the Maryland Legislature continues to make policing more difficult, it is inspiring to know that there are still selfless men and women who are willing to risk their lives daily for all of us, knowing that their every action will be scrutinized by people who have risked nothing and have never known real danger. I can't thank these public servants enough for their sacrifice and heroism."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a shooting, police investigation, and a multi‑agency manhunt, which are core subjects of public safety reporting.

title: Butters makes it back home - Missing cat returns to owners 12 years after being lost
author: Isabella Loy; Stanwood Camano News
content:
On their 29th wedding anniversary, Angelo and Shelley Castellino were driving to their Stanwood, Washington, home when Shelley received two calls from an unknown California number. “We figured was a scam call,” Angelo Castellino said. When they finally answered, “The gentleman said, ‘I'm from animal control, and I have your cat, Butters,’” Angelo Castellino recalled. “I go, ‘Is this some sort of punk call?’”

The call was genuine: Riverside County Animal Control Officer Dalton Churchwell had found Butters in his yard on Sunday, Oct. 3, scanned the cat’s microchip, and reached the same phone number the Castellinos had when they reported him missing in San Diego 12 years earlier, in 2011. “I was astonished, it was kind of unbelievable,” Angelo Castellino said. “We figured that he was a meal for some coyotes.”

With the Castellinos now living in Stanwood since 2014, the Animal Solutions Konnection Foundation covered the flight costs. “We were thrilled to work with the Department of Animal Services to make this reunion possible,” said Carolyn Badger, president of the ASK Foundation. “It was such a wonderful story, and we are very happy to know that Butters is home and safe with his family,” she said.

On Oct. 7, volunteer Larry Rudolph delivered Butters to Seattle, reuniting him with his brother Barnacles and the Castellinos’ dogs, Roscoe and Alita.

llm_classification.explanation: The story centers on animal control, a public safety function, and a non‑profit helping reunite a lost pet, making Public Safety the closest match among the given topics.

Shelley Castellino

Carolyn Badger, president of ASK Foundation

title: Common sense degrees needed
author: Staff Writer
content:
This past weekend, I was enjoying my morning tea when I got a curious phone call. The gentleman knew me by my nickname, and I quickly became a good listener. Trying to place the voice it took me a few minutes to realize who it was a long-time multigenerational family friend. Let's call him Mike. I would later reflect on what an honor it was for me. For the better part of an hour, he regaled me with stories of yesteryear (none, surprisingly, set in the famed bygone watering hole of that name), featuring my father, grandfather and great-grandfather. My eyes swelled as he began to bring the good old days back to life, first in black and white, then in color. Some stories I had had a taste of, but most were new to me. What gentlemen they were.

The conversation brought back memories of my great-grandfather Walter Wood; he was the chief of police for then little old Easton. He called it "my town," and used his platform to serve with understanding as only he could. One quality of old Walter I heard about more than a few times was his sensible approach to life. My dad called it his C.S. (common sense) degree. As it goes, he would leave home after supper, head to the firehouse, and open the door to the locals who needed shelter for the night. Today, we call them homeless. He would lock the door and call it a night. In the morning, the routine played out in reverse. What a novel solution.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the role of a former police chief, homelessness, and community safety, aligning most closely with the Public Safety topic, while also touching on local governance and social climate.

people: Walter Wood, former Easton Police Chief

title: Ophelia a bust but still causes flooding
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Tropical Storm Ophelia brought “moderate to borderline-major tidal flooding” to Dorchester County after making landfall near Emerald Isle, N.C., on Saturday, Sept. 23. “Luckily we didn’t make out too badly with the storm,” Dorchester County Emergency Management Planner Jimmy Windsor said, noting the hardest-hit areas were “the Hoopers Island area, Taylor’s Island and the Wingate, Toddville and Bishops Head areas.” Cambridge recorded 2.61 inches of rain between Friday and Sunday, and Water Street in Cambridge and the road past the Hoopers Island Causeway were temporarily closed; the Sheriff’s Office also tried “to limit traffic through Worlds End Turn,” Windsor said.

The county activated its contingency plan once Gov. Wes Moore declared a state of emergency on Friday. “They had brought a couple Humvees with them,” County Council member Rob Kramer said of the National Guard. “They were just a contingent plan in case we needed them.” Windsor added the Guard did “some pre-deployment area reconnaissance just to make sure they knew where they were going if they had to go anywhere,” though their help was ultimately unnecessary. “I know the [Hoopers Island Volunteer Fire Company] assisted some people with getting back to their residences from places they were at on the island after it had started to flood,” Windsor said, while the Department of Emergency Services received few, if any, flood-related calls.

By Wednesday, “most of the flood water has receded,” Windsor reported, though “there is still some high water areas in the lower part of the county, which is not being helped by the fact that we currently have a higher than usual tide cycle.” He urged motorists to use caution, but confirmed “everything is back open.” Kramer summed up the event: “In the grand scheme of things, this was minor compared to some of the storms we’ve had in the past.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on flooding from Tropical Storm Ophelia, emergency management actions, road closures, and National Guard deployment, all of which pertain primarily to public safety and emergency response.

Rob Kramer, Dorchester County Council member
Gov. Wes Moore

title: MD 405 crossover closure to remain until safety improvement implemented
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
State transportation officials shut the MD 405 median crossover at U.S. Route 301 in Queen Anne’s County on July 26 after two fatal crashes in three days. “The closure is temporary but will remain in effect until a permanent safety improvement is designed and constructed,” State Highway Administration spokesperson Charlie Gischlar said. The first crash, on Tuesday, July 22, killed a woman whose vehicle was struck while crossing Route 301; the other car’s two occupants, ages 22 and 20, were flown to R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in critical condition. A second collision at noon on Thursday, July 24, left two more people dead at the scene.

SHA had closed the same crossover for nearly two months in 2024 after 76 crashes were reported there from January 2019 to December 2023. The agency reopened it after reconfiguring the westbound MD 405 approach and trimming roadside trees. With the new closure, SHA is again evaluating long-term fixes. “There are challenges with at-grade crossings along a major highway, especially as we observe traffic volumes, speed and distracted driving behaviors continue to increase,” Gischlar said, noting that alternate crossings such as MD 19 and Hayden Clark Road “are well-marked with flashers to alert drivers to potential cross traffic.” The current closure layout was recommended by the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Department to preserve emergency access. “SHA is committed to improving safety for motorists along this corridor,” Gischlar added. “We are evaluating larger safety improvements; however, our immediate focus is addressing the safety concerns with near-term projects that improve safety conditions and assist motorists in making good driving decisions.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on road closures and safety measures after fatal crashes, focusing on protecting motorists and coordinating with emergency responders, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic.

title: CHIEF OF POLICE POSITION TOWN OF GREENSBORO
content:
The Mayor and Council of Greensboro are currently accepting applications for a Chief of Police for the Greensboro Police Department. The Town is looking for someone who is "results oriented, has a great attitude, works efficiently, shows a record of success, has a passion for public service and wants to work in a team environment." The successful candidate will have "excellent leadership and decision-making skills, will show fairness to all people, will be proficient in writing reports and handling paperwork." The candidate must be willing to work "shift work, nights, weekends and holidays as needed."

Minimum qualifications include: "Candidates should be Maryland Police Training Commission (MPCTC) certified; must be a US citizen; have a high school diploma and preferably a two-year degree in criminal justice; at least 10 years administrative and senior command experience in law enforcement; and must possess a valid Maryland driver's license." The Town offers "a competitive salary and a generous benefit package including Maryland State Retirement."

llm_classification.explanation: The article advertises a Chief of Police position, directly relating to law enforcement and public safety functions, making Public Safety the most appropriate category.

title: Police: Suspects caught with Molotov cocktail in truck linked to recent homicide
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Three suspects — Timothy Michael Dickerson, 18, of Newark, Del.; Bobbie Sue Perkins, 28, of Elkton; and Xavier Armani Santana, 20, of Philadelphia — remained jailed without bond July 30 after an Elkton officer stopped their green Ford pickup at about 12:20 a.m. Saturday and seized “a Molotov cocktail created with a liquor bottle and gasoline,” court records show. The truck had allegedly “been involved in a recent homicide,” though no further details were available.

Officer A. McGonigle, who patrols the Hollingsworth Manor area, wrote, “I have personally made dozens of arrests in reference to violent crimes and narcotics in this area. Additionally, this area has recently been inundated with violent crime, including a homicide and shooting.” Eight days earlier, on July 18, a 14-year-old was fatally stabbed on Road C in what police called “a pretty strong case of self-defense.”

During the traffic stop, McGonigle noted, “I know Santana and Dickerson to be violent offenders through previous incidents with both of them. Additionally, dispatch advised the vehicle had been involved in the recent homicide.” The officer added, “As I spoke to both Dickerson and Santana, whom I have a rapport with; I noticed they were acting in an unusual manner. Typically, both Dickerson and Santana are very talkative and often joke with me. However, they were unusually quiet and could not maintain eye contact.” A K-9 alerted to the truck, leading to the discovery of an E&J liquor bottle “filled approximately three-quarters with gasoline” and covered by a gas-soaked blue rag, plus a Bic-style lighter “shoved inside the seat cushion.”

Perkins claimed she filled the bottle at Wawa to fuel a dirt bike on her street, then said the bike wasn’t there; Dickerson and Santana said it was on Mallard Court, but “All three subjects were traveling from the opposite direction from Mallard Court when stopped.” Santana claimed “the rag was being used to stop the gasoline from spilling,” while Dickerson admitted he “filled the bottle with gasoline.” Santana’s pants were soaked, which he attributed to rain, though “there hadn’t been any precipitation since about 10:45 p.m.”

All three are charged with possession of a destructive device, a felony carrying up to 25 years and a $250,000 fine.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police traffic stop, arrests, and a suspected link to a homicide, which are matters of crime and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Local program celebrates 10th summer of free swim lessons for kids
author: Staff Writer
content:
For the 10th consecutive summer, the SOS Sink or Swim program is offering free swimming lessons to children across Talbot County, with sessions beginning June 17, July 8, and July 22 at the George Murphy Pool in Easton and the Bay Hundred Pool in St. Michaels. The program, founded in 2014, has already provided lessons to 8,000 local kids aged 18 months to 18 years, according to a release from supporting partner the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum.

"Swimming is an essential life skill for all ages, and it is critical for all children on the Eastern Shore to know how to swim and be safe in the water," said SOS Sink or Swim President Libby Moose. Operated through the Talbot County Department of Parks & Recreation, the initiative partners with CBMM and local nonprofits including BAAM (Building African American Minds) and Critchlow Adkins Children Centers.

"We are so proud to have been providing this service for ten years now," Moose said. "Each year, our generous community steps up to make these swimming lessons possible, and each year, we watch as children learn these crucial life skills. We look forward to many more years of teaching our children to save their own lives." Registration remains open for the 2024 season at sossinkorswim.org/register, with donations of $50 funding two weeks of lessons for one child.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community program offering free swimming lessons, emphasizing life‑saving skills and water safety for children, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Libby Moose, President, SOS Sink or Swim
organizations: Talbot County Department of Parks & Recreation

title: Mother gets six years for Christmas Day fire that killed daughter, 10
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Theresa Ann Moats, 41, was sentenced to six years in prison by Cecil County Circuit Court Judge William W. Davis Jr. on May 12 for the involuntary manslaughter of her 10-year-old daughter, Kyleigh Nicole Treadway, who died in a Christmas Day 2023 townhouse fire at 317 Willow Dr. near Elkton. "It was totally preventable. I'm not doubting that you love your daughter, but the care wasn't there," Davis told Moats, adding, "This is the exact definition of a difficult case. You have the tragic loss of a young person and there his zero intention for this to happen. It's the nature of the charge."

Investigators found the home filled with as many as 35 pets, animal waste, trash and overloaded extension cords powering heavy appliances, with no working smoke detectors; Kyleigh, asleep in a second-floor bedroom, was trapped while the rest of the family escaped. School records showed chronic neglect: Kyleigh arrived at Cecil Manor Elementary reeking of waste, prompting the nurse to wash her clothes and hair, and referrals were made to Cecil County Department of Social Services. "It was the saddest fact pattern I've ever read," Davis said. "Her existence seemed to be miserable and her demise was miserable. It does make me want to cry."

Moats, who received credit for 424 days already served, tearfully told the court, "Living without my daughter has been like a mental prison. I miss her. I can't hug her. I can't play games with her. Life is dull. She was the shining star of the family. Kyleigh was everything to me . . . I can't look at her picture. I wish she was here." Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick, who sought the maximum 10-year term, argued, "The defendant flatly refuses to accept any responsibility . . . The house was in shambles . . . Kyleigh didn't have any friends. No one would touch her. Her only friends were teachers. This child was essentially forgotten," and detailed that Kyleigh "died horribly," with burns over 90 percent of her body and "soot in her mouth, smoke in her lungs." Defense attorney Emily Gillis blamed Social Services for failing to intervene after 18 animals were removed five days earlier, asserting, "There was no shelter plan, no safety plan . . . The Department of Social Services failed. They (social services) would have had Kyleigh with them if they had done their job properly."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fatal house fire, neglect, and the resulting criminal sentencing, which are matters of public safety and community protection rather than sports, education, or other categories.

title: People can get vicious
author: Staff Writer
content:
While volunteering at the Firehouse this week, Catherine Nobles reports being “called a Nazi” and told “You are all sick.” She says volunteers “have been spat, cursed at and given the old middle finger,” and that “One sign holder had a cup of coffee thrown at him.” On another day she “watched a woman in her 70s bend down and give a Trump sign the middle finger,” adding “Real mature.”

Nobles adds that “Two ladies at the tent on Sunday evening felt threatened to the point they considered calling the police,” and concludes, “I thought it was bad when the signs were being destroyed, little did I know how viscous people can get.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes verbal and physical threats and harassment at a public event, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Following lockdown, lawmakers express worry over Capitol’s emergency alert system
author: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service
content:
ANNAPOLIS — After a nearly two-hour lockdown of the state capitol Thursday evening, lawmakers praised law enforcement’s rapid response but voiced frustration over the lack of an internal emergency-alert system. Sen. Antonio Hayes (D-Baltimore City) said he first learned of the threat from “a member of the press” while voting in a Finance Committee meeting; only afterward did a state trooper order the room to shelter in place. “I wish I would have gotten a text message internally before I got one externally, but I think just given the series of events, it is what it is,” Hayes said.

The anonymous call came in around 5 p.m. to Annapolis City Police; Maryland Capitol Police ultimately found no evidence of danger. On Friday both chambers gave officers a standing ovation. “Yesterday was certainly a very scary moment for many, a very intense moment, but a moment when our first responders did everything that they were supposed to do and kept everyone safe, followed protocol and really responded to a very intense situation appropriately,” Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore County) told reporters.

A Department of General Services spokesperson offered no comment on the communication efforts. Sen. Will Folden (R-Frederick), an active-duty Frederick city officer, defended the limited information flow: “The one thing you can’t have happen is, you don’t want to over alert or over alarm the people you’re trying to protect. It’s a necessary element to only provide absolutely necessary information to not create panic.”

The incident came days after the General Assembly signed a Motorola contract for a text-alert system for State House officials; the network is still under construction and was not operational Thursday. “Within the structure we have right now, (state troopers) did an amazing job. I think we all would like a world in which we had a text service to keep us informed,” said Sen. Sarah Elfreth (D-Anne Arundel). Hayes added, “I didn’t even realize that we were in the middle of negotiating a text messaging contract, which I think would have been helpful.” Lawmakers said they remain grateful for police efforts while awaiting the new alert platform.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a security threat, lockdown, and emergency alert communications at the state capitol, which are core issues of public safety.

Sen. Will Folden (R-Frederick)

title: Denton chief disciplines officers after Administrative Charging Committee gives recommendations
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Denton Police Chief George Bacorn, Jr. said in a news release Tuesday that he has "thoroughly reviewed and followed through on" a ruling handed down by the Caroline County Administrative Charging Committee regarding two Denton police officers. The officers were found in violation of Town of Denton police policies in an April 7, 2023, incident that led to a citizen complaint and received millions of views on YouTube. The video shows Christopher Morgan threatening residents and breaking the window of the storm door of a home while two Denton Police officers stand on the sidewalk watching.

The way the officers handled the call for service led Bacorn to request the Talbot County Sheriff's Office to investigate the incident. Their findings were turned over to the Administrative Charging Committee, which recommended discipline based on the Maryland Uniform Disciplinary Matrix, according to the news release.

The news release said the committee recommended a 10 days loss of leave and/or pay for Corporal Mark Snyder. Bacorn said he imposed five days loss of leave and a five day suspension without pay. The news release said the committee recommended a 10 day loss of leave and/or pay, as well as a demotion of one rank for Corporal Ciaran Mayo. Bacorn said he imposed a five days loss of leave, five days suspension without pay and a demotion to patrolman first class.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on police disciplinary actions and oversight by a municipal committee, which directly relates to public safety issues.

title: Transcript reveals final words from Dali crew before Key Bridge collapse
author: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com
content:
Transcript reveals final words from Dali crew before Key Bridge collapse

 June 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 887
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Just five minutes prior to the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March 26, 2024, crewmen aboard the Dali ship were conducting business as usual.At 1:06 a.m., the ship's pilot communicated to one of the Dali's tugboats: "I like my chances if you want to take off."
"Alright — all done here. (Have) safe trip," the tugboat Bridget McAllister responded.
Less than 20 minutes later, around 1:25 a.m., the Dali's command center was sent into chaos as the vessel lost power.
A transcript released by the National Transportation Safety Board in April, which was first reported by The Baltimore Banner on Monday, notes the first 25 minutes of the Dali's voyage as unremarkable.
However, the initial power outage, signified in the transcript by a sound "similar to Automatic Power Change Over Circuit" and multiple blaring alarms that continued throughout the collision, threw the crew into a state of alarm.
What followed the power outage is a series of internal and external communications between Dali crew members, the Dali's tugboats, the Maryland Transportation Authority Command Center. To better lay out the events leading to the collision, The Dundalk Eagle has organized the communications between calls for external help, attempts to lower the anchor and attempts to use bow thrusters.
CALLS FOR HELP
Immediately upon losing power, the pilot asked the second officer and helmsman if they had steering, to which both responded yes.
As the crew attempted to maneuver the ship away from the Key Bridge, the pilot communicated to the second officer and helmsman again at 1:25:24 p.m.
"(Just) let me know if you can't steer," the pilot said.
Seconds after the pilot's command, another sound similar to an automatic power change is noted in the transcript. The pilot then communicated with the AMP Pilot Command Center.
"@[AMP Pilot Dispatcher] have them shut down the Bay Bridge. I just lost steering — not the Bay Bridge — the, uh ... Key Bridge," the pilot said.
At 1:26:10 a.m., the helmsman reported that they were "swinging to starboard." Soon after, the pilot can be heard asking for a "mac boat," referring to the Dali's two tugboats, the Bridget McAllister and Eric McAllister.
"Calling the Mac boats — anybody out there?" the pilot asked at 1:26:38 a.m. Just seven seconds later, the Eric McAllister responded.
"Hey Eric [IMO 9707413] it's the Dali — I need ya over here quick. I've uh just lost power (heading to the Key Bridge)," the pilot said.
Simultaneously, as the pilot called the Eric McAllister, the pilot's command center contacted the MDTA.
"No there's a vessel — I'm calling for the pilot. There's a ship heading toward the Key Bridge. He lost steering. We need to stop all traffic on the Key Bridge," the pilot's command center said to the MDTA Command Center at 1:26:57 a.m.
As the captain attempted to lower the anchors, the training pilot made a call over very high frequency (VHF) radio to alert other ships at 1:27:25 a.m.
"Security call. Security call. Container ship Dali has lost power. Approaching the Key Bridge — I repeat — the container ship Dali has lost all power approaching the Key Bridge — Dali," the training pilot said.
This was the final external warning call.
ATTEMPTS TO LOWER ANCHOR
After the pilot's command center asked to close traffic on the bridge, the captain can be heard asking the forward crewman to let go of the port anchor.
"Sir I cannot * * *," the forward said. According to the NTSB, the rest of the forward's response could not be made out over shouting on the ship's bridge, marking the obscuring with asterisks.
The captain again called for the anchor to be lowered at 1:27:14 a.m., shouting, "Fast, fast let go port anchor."
As the pilot attempted to use the bow thrusters, the captain continued to command the forward to lower the anchor, imploring the crewman until he received another response at 1:27:55 a.m.
"I tried to open the break. Break is not able to open up," the forward said.
At 1:28:42, the frontman told the captain that he opened the break.
"Let go. Let go," the captain said in response.
After not receiving a response, the captain checked back in with the forward at 1:29 a.m. exactly before delivering what would be the final words before the crash is marked on the transcript: "Let go, yes."
LAST-RESORT ATTEMPTS
The pilot made one final attempt to prevent the ship from colliding with the Key Bridge.
At 1:27:42, the pilot asked the crew if the ship had bow thrusters. According to The Baltimore Banner, the device helps guide ships laterally while docking.
After the crew confirmed to the pilot that the ship had bow thrusters, the second officer delivered devastating news: "No. It's not working."
"Not working #," the pilot said, with an expletive marked by a pound sign in the transcript. These would be the pilot's final words before the collision, which is estimated by the transcript to have occurred at 1:29:06 a.m.
What followed was a story that Dundalk knows well: six construction workers dead and a span that connected Baltimore left twisted in spirals of steel.
As the collision is still under investigation, around 12 Dali crewmen remain in Baltimore. This June marks a year since the crew was allowed to leave the ship, as cleanup efforts, expired visas and maritime law complicated their departure.
To read the full transcript, including the events before and after the Dali lost power, visit the docket at ntsb.gov/investigations/Pages/DCA24MM031.aspx 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details the communications and investigation surrounding the Key Bridge collapse, focusing on safety failures, emergency response, and the NTSB investigation, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Chamber of Commerce partners with Sheriff in fight against opioid overdoses
author: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat
content:
CHESTER — On Monday, Sheriff Gary Hofmann and Queen Anne’s County Chamber of Commerce President Linda Friday began distributing free ONEbox opioid-overdose-reversal kits to 11 local businesses. Hofmann called the kits “an emergency opioid overdose reversal kit designed to promote safety by assuring that individuals have life-saving, on-demand training when and where they need it,” adding, “(AEDs) save lives, and these kits will too.”

Each ONEbox contains two Narcan doses, personal-protection equipment for responders, and an English-and-Spanish self-playing instruction video. Hofmann noted overdoses can strike anyone, not just people with addiction: “Opioid overdoses are not just contained to those with an addiction … but can happen to anyone who may not realize they are taking more prescription pain medicine than is safe.”

Since January 2023 the county has provided 1,488 free Narcan doses with training; schools stock the spray for nurses, and peer specialists meet overdose patients at the hospital. Chamber program coordinator Rebecca Groff said, “The goal is to distribute these kits to businesses throughout the county, regardless of their size,” while Friday observed, “QAC businesses give all the time to worthwhile community causes,” aiming “to give something back to them that could be life saving.”

The Chamber, County Commissioners, Drug Free Coalition, Health Department and Sheriff’s Office are jointly funding the effort; Health Department Prevention Specialist Anna Ashley coordinates distribution. Hofmann is urging businesses to request boxes while supplies last, and Chamber executive director Wright concluded, “This is a great example of the community coming together — everyone working together makes tasks easier.” Businesses can contact Becky Groff at 410-643-8530 or rgroff@qacchamber.com.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a safety initiative—distribution of opioid overdose reversal kits by the sheriff’s office and Chamber of Commerce—to protect the public from overdose deaths, making Public Safety the most fitting category.

title: Solar panel fire damages Chestertown home
author: STAFF REPORTS
content:
Solar panel fire damages Chestertown home

 May 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORTS | Section: Local News 
 
 292
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A fire originating from roof-mounted solar panels damaged a two-story home in Chestertown in early May, according to fire officials.The Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company responded to a structure fire in the 22000 block of Great Oak Landing Road around 5:30 p.m. on May 2, finding flames visible from the roof area surrounding solar panels, the department reported.
"Due to the location and timing of the incident, there was a delayed response," said Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company Chief J. Darling, who arrived at the scene with Kent EMS Paramedic 11.
First responders initially used garden hoses from the property and a neighboring home to combat the flames before additional units arrived. A second alarm was called due to staffing needs and the size of the house, bringing in additional resources including a tanker task force, though some were later deemed unnecessary, according to fire officials.
Fire crews deployed two hand lines upon arrival, with one targeting the roof fire and another addressing flames in the attic. The fire was contained to the second-floor attic and the section of roof containing the solar panels, the fire department said.
The Maryland State Fire Marshal's Office determined the cause was related to the solar panels. Tesla, the apparent manufacturer of the system, was notified, and representatives met with homeowners at the scene.
No injuries to civilians or firefighters were reported.
Eight volunteer fire companies and emergency services from Kent and Queen Anne's counties responded to the incident.
Officials from the fire department advised, "As more homes install solar panels, it's important for homeowners to understand the potential fire risks and how to reduce them. While solar panels are generally safe and highly regulated, like any electrical system, they can pose hazards if improperly installed, damaged or affected by environmental factors." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
