title: Man Arrested In Connection With Shooting, Escape At Hospital
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com
content:
Man Arrested In Connection With Shooting, Escape At Hospital

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com | Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - A Glen Burnie man was arrested Tuesday in connection with a shooting that allowed a patient to escape from the Eastern Shore Hospital Center via a broken window in August.Following a joint investigation with the Cambridge Police Department and the Rockville Police Department, officers arrested Israel Labastida, Jr., 19, and searched his Glen Burnie home Tuesday. Several items were seized from Labastida's home, including a loaded 9mm handgun, police said.Labastida is charged with conspiracy to escape, numerous counts of first-and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, firearm charges and malicious destruction of property over $1,000.Charges are still pending in Rockville for items seized from Labastida's residence, police said.The charges against Labastida stem from his alleged involvement with the patient's escape from the psychiatric facility.Officers from the Cambridge Police Department responded to the facility in the 5200 block of Woods Road just after 5:30 p.m. Aug. 1 for a shooting incident.Security officers on scene at the hospital told police that an unknown person in a black vehicle approached the building and shot several times into a glass window. The unknown person then kicked the broken window out, which allowed a hospital patient to escape with the unknown person in the black vehicle, police said.Police said no injuries were reported at the scene.Detectives from CPD's criminal investigation also responded to the scene and recovered several spent shell casings, police said.The patient who escaped was identified as Darrin Lee Jeter, 19, of Rockville.Police said Jeter had been committed to the hospital center for assault on law enforcement officers in Montgomery County.Detectives continued the investigation through contacting law enforcement in Montgomery County, where Jeter was later located.Jeter was charged with first-degree escape and is being held without bond. His case remains pending in Dorchester County Circuit Court.Labastida was ordered held without bond during an initial appearance Tuesday. A bail review is set for Wednesday in Glen Burnie District Court in Anne Arundel County. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: YMCA fire on Saturday intentionally set, fire marshal says
author: Konner Metz
content:
YMCA fire on Saturday intentionally set, fire marshal says

 January 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A fire at the YMCA on Peachblossom Road on Saturday was intentionally set, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.At around 12:30 p.m., Easton firefighters responded to a fire on the second floor, which took just under an hour to control, per the fire marshal. No injuries were reported.
A preliminary investigation ruled the cause as "incendiary." The fire marshal stated that "subject(s) ignited a small pile of party supplies located on the second floor rear storage hallway."
Normal operations at the Y resumed Sunday.
YMCA of the Chesapeake CEO Robbie Gill said, "it's disheartening to know that that can happen."
"The Y's been in this community 168 years," Gill said Monday. "It serves one in three people. It's kind of a third place where people go. It's a place where everyone is welcome."
The blaze around 12:30 p.m. was the first of two fires at the Y on Saturday. Around 5:30 p.m., firefighters were once again called to the Y, where an HVAC unit was on fire on the building's roof.
The cause of the HVAC fire was deemed to be a mechanical failure. The fire marshal ruled that second blaze as accidental and said it was unrelated to the incident earlier that day.
Both fires caused a combined $50,000 in estimated damages, according to the fire marshal's reports.
Gill said he's grateful the Easton Volunteer Fire Department responded so promptly and that there weren't extensive damages to the Y. Saturday's first fire was extinguished by the Y's sprinkler system before firefighters arrived at the scene.
Peter Hyman, president of the YMCA's board, was on his way to the Y around noon on Saturday when he learned of the first fire. He noticed community members and Y staff gathering.
"The staff was upset. It was an upsetting moment, and I just did what I could to help both in terms of the emotions of the folks as well as the physical reality of the situation," Hyman said Sunday morning.
"When something like this happens, it's offensive on a multiplicity of levels," Hyman added.
Gill said the Y is going to take a look at its procedures and protocols moving forward, as well as continuing to work with law enforcement in its investigation.
The fire marshal's office is asking anyone with information regarding the intentionally set fire to contact its Upper Eastern Regional Office at 410-819-3500.
Gill said the fact that someone tried to "impact the sanctity" of the Y as a community center is "always scary at the time and also sad."
"But if there's one thing about Talbot County and our community, it is a tight group of people," Gill said. "... Something like this isn't going to deter us from continuing to make a positive impact."
Star Democrat editor Wendy Weitzel contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Prosecutors: 80-year-old man who fatally shot son won't be charged
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Prosecutors: 80-year-old man who fatally shot son won't be charged

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 307
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ELKTON — Prosecutors have elected not to file criminal charges against an 80-year-old man who fatally shot his adult son in September during an incident on the family's Conowingo property, concluding that the patriarch had acted in self-defense, according to The Office of the Cecil County State's Attorney.The father fatally shot his son — Joe Berry Jr., 53, of Conowingo — at approximately 2 p.m. on Sept. 24 on a residential property in the 200 block of Mt. Zoar Road while the son was attempting to break into his parents' home, police reported at the time.
During the incident leading up to the fatal shooting, the patriarch's 78-year-old wife suffered injuries, police said. An ambulance crew drove the woman to Upper Chesapeake Medical Center in Bel Air, where she was treated for unspecified injuries that were not caused by gunfire, police added.
"Following a thorough review of the evidence, Maryland State Police investigators determined that the decedent was shot while attempting to break into the home after an earlier physical and verbal altercation with the resident elderly couple. After a review of the current statute, case law, and all information gathered by the Maryland State Police, the Office of the State's Attorney has elected to not proceed with criminal charges. In these circumstances, the suspect was protecting himself and his wife and was acting in self-defense," an SAO spokeswoman explained.
The father was cooperative throughout the investigation, police reported.
MSP troopers assigned to the agency's North East Barrack rushed to scene shortly before 2 p.m. on Sept. 24 in response to a reported shooting, police said.
Firefighters responded to that Mt. Zoar Road property, too, and extinguished a blaze at an adjacent home, police added.
After completing their concurrent investigation, detectives with the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal ruled "undetermined" for the cause of that blaze, the SAO spokeswoman reported. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Police: Couple robbed homeless man inside his tent
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Couple robbed homeless man inside his tent

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man and a woman face assault, theft and other criminal charges after they allegedly attacked and robbed a homeless man inside his tent in Elkton, according to Cecil County District Court records.Investigators identified the suspects as Elkton residents Justin William Hand, 27, and 50-year Brandy Lee Gibbs, who, according to court records, had been "longtime friends" with the alleged victim.
The investigation leading to their arrests and the charges against them started at approximately 11:45 p.m. on Wednesday (Sept. 25), when the alleged victim went to Elkton Police Department's headquarters on Railroad Avenue and told an officer that he had been robbed, court records show.
The man reported that he was inside his tent in a wooded area near the West End Gardens Motel property in the 200 block of West Pulaski Highway, when Gibbs asked him for $20, police said. After the man declined, Gibbs allegedly started yelling aggressively as she accused the alleged victim of "being smart with" her and then ordered Hand, who was standing nearby, to kill him, police added.
At that point, Hand allegedly started beating the man with a "metal blunt object," prompting the alleged victim to hold up a mattress to deflect the blows, according to the charging document.
Then Gibbs and Hand cut open the man's tent with their knives, court records allege.
The man told investigators that Gibbs yelled, "Stop," to Hand and, at that point, the suspects got into white 2019 Dodge Ram and sped away, police reported.
After the suspects had fled, the man realized that his bicycle and $150 were missing, police said, noting that his bike is valued at $150. During the incident, the man's tent and mattress were destroyed, translating to a $500 loss, police added.
Court records indicate that the man told investigators that he was "longtime friends" with Gibbs, whom he described to police as "an older white female of medium build with no teeth." He, however, did not know her last name — only that it started with a "G," police noted.
The alleged victim described Hand as a "middle aged" white man of "skinny build with face tattoos," police reported.
"Due to the suspect descriptions, officers believed the suspect description provided matched those of Brandy Gibbs and Justin Hand, who(m) officers are familiar with through prior contact," according to the charging document.
When an investigator displayed photos of Hand and Gibbs, the alleged victim identified them as the suspects, court records show. Investigators were able to track down Hand and Gibbs and arrest them, police reported.
Hand and Gibbs are each facing numerous criminal charges, including home invasion, first-degree assault, robbery, theft, malicious destruction of property and related conspiracy counts, court records show. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a violent robbery and assault investigated by police, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

title: Lawmakers work toward juvenile justice solution
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Lawmakers work toward juvenile justice solution

 March 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 994
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers are moving toward consensus on changes to Maryland's juvenile justice system, discussing how to address crime by children ages 10 to 12 and get them into rehabilitation programs that can help.The House and Senate have each passed their own version in this effort, and lawmakers are now turning to the task of agreeing on a shared solution.
The main point of contention between the two bills now is whether kids who are being shielded from prosecution should go to programs without Department of Juvenile Services involvement or, instead, go into a Juvenile Services process that would play out in court.
"I think that what it comes down to is both sides want to find some way prior to the child being put directly into DJS, of having a stop on the way before that happens," said Del. Luke Clippinger (D-Baltimore City), co-sponsor of the House bill.
Sen. Will Smith (D-Montgomery), co-sponsor in the Senate, said that in discussions to agree on a single bill, lawmakers will "do whatever makes sense to ensure that, obviously, our youth have the supports to succeed and public safety is upheld."
But as the measures advance, they also differ on the crimes that would trigger mandatory rehabilitation.
The House bill would give kids accused of auto theft or firearms violations for the first time a chance to avoid court by participating in a so-called "diversion program" chosen by the arresting officer. Such a program is meant to offer services and divert a child from entering the juvenile justice system.
The Senate bill would send kids accused of auto theft for the first time to court through an existing DJS procedure, known as the "Child in Need of Supervision" process.
In current law, when law enforcement or a member of the public reports someone as a Child in Need of Supervision, a DJS intake officer can decide whether to refer the young person to services or file a "CINS petition" in court. A CINS petition asks the judge to assess the case and decide on an appropriate intervention.
The amended Senate bill would require the filing of a petition in court, but only in cases of children under 13 accused of auto theft for the first time.
While a judge could choose from a range of options in such cases — such as community-based services, a substance abuse rehabilitation program or an out-of-home placement — incarceration would not be on the table. And if a child did not complete the rehabilitation, the judge could recall them to court.
Lawmakers are also working to address lapses of communication between police and DJS with their bills.
Both bills would require police to file a written report with DJS when they refer a young person to services or take them into custody. The CINS petition required in the Senate bill would also create a written record that would go into a child's case history.
Smith said that by requiring an intake officer to send children before a judge, the Senate bill will allow children "to have the ability to get services and support, but there will be a level of accountability there."
Both bills would specify that if a child repeats the same offense a second time, they could be sent to court with the possibility of incarceration.
Clippinger said he's "happy to hear more from the Senate" but that creating a separate CINS process for children ages 10 to 12 accused of auto theft could create confusion.
"The special kind of CINS, at least how it is described to me, sounds an awful lot like just putting kids at the Department of Juvenile Services," Clippinger said. CINS "has been administered disparately" by DJS, he added.
Even with these changes, the amended bills have failed to win the approval of some youth advocates and public defenders.
"Only one diversion for a kid who's 10, 11 or 12 is not going to solve the problem of whether they're competent to stand trial," said Kimber Watts, attorney in the Forensic Mental Health Division at the Maryland Office of the Public Defender.
When a young person is charged with a crime, they undergo a process to determine whether they are "competent" to understand the court proceedings. During this process, they can only receive services to help them attain competency.
In cases when children are ruled incompetent, Watts said, "then we're high and dry, and we can't get them whatever it is they need."
Both versions of the bill moved through their chambers with largely favorable votes, with support from Democrats and Republicans.
Sen. William Folden (R-Frederick) said that while the Senate bill wasn't "as far-reaching as we would like to have had," it would help hold kids accountable for their rehabilitation.
"That's an important component, being able to have that recall authority of the judge to say that their sentencing and their guidelines have some teeth," Folden said.
Neither bill would change a 2022 law that bars police from interrogating minors before they have consulted with an attorney.
"There are parents that want law enforcement to be in contact with their child and say, 'Listen, you're going down a bad path. Don't do this. This is why,'" said Folden. "That type of candid dialogue is now gone because the officer can't talk (with the young person) even with parental consent."
The House and Senate both amended their bills to move up the work of the proposed Commission on Juvenile Justice Reform and Emerging Best Practices from October to July. The House bill would push back the implementation date of its other measures to January to give some jurisdictions time to stand up diversion programs, while the rest of the Senate bill would go into effect Oct. 1.
Del. Cheryl Pasteur (D-Baltimore County) said she decided to vote for the bill because the House had "ameliorated" penalties for 10- to 12-year-olds. She urged her colleagues to use the commission to prioritize prevention of youth crime.
"We have commissions, and sometimes the seats don't get filled. We don't take them seriously," Pasteur said. "This time, we need to take it seriously." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses legislative changes to Maryland's juvenile justice system, focusing on crime prevention, rehabilitation, and court processes, which are core aspects of public safety.

title: Kent County weighs ICE cooperation amid liability concerns
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County weighs ICE cooperation amid liability concerns

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Will Kent County police cooperate with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement when and if they call? More specifically, will they participate in the 287(g) program, which allows local law enforcement agencies to collaborate with ICE to detain immigrants?Kent County Sheriff Dennis Hickman acknowledges this is a complicated issue, based on recommendations from the Maryland State's Attorney's Office.
A 2018 guidance memorandum states that law enforcement agencies can cooperate, but are not required to do so and could be liable in certain situations.
"As the elected sheriff, I don't want to potentially cause additional liability to me or our county government, but we don't want the same problems that we have seen in other counties," Hickman said in an interview with the Kent County News.
Hickman is referring to the releasing of dangerous criminals back into the community. By refusing to cooperate with ICE, local lawmakers could release a person charged with a minor offense while the federal government has information about a more serious crime.
Although Hickman is aware of liability issues, his first priority is protecting the public.
The issue is politically charged across Maryland and the country. Democratic lawmakers are advocating for eliminating the federal program altogether. On March 17, during the Maryland General Assembly crossover session, Delegate Nicole Williams, D-Prince George's County, advanced a bill that appeared closer to passage.
"We should not be doing the federal government's job for them," Williams told her colleagues during a floor debate.
In the state Senate, Sen. Will Smith, D-Montgomery County, has proposed a "protected spaces" bill that would require guidelines for how ICE carries out actions in sensitive locations like churches and schools.
Several Maryland jurisdictions already have policies limiting cooperation with ICE.
Howard County's Liberty Act prohibits county employees from asking residents about their immigration status and bans discrimination based on citizenship status.
Similarly, in Prince George's County, legislation has been enacted to ban local agencies from cooperating with immigration enforcement.
Despite opposition, sheriffs from Garrett, Allegany and Washington counties agreed to assist ICE, joining Frederick County, which has been assisting for several years.
Hickman acknowledged that this level of cooperation is not feasible in Kent County, not because they oppose the policy, but because it requires additional training and duties without federal compensation.
Most likely, Kent will not enter into a 287(g) agreement but will cooperate while trying to avoid liability and maintain public safety.
On its website, ICE expressed gratitude for the three counties' cooperation in the Secure Communities Program, which helps "identify criminal aliens in state prisons and local jails by running their fingerprints against federal immigration databases when they are locked in the system."
This information-sharing program now includes 21 counties, including Kent.
Matt Elliston, Maryland ICE director, warned that cooperating with the state may put local law enforcement in liability issues, but not cooperating could also create consequences.
In Frederick and Howard counties, Elliston is calling on the U.S. Department of Justice to take action against them for refusing ICE detainers and releasing criminals without notifying ICE.
For Hickman, a balanced approach is best and, most importantly, safest. "Some counties refuse to cooperate with the federal government, resulting in releasing potentially dangerous people back into the community," he said. "Failing to have some measure of cooperation is not in the best interest of our community."
Currently, the county has not been asked to assist ICE beyond notifying the agency before a state release. The Kent County Sheriff's Department has not been asked to hold anyone past their state-release date.
"If ICE has a detainer on someone, we will let them know when they are done with local charges and they are welcome to meet them at the back gate to pick them up," Hickman clarified.
Since the mid-March, there have been no ICE seizures, but one individual completed their local sentence and was then received by ICE. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on law‑enforcement cooperation with ICE, liability, and community safety concerns, which are central to public safety, while also involving local government policy decisions.

title: 'It was all smiles': Cambridge National Night Out brings more than 800 to county pool
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
'It was all smiles': Cambridge National Night Out brings more than 800 to county pool

 August 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 582
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — This year's National Night Out event in Cambridge brought more people, more hotdogs and more smiles."Like many other years, it was another successful year," Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said. "We had tons of kids and a lot of people and businesses and community leaders that came out and all took part. It was all smiles."
Between 800 and 900 people showed up to the Dorchester County Pool on Aug. 6 for National Night Out on, compared to around 600 people last year, Cambridge Police Captain Antoine Patton said.
Patton said all of the feedback he received about the evening was positive. He said multiple children came up to him to thank him and tell him they had a great time.
Todd said all of the positive feedback is why the police department continues to hold the event at the pool year after year.
"I think there's just something about being at the county pool and the kids being able to have the opportunity to swim for a couple hours, not worry about any prices or charges and just enjoy time with their friends and family," he said.
Attendees were able to talk with a variety of vendors, from the Dorchester County Health Department to the Department of Juvenile Services to the Boys and Girls Club. The different vendors offered pamphlets and information about the resources they have available to residents.
Similar to the number of attendees, Patton said there were more vendors at this year's event than in years past. Todd said that number has increased every year.
"And it's good because you get those necessary resources and information that people may not otherwise see or get," Todd said. "It actually gets handed to them. And they can talk to one another and start forming those bonds."
Along with swimming in the pool, listening to the music played by DJ Doc Lane and eating hotdogs courtesy of the police department, a handful of lucky attendees won prizes that had been donated by Paul Davis Restoration. Prizes ranged from a TV, to a Minnie Mouse kitchen set, to a gas grill, to baskets filled with household goods.
"The lady who won a TV actually cried," Patton said.
Not only did attendees get served the 700 hotdogs the police station cooked up, but MidShore Meals til Monday — a nonprofit that provides food for food-insecure children and families in Dorchester County — handed out bags of food, Patton said.
Todd said National Night Out represents what Cambridge police have been trying to do for the last two years: community-oriented policing.
"It's building relationships between the police and the community," he said. "But also (building) other relationships such as (with) Juvenile Services, the health department, the Dorchester County school system. ... Us all working together to build a stronger community for tomorrow."
According to National Night Out's website, the event was first held in 1984. It aims to promote partnerships between the police and community nationwide, as well as make neighborhoods safer. Patton said the event was created with the intention of having a night without crime in every community.
"And what it does is it brings community together and it gives them a live interaction with law enforcement officers to let the community know that we're working together and we support them just like they support us," he said about the event.
Patton thanked Dorchester County Recreation and Parks for allowing Cambridge police to hold the event at the county pool.
"It was a great event and we look forward to doing it again," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community policing event (National Night Out) organized by the Cambridge Police Department, highlighting safety, police-community relations, and public safety resources.

title: Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content:
Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 587
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Children as young as 10 could potentially go to court for auto thefts and handgun violations, under one proposal key Democratic lawmakers detailed on Wednesday and plan to push for in the legislature in coming weeks.The lawmakers propose giving Juvenile Services officers the option to route a young person's case to court if the child is 10 to 13 years of age and accused of these or other crimes — adding them to the list of serious offenses that already can land a young person before a judge.
The proposals are meant to promote collaboration and make the system work more smoothly, Democratic officials said, but youth advocates worry that they will lead to higher incarceration rates, especially of youth of color.
"Right now, juvenile offenders and the services and accountability they need are separated by an abundance of confusion," said House Speaker Adrienne Jones, D-Baltimore County. "Egos, political agendas and arguments over process have filled the gaps."
There must be "accountability for adults in the system, who are charged with administering the system," said Senate President Bill Ferguson, D-Baltimore City. "We must ensure that all parts are working to their highest potential."
Jones and Ferguson joined Democratic Gov. Wes Moore on Wednesday for a public announcement of the proposals, alongside the lawmakers who crafted them.
The raft of changes, if enacted, would toughen a reform law the state legislature passed in 2022. Among other things, that reform barred police from charging young people under 13 except when they are accused of the most serious crimes.
The newly unveiled legislative package would expand that list of serious crimes and lengthen the maximum probation period that can be ordered by a judge. It would also expand the reporting responsibilities of a state agency charged with oversight of the youth justice system.
The announcement on Wednesday gave shape to Democrats' response to pleas for accountability amid spikes in certain youth offenses in recent years. While youth violent crime arrests fell 16.5% overall between fiscal years 2020 and 2023, according to a Juvenile Services report last year, carjackings increased by 85.4% and handgun violations rose almost 220%.
After weeks of talks with law enforcement and advocates, the set of proposals represents a general agreement among Democrats, who control both chambers of the legislature and also hold the governor's office.
But advocates in the Maryland Youth Justice Coalition predicted in a written statement that the "legislation introduced today will see thousands more kids incarcerated every year, particularly Black and brown children, and (exacerbate) the already serious racial disparities in Maryland's juvenile justice system."
As the minority party, Republicans have said in recent months that the reform law leaves Marylanders less safe and also prevents young people from getting the services they need. GOP lawmakers in Annapolis have their own ideas for change, including a measure that would prohibit young people who have committed sexual offenses from attending school in person.
But one key Republican on Wednesday said the Democrats' plan shows they are taking "first steps" in addressing flaws in the youth justice system. House Minority Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, said he appreciates that Moore has put his weight behind the issue of youth crime.
"For him to be able to step in and say, 'Hey, I'm a Democrat. I'm from Baltimore City, but I'm going to step up and say too much is too much and this is a reasonable way to deal with this' — it's incredibly helpful," Buckel said.
Buckel said he also hopes Moore will be able to persuade fellow Democrats to consider other tough ideas, too. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses proposed legislation targeting youth crime, juvenile court procedures, and public safety concerns, making Public Safety the most relevant category.

title: St. Michaels peeping Tom sentenced to 3 years
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels peeping Tom sentenced to 3 years

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 276
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The St.Michaels man previously convicted of being a peeping Tom was sentenced Oct. 18 to just over three years in jail.Talbot District Court Judge Karen Ketterman sentenced Diego Albarado Lopez, 31, to three years and 90 days of active incarceration after finding him guilty of stalking, harassment and trespassing as a peeping Tom.The charges stemmed from an incident captured on surveillance footage at a home on Jefferson Avenue in St. Michaels just after midnight on April 12.The home's residents contacted police several days later after seeing a man they identified as Lopez on their property during a review of previous surveillance footage.The footage showed the man walking toward the residents' bedroom window and holding his hands near his groin area, according to charging documents.The residents recognized Lopez from his March 2022 attempt to burglarize their home.Police said he was caught in the act by one of the residents, who detained Lopez until deputies arrived and arrested him.Lopez was previously convicted of being a peeping Tom and trespassing in May 2022 for following women home and peering in windows.He was sentenced to 4.5 months in jail and three years of supervised probation. Ketterman previously ordered Lopez to not have contact with any victims and to not enter or be found near several specific locations in St.Michaels.Lopez received about six months of credit for time already served in connection to the April charges. Following his release from jail, he will be placed on three years of supervised probation.Lopez will also be required to submit to a mental health evaluation and complete mental health and alcohol treatment. 
 
 Caption: DIEGO ALBARADO LOPEZ

title: Maryland State Police investigating two late-night fatal crashes in Queen Anne’s, Kent counties
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland State Police investigating two late-night fatal crashes in Queen Anne’s, Kent counties

 September 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Maryland State Police are investigating two fatal crashes that occurred late Saturday in Queen Anne's and Kent counties, police said.Around 11:22 p.m. Saturday, troopers from the Maryland State Police Centreville Barrack responded to the area of northbound U.S. Route 301 at Hayden Clark Road in Centreville for a report of a two-vehicle crash involving a motorcycle, police said.
The operator of the motorcycle, identified as Marcus Dangerfield, 20, of Dover, Delaware, was pronounced dead at the scene, police said. The driver of a GMC Acadia, a 45-year-old man, was taken by ambulance to the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center. A passenger in the SUV, a 38-year-old woman, was flown by Maryland State Police Aviation Command to the same hospital.
The preliminary investigation indicates the GMC was traveling east on Hayden Clark Road, attempting to cross northbound U.S. Route 301, when it was struck by the motorcycle for unknown reasons, police said.
U.S. Route 301 was closed for more than two hours for the crash investigation. Assistance at the scene was provided by the Church Hill Fire Department, Queen Anne's County emergency medical services and the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration.
Around 11:55 p.m. Saturday, troopers from the Centreville Barrack responded to Maryland Route 213 and Riley's Mill Road in Chestertown for a report of a single-vehicle crash, police said.
A passenger in a Ford Fusion, a 17-year-old boy, was pronounced dead at the scene, police said. The driver, a 19-year-old woman, was flown by Maryland State Police Aviation Command to the Shock Trauma Center for treatment of her injuries. Three other passengers — a 21-year-old woman, a 17-year-old boy and a 23-year-old woman — were transported by ambulance to University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown, police said.
As of Sunday morning, police had not released the names of those involved in the Kent County crash.
The preliminary investigation indicates the Ford was traveling south when, for unknown reasons, it left the roadway onto the right shoulder, lost control, struck a telephone pole and overturned, police said. Investigators believe impairment may have been a factor.
Maryland Route 213 was closed for more than two hours. Assistance at the scene was provided by the Chestertown Fire Department, Kent County emergency medical services and the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration.
The Maryland State Police Crash Team is leading the active and ongoing investigations into both crashes, police said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chester woman charged in January Bay Bridge crash
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Gwendolyn Persina, 48, of Chester, has been charged this week for the Jan. 27 Bay Bridge crash involving more than 20 vehicles that shut westbound traffic for hours. Court documents cite “causing life-threatening injuries while operating a vehicle, driving under the influence of alcohol, driving while impaired by a controlled dangerous substance and driving on a suspended license,” after the Maryland Department of Transportation Authority Police Collision Reconstruction Unit concluded Persina “was driving at high speeds and erratically, contributing to the crash.”

Queen Anne’s County State’s Attorney Lance Richardson, noting Persina was still on probation for a 2022 DWI, said he asked the court to hold her in the detention center during the Aug. 29 bail review because he believed Persina is “a threat to public safety with her potential to drive in a dangerous manner again if she were to be released on pre-trial supervision.” Richardson added, “The chain-reaction collision also ultimately caused an innocent man to lose his arm in the accident.”

An arrest warrant issued Aug. 27 led to Persina’s detention after the Aug. 29 bail hearing; a jury trial is scheduled for February.

title: Bay Bridge to hold traffic temporarily today
author: Staff Writer
content:
Bay Bridge to hold traffic temporarily today

 June 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 156
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — In consultation with the U.S. Coast Guard and out of an abundance of caution, the Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA) is holding traffic temporarily at the Bay Bridge for approximately 15-30 minutes today between 11 a.m. and noon.The closing is out of an abundance of caution as the M/V Dali passes beneath the bridge on its way to Norfolk. Four tugs are escorting the Dali to provide anchoring support along its entire Norfolk journey.
According to the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff undue traffic congestion is not anticipated on the east side of the bridge.

Travelers are advised to contact 1-877-BAYSPAN (229-7726) or follow us on X/Twitter at https://x.com/TheMDTA for real-time updates during this event.

title: 400 flags placed to honor heroes this Memorial Day weekend
author: Konner Metz
content:
400 flags placed to honor heroes this Memorial Day weekend

 May 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 210
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Rainy and windy conditions Wednesday didn't stop Civil Air Patrol cadets and Easton Rotary Club members from placing over 400 flags in front of the Talbot County Community Center in advance of Memorial Day weekend.1st. Lt. Richard Mellinger, commander of the Easton Composite Squadron, Civil Air Patrol, led a group of young cadets and senior members in arranging the flags, which are easily spotted by drivers on U.S. Route 50. Mellinger said recognizing fallen heroes with the patriotic display is extremely meaningful.
The flag display is part of the Rotary Club's Flags for Heroes initiative, which honors veterans, law enforcement officers, first responders, teachers, health care workers and more. It was started in 2012, and every May since, flags have been erected throughout Easton.
This year, in addition to the community center, flags were placed at Idlewild Park, Aqua Pools & Spas and Londonderry on the Tred Avon.
Rotary Club Secretary George Hatcher said the tradition "has never failed to be something that brings people together."
The Easton Rotary Club has raised nearly $600,000 since 2012 through donations from those who sponsor a flag for their heroes. The proceeds go to local organizations such as the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, Easton Police Department, Civil Air Patrol, local fire departments and more.

title: Case for woman charged with assault of toddler at child care center made inactive
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Case for woman charged with assault of toddler at child care center made inactive

 August 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Crime 
 
 403
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Charges made against a Preston woman for the assault of a toddler were made inactive in the Talbot County District Court at a hearing on Tuesday.In June, Linda Perry, 77, was charged with neglect of a minor, second-degree assault and reckless endangerment for a May 2 incident at Best Buddies Learning Center, a child care facility in Easton.
At a hearing on Tuesday, District Court Judge Karen Ketterman placed Perry's case on the stet docket, making her charges inactive on the conditions that Perry have no contact with the child or the child's family, not provide child care to any non-family member, and complete a mental health evaluation and follow through with any treatment recommendations that come out of that evaluation.
Perry's defense attorney Christine DuFour said a mental health evaluation for Perry had already been scheduled for September.
According to court documents, on May 2 Perry was seen putting a 2-year-old boy on a changing table, spanking him on his bare butt and then dropping him to the floor.
A statement of charges document completed by Easton Police Detective Heather Hanson describes captured video surveillance of the incident. According to the document, in the video Perry is seen picking up the crying toddler and walking him over to a changing table. When Perry puts the boy on the changing table, he cries even louder, the document says.
In the video, Perry can be heard telling the boy, "You better not kick me, young man," and "Stop," as she changes his diaper. According to the document, Perry then lifts both of the toddler's legs and audibly smacks him on the butt, causing other teachers in the room to take notice.
At this point, the toddler is "crying and screaming," the document says.
Perry then takes the boy's left arm, lifting him up off the table. She grabs his other arm and "quickly" puts him on the floor, letting him fall onto his back, the document says. She leaves him on the ground crying and tells another teacher in the room that is what the boy does, according to the document.
In an interview, the parents of the child told Hanson the child might have autism, and they were meeting with doctors to make that determination, the document says.
Two teachers in the room at the time of the incident provided witness statements. One of those witnesses described Perry as "overly aggressive" with the two year old, the document says.

title: Scammers look to lure voters to get information
author: MORGAN LEASON Capital News Service
content:
Scammers look to lure voters to get information

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MORGAN LEASON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Scammers posing as election workers are trying to mislead Maryland voters with fraudulent text messages, prompting concerns at the State Board of Elections.The scammers are telling voters they're not registered to vote in November and then urging them to click a false link to remedy that, according to Jared DeMarinis, the board's state administrator of elections.
"They're capitalizing on the hypertension involving this election," DeMarinis said in an interview with Capital News Service. "The text message is urgent, and they're playing on a fear that an individual is not registered to vote when they really are."
He said he worries that texting scams of this nature could have a sweeping impact on the election, especially if they mislead voters about whether they're registered and eligible to vote.
"The impact of this is to create a new narrative and foster disinformation about voter roles," DeMarinis said.
Similar incidents of text scams have been reported in Illinois, Georgia and Pennsylvania already this year. In Peoria County, for example, text scammers also meant to deceive voters into registering to vote by mail through a false link.
Ensuring the integrity of elections and maintaining public trust are critical issues for Maryland election officials and the nation, especially as the 2024 election nears and texting scams become more prevalent.
As the state elections administrator, DeMarinis is tasked with administering and conducting elections and creating consistent policy and application of the laws in Maryland.
The Maryland board was already working to recruit election judges, track mail-in ballots and secure the local elections. Now, they must also battle continuous threats to undermine public trust in elections.
According to the board, the text scam informs recipients that public records show they are not registered at their address. The matter is "URGENT," the text says. The text then invites the recipient to click a fake link to register before the deadline.
The board's website lists the valid sources for voter registration, polling locations, mail-in ballot status and ways to vote. The board is also reminding voters that trusted information will come from a .gov web address.
DeMarinis told CNS he is determined to combat the spread of disinformation by being proactive on social media. He also encouraged people to contact him or the state board to verify information.
"You don't wait until things hit critical mass," he said, "you combat this information and correct the record immediately."
The board created a portal on its website where people can report instances of scamming and disinformation. DeMarinis said he plans to work with social media platforms to help correct false information.
He said that if scam efforts rise to the level of voter disenfranchisement or suppression, the board will work with law enforcement to ensure that Marylanders are "free to vote, without any sort of undue influence."
As the general election approaches with only 48 days left and early voting starting on Sept. 23, the threat of these scammers remains high. The public must remain vigilant and in the meantime, the board will continue its efforts to combat scams and safeguard the integrity of the election, he said.
"These scams are a direct threat to the legitimacy of the electoral process, because, at best, they're just trying to steal identities," DeMarinis said. "But at worst, they're there to kind of sow distrust in an election administration and undermine confidence in the system." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on fraudulent scams targeting voters and the threat they pose to election integrity, which aligns with public safety concerns about fraud and misinformation.

title: Two arrested in shooting death at Easton bar
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Two arrested in shooting death at Easton bar

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 546
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Police arrested two people in connection with the Saturday, Sept. 30, shooting death ofa 23-year-old man in the parking lot of an Easton bar. Both were ordered to remain held without bond following bail reviews Monday afternoon.With assistance from the Cambridge Police Department, detectives from the Easton Police Department arrested Kevron Chase, 34, ofCambridge and Chadnee Harris, 32, ofHurlock on Saturday.Chase is charged with first-and second-degree murder, first-and second-degree assault, reckless endangerment, using a firearm in a felony crime and illegal possession of a regulated firearm.Harris is charged with acting as an accessory after the fact offirst-and second-degree murder and acting as an accessory after a felony.The charges against the two stemmed from the early morning shooting at the Sidetracked Saloon. Police responded to the bar just before 2 a.m. Saturday morning for a report of shots fired.Officers found a large crowd in the parking lot and a man, later identified as Antonio L. Smith, suffering from a gunshot wound to the head.Two shell casings were found in the parking lot, according to charging documents.Officers initiated lifesaving efforts until Talbot County paramedics arrived and transported Smith to the University ofMaryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, where he was pronounced dead.In charging documents, police said multiple witnesses were interviewed. Multiple people identified Chase as the shooter.Police reviewed the bar's security camera footage, which showed Chase and Harris entering the bar shortly after midnight and exiting to the parking just before 1 a.m., according to charging documents.Further review of the video footage reportedly showed Chase and Harris standing between two cars near the entrance of the bar and Smith approaching the two.The officer reviewing the footage wrote in charging documents that Chase pulled a handgun from his waistband area and pointed the handgun at Smith. Chase put the handgun back toward his waistband area and then appeared to hand the gun to Harris, police said.Smith and Chase began physically fighting in the parking lot, drawing a crowd.Charging documents said Harris walked toward the two men fighting near Chase and that the crowd quickly dispersed. Smith appeared to duck behind a car and Chase walked toward Smith, pointing a handgun at him.The officer who reviewed the footage wrote in charging documents that they saw a muzzle flash from the gun and Smith collapse in between two cars.Security camera footage captured the license plate number on Chase's car, police said. Police shared information with surrounding law enforcement agencies and obtained location data on Chase, who was found in the car with Harris during a traffic stop on Race Street in Cambridge. Both were detained by police.In interviews with Cambridge police, Chase told officers that the physical fight began over Smith trying to rob him several months before, according to charging documents. Chase told police that Smith's friends shot at him, and he fired a single shot back toward their area, but Chase denied shooting Smith.Talbot District Court Judge Karen Ketterman ordered that Chase and Harris remain held without bond during bail reviews Monday afternoon, citing concerns about public safety.Chase and Harris are scheduled to appear for preliminary hearings in the county district court on Oct. 30. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A 23-year-old man was shot and killed outside the Sidetracked Saloon in Easton on Saturday, Sept. 30.

title: Police investigating weekend shooting in Ridgely
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office is investigating a non-fatal shooting that occurred Saturday night around 8:25 p.m. at the Daysprings Townhomes on School Street in Ridgely. Police responded to reports of shots fired and found an adult male with a gunshot wound to the hand, who was transported to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

The sheriff's office said that Maryland State Police crime scene unit responded "to collect and preserve physical evidence in support of the investigation." No suspect was immediately identified by authorities. The county's Criminal Investigations Division is conducting the investigation. Anyone with information can contact authorities at (410) 479-2515.

title: Laurel man arrested for vehicle theft in Easton
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
A Laurel man was arrested on charges of theft, malicious destruction of property and other charges relating to the theft of a vehicle. According to a news release from the Easton Police Department, officers responded to Hertrich Chevrolet GMC on Ocean Gateway the morning of May 30 in response to a report of suspicious activity. Upon arrival, officers noticed a white Chevy Silverado with Virginia plates leave the parking lot, police said.

Officers stopped the vehicle at U5 Foods on Ocean Gateway and detained 20-year-old Donya Jenkins-Patterson. Police said officers noticed the passenger side window was broken and noticed ammunition and equipment that "appeared to be law enforcement-related" in the vehicle. During the investigation, officers learned of a second person "fleeing" into the wooded area behind Hertrich Chevrolet GMC, police said.

Upon arrival, officers said they noticed the passenger side window of a parked Dorchester County Sheriff's Office vehicle was broken. Police said these observations made it unclear whether the suspect had obtained a firearm. With assistance from Maryland State Police Aviation Command, the Maryland State Police K9 Unit and the Dorchester County Sheriff's Office K9 Unit, Easton police searched the wooded area, but were unable to locate the second suspect, police said.

A few hours later, officers were dispatched to the 29000 block of Hawkes Hill Road in Easton regarding a stolen 2024 Chevy Traverse, police said. Police believe the second suspect that got away stole that car due to the close proximity of thefts. Police said it is unclear what time the Chevy Travers was stolen, but said it was later located in the Hebron area.

According to the news release, further investigation revealed the white Chevy Silverado was stolen May 29 from Baltimore around 11 p.m. Police said that items located in the vehicle linked Jenkins-Patterson to vehicle break-ins in Queen Anne's County.

title: Caroline CASA honors armed forces veterans
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
CASA of Caroline hosted its annual Veterans Day Heroes Breakfast at 7:30 a.m. Friday, Nov. 10, at the Denton Diner, welcoming about two dozen local veterans. Executive Director Amy Horne opened the event by declaring, “Anybody who has had the courage to put on the uniform is a hero in my mind.” Pastor Don Reynolds, retired lieutenant colonel with the Maryland Army National Guard, offered the opening prayer, and Horne read a statement from U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin expressing “profound admiration for the unwavering service and sacrifices of our veterans.”

After a short video showing a veteran who serves as a court-appointed special advocate, Horne explained, “At CASA, we really want to honor and recognize our veterans because veterans are people who protect our freedoms, just like our advocates are the people who protect the rights of the children we serve.” She noted her late father, Army veteran and Talbot County Circuit Court Judge William S. Horne, helped bring CASA to the Eastern Shore in 1990.

Denton Town Councilman and former Marine Keith Johnson, who is also president of CASA of Caroline, urged veterans to become volunteers. “Discipline, fighting spirit, leadership, resiliency. We see our veterans as difference-makers in the world. They’re mission-ready,” Johnson said, adding, “Being married to an advocate, I know that those traits overlap.” He emphasized the county’s need: “Our children are underserved and our children live as victims of abuse and victims of neglect every day.” Johnson concluded, “If you’re not an advocate, think about what you can do different this year. The military focuses on protecting our country, while at CASA we want to protect tomorrow’s future — our children.”

title: Jury acquits woman who stabbed two women in neighborhood fight
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
A Cecil County Circuit Court jury acquitted Lacey N. Siple, 31, on Thursday of attempted second-degree murder, first-degree assault and all other charges stemming from an August 30 knife fight on Cedar Hill Circle near North East. Jurors deliberated about two hours after a three-day trial presided over by Judge William W. Davis Jr.; Assistant State’s Attorney Ellis Rollins prosecuted while Assistant Public Defender Denise Winston represented Siple.

Testimony showed weeks of neighborhood tension over one of Siple’s children shooting other kids with a toy gel-ball gun. At roughly 9:30 p.m., an argument between Siple and two women turned physical. Both women, called by the state, admitted they “maced Siple during the altercation — but qualified that they did so after she became aggressive, lunging at them.” One said Siple “stabbed her near the shoulder, causing blood to squirt out from the gash, and then stabbed her in the back as she retreated,” leaving her with four stab wounds; the other sustained arm and hand wounds severe enough that “first responders applied a tourniquet.”

Siple testified she and a friend were “walking to Siple’s home to pick up pizza that Siple had forgotten” when “a mob…descended upon them… and threatened them.” She said moments earlier “four masked men got out of a vehicle and ran toward her children… making threats,” so she was already terrified. “A man punched her in the face, as the mob behind him started closing in. ‘I thought I was going to die. I thought they would stomp me,’ Siple testified.” After being pepper-sprayed she “grabbed her knife and started flailing her arms blindly. ‘I was just trying to get home, trying to get home with my kids. I didn’t mean to hurt anybody,’” she sobbed, adding she never realized she had stabbed anyone.

Cross-examined on why she never called police, Siple said, “if she were viewed as a ‘snitch’ in that neighborhood it would put her life and the lives of her four children in jeopardy,” and “someone simply would snatch” her phone.

In closing Rollins insisted, “There was no mob,” labeling Siple “the initial aggressor” who “brought a knife to a fistfight. She didn’t just slash the victims; she stabbed them.”

Winston countered: “My client acted in self-defense… Every time there was an interaction, it happened outside of her house. They went to her; she didn’t come to them… They brought the fight to her. She just wanted to go home.”

title: Ex-officers sue Ridgely, sheriff over disbanding force
author: Konner Metz
content:
Seven former Ridgely police officers and a civilian employee filed suit Aug. 13 in U.S. District Court against the Town of Ridgely, Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker and others, alleging the defendants “orchestrated a coup” to disband the Ridgely Police Department. The 13-count complaint cites due-process and 14th Amendment violations, civil conspiracy and defamation, and names as defendants Baker, Chief Deputy Rodney Helmer, then-commissioners John Hurley, John Buckle and Anthony Casey, former officer James Joles, the State of Maryland and the town. Plaintiffs, led by former chief Jeff Eckrich, seek back wages, benefits and a court order reinstating the department and its employees.

The department was suspended with pay in March 2024 while the Office of the State Prosecutor investigated; in April the town laid off all officers and staff effective July 1, 2024. A July 2024 state prosecutor report that investigated only Eckrich for “suspected” perjury and misconduct found “no sufficient evidence” and closed the case. The lawsuit contends the probe stemmed from Joles, who blamed Eckrich for his threatened termination in January 2024 and, after resigning, met with Baker and “the two devised a plan that would eliminate the RPD and allow Sheriff's Office to assume responsibility for law enforcement in the Town of Ridgely.” The town has contracted with the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office since, budgeting $493,000 for three dedicated officers in fiscal 2026. Baker declined to comment on the lawsuit, citing legal advice, and town attorney Patrick Thomas wrote that he can’t “comment on pending litigation involving” clients.

title: Queen Anne's County man added to Animal Abuse Registry
author: Staff Writer
content:
Troy Michael Sellman, 37, of Queenstown, has been added to the Queen Anne's County Animal Abuse Registry after pleading guilty to animal abuse charges, according to Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson. Sellman entered a guilty plea in Queen Anne's County District Court on Nov. 24, 2024, for failing to provide proper shelter for a Cane Corso dog, violating Maryland Criminal Law Article 10-604, Richardson said. The offense is punishable by up to 90 days in jail and/or a $1,000 fine.

In August 2024, county animal control officers responded to an anonymous tip about a dog in distress at Sellman's Thompson Avenue residence, Richardson reported. Officers found the Cane Corso tethered with a choker collar in direct sunlight without shelter or water. The dog was heavily panting in critical condition, with an external temperature of 121 degrees when the air temperature was 96 degrees. According to Richardson, officers transported the animal to a nearby clinic where it was pronounced dead upon arrival.

Richardson said Sellman received a suspended jail sentence and supervised probation, as he was already incarcerated on unrelated charges. His probation conditions prohibit him from owning or possessing animals and require a mental health evaluation. The Queen Anne's County Animal Abuse Registry, maintained by the county State's Attorney as mandated by County Ordinance 24-17, lists individuals convicted of animal abuse in county courts, Richardson noted.

title: Greensboro contractor sentenced for felony home improvement fraud
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Jeremy Bowen, 44, of Greensboro, was sentenced June 20 in Sussex County Superior Court in Delaware to six months in prison after pleading guilty to three counts of felony home improvement fraud. The plea, entered April 7, also covered one count of issuing a bad check and one count of misdemeanor home improvement fraud, resolving complaints that Bowen “had taken funds, then failed to perform in 13 contracts throughout Delaware's Kent and Sussex counties,” many involving swimming pool construction and several victims being seniors.

“Jeremy Bowen's deceitful actions didn't just hurt his victims financially — they caused a great deal of emotional and psychological distress to several families across our state,” said Delaware Attorney General Kathy Jennings. “Delawareans throughout the state pour their life savings into buying and then improving their homes; they need to be able to trust their contractors and that their funds will be used as promised. My white collar crime unit will continue to hold contractors who breach that trust accountable.”

In addition to the prison term, Bowen must pay approximately $270,000 in restitution, serve a year of home confinement after release, and is barred from working in home improvement for 4½ years.

title: How one Mid-Shore town plans to weather future storms
author: Staff Writer
content:
“Having spent my career in coastal communities, there is one issue I have covered again and again. Flooding has affected every community I have worked in — a major road washed out by stormwater or a business protecting its merchandise from knee-high surge,” the reporter notes, underscoring the region’s recurring struggle with rising water.  

Mid-Shore towns “know the issue well, and they are seeking solutions to help them fare better through large storms,” the story explains, framing the ongoing local effort to plan for future extreme-weather events.

title: Helmer Sworn In As Chief Deputy
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com
content:
Capt. Rodney “R.J.” Helmer, 38, was sworn in as chief deputy of the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office at 1 p.m. Friday, Dec. 8, in the Caroline County Circuit Court, with Clerk of Court Terry Lord administering the oath. A reception followed at the Sheriff’s Office on Double Hills Road in Denton. About 40 guests—including county commissioners, retired Sheriff Randy Bounds, Judge Heather Price, and Helmer’s family—gave him a standing ovation.

“R.J. has been with me through thick and thin at the sheriff’s office,” Sheriff Donnie Baker said. “He is true blue, and I really appreciate that, so it wasn’t really a hard choice for me.” Helmer thanked his predecessors: “I thank Sheriff Baker for the opportunity, and I wouldn’t have this opportunity if it weren’t for Sheriff Bounds. It’s a pleasure to work with each and every one of you, and I look forward to doing everything to the best of my ability.”

Bounds praised the new chief deputy: “R.J. is an outstanding police officer, a wonderful human being and one of the hardest working people that I’ve ever had the pleasure of working with. It was an honor to hire him, and I’ve never regretted that one second. He’s knowledgeable, energetic, and most supremely of all, he cares about those with whom he interacts. You will never, ever have to worry about his dedication and loyalty. He will serve the citizens of Caroline County well.”

Baker added, “He is an absolutely hardworking individual and a very capable individual to be my chief deputy and to lead this agency to the next level.”

Helmer began his law-enforcement career with the Cambridge Police Department in July 2008 and joined the Sheriff’s Office as a deputy first class on Aug. 19, 2013. He lives in Hurlock, where he served as chief of the Hurlock Volunteer Fire Company until Dec. 18. He formerly led the criminal investigation division as lieutenant; Lt. George Paugh, ex-chief of the Greensboro Police Department, was appointed to that post Nov. 1. Helmer succeeds Maj. James Henning, who retired in September after more than 26 years with the agency.

title: Attorney takes on ICE on Eastern Shore
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown criminal-defense and immigration attorney Ivette Furneisen says federal enforcement on Maryland’s Eastern Shore has intensified under the Trump administration. “In general, I see that people are being picked up and detained for minor traffic offenses,” she said, contrasting today’s practice with past ones in which “felonies and misdemeanors such as assault, theft, neglect of a minor and sex crimes would lead to deportation since they are crimes of moral turpitude. Under Trump however, people are being picked up for minor offenses and then targeted by ICE.”

Furneisen described a recent case in which a client acquitted of DUI after open containers were found in his car was later stopped by ICE agents while driving his pregnant wife home from a medical appointment. “Agents busted out the windows while his pregnant wife was in the car and detained him,” she said, adding that she and the man’s family did not know where he was for three days. She also reported undercover ICE agents arresting another client inside a courthouse: “I am seeing a lot of failure to appear in court, especially for minor traffic violations, and that makes things worse for those facing charges. I tell them they need to show up for court with a lawyer.”

The Spain-born naturalized U.S. citizen, who earned her law degree at the University of Barcelona and a U.S. law master’s from George Mason, is half of Campbell and Furneisen on Cross Street in Chestertown and one of the only Spanish-speaking lawyers on the Shore. She said her docket is overflowing: “I am swamped with work of this nature,” citing cases in Kent, Talbot and Queen Anne’s counties. She noted that many undocumented clients “pay taxes and they are contributing, but they are still getting deported.”

Furneisen criticized new federal efforts to curtail bond hearings, warning, “The problem is that this will lead to indefinite detention because there is a backlog in immigration court. These people could be detained for years before they have their immigration hearing.” She recalled one client who, after refusing to plead guilty to theft and paying restitution, was released by a judge but then given a choice by ICE: “get deported or sign a voluntary departure. He chose the latter and went back to an area where his brothers and cousins were tortured before being beheaded by a gang.” She added, “That’s why I fight so hard to keep them here, but sometimes everything goes against you and you lose those battles.”

Kent County Sheriff Dennis Hickman said his office’s policy remains unchanged: “In the past ICE has placed a detainer on illegal immigrants who were being held on local charges, but when the sentence was over they were required to come get them. That practice has not changed.” Furneisen, encouraged by high-profile reversals such as that of Kilmar Abrego Garcia, maintains, “Just because you’re being charged with a crime doesn’t mean you did it. I love my job in helping those who don’t have a voice and being an advocate for them.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on immigration enforcement, ICE actions, and the attorney's role in protecting clients from detention, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety.

title: Police seeking information in Bay Bridge crash
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland Transportation Authority Police are continuing to investigate a 23-vehicle crash that occurred on the westbound span of the Bay Bridge on Saturday, Jan. 27. “Investigators with the MDTA Police Collision Reconstruction Unit are completing a full reconstruction of the 23-vehicle crash,” officials reported.

According to the Collision Reconstruction Unit, “a blue 2018 Honda Civic sedan was being driven at high speeds and erratically prior to the crash and may have contributed to the crash.” Witnesses who saw the blue Honda Civic on westbound US-50 near the Bay Bridge between approximately 7:30 and 7:45 a.m. on Jan. 27 are asked to call the MDTA Police at 443-454-8703.

Police emphasized that “the reconstruction is a detailed process that typically takes months to complete as investigators analyze evidence such as interviews, physical evidence, medical records and more,” and noted that “any potential charges related to the crash are pending the conclusion of the investigation.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police investigation of a major traffic crash, focusing on safety, witness assistance, and law enforcement actions, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Rape charges against Cambridge man dropped; now facing 8 counts of sextortion
author: Konner Metz
content:
Devonte Rodriguez, 37, of Cambridge, is no longer facing rape charges after prosecutors opted not to pursue the first- and second-degree rape counts, among other sex offense, assault and firearms crimes, that had been scheduled for a two-day trial this week in Dorchester County Circuit Court.

Instead, on Aug. 19 Rodriguez was newly charged with seven misdemeanor counts and one felony count of causing/threatening a subject to engage in a visual representation or performance of sexual activity. Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard confirmed the eight new counts stem from the same 2024 incidents with a woman that led to the now-dropped charges.

According to court documents, Rodriguez is accused of demanding a then-18-year-old woman produce photos and videos sexual in nature on four separate occasions between March 16 and April 1, 2024. Cambridge Police Department investigators obtained message logs between Rodriguez and the woman, and police allege in court records that Rodriguez threatened to have the woman "physically assaulted by other parties for her failure to comply with his demands." In two instances, the woman did "acquiesce to the demands," police wrote. Investigators said social media messages reveal "her declining mental state and depression," and court records state the threats "inflicted emotional distress."

Rodriguez was released on his own recognizance on Aug. 19, and a hearing in district court is scheduled for Sept. 29.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on criminal charges and court proceedings, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Devonte Rodriguez, 37, of Cambridge
Amanda Leonard, Dorchester County State's Attorney
